paras.en: So in August my parents got this call from Mr. Tushman, the middle-school director. And my Mom said: "Maybe he calls all the new students to welcome them," and my dad said: "That's a lot of kids he'd be calling." So my mom called him back, and I could hear her talking to Mr. Tushman on the phone. This is exactly what she said: "Oh, hi, Mr. Tushman. This is Amanda Will, returning your call? Pause. Oh, thank you! That's so nice of you to say. He is looking forward to it. Pause. Yes. Pause. Yeah. Pause. Oh. Sure. Long pause. Ohhh. Uh-huh. Pause. Well, that's so nice of you to say. Pause. Sure. Ohh. Wow. Ohhhh. Super long pause. I see, of course. I'm sure he will. Let me write it down . . . got it. I'll call you after I've had a chance to talk to him, okay? Pause. No, thank you for thinking of him. Bye bye!"
paras.cn: 所以八月时，我父母接到了中学校长塔什曼先生的电话。我妈妈说：“也许他给所有新生打电话欢迎他们，” 我爸爸说：“那他要打的电话可真多。” 于是我妈妈给他回了电话，我能听到她在电话里和塔什曼先生说话。这正是她说的：“哦，嗨，塔什曼先生。我是阿曼达·威尔，回您的电话？（停顿）哦，谢谢您！您这么说真是太好了。他很期待。（停顿）是的。（停顿）嗯。（停顿）哦。当然。（长停顿）哦哦。嗯哼。（停顿）嗯，您这么说真是太好了。（停顿）当然。哦哦。哇。哦哦哦。（超长停顿）我明白了，当然。我肯定他会的。让我记下来……好了。我和他谈过之后会给您打电话，好吗？（停顿）不，谢谢您能想到他。再见！"

vocab.ex: She is the director of the marketing department.
We are here to welcome the new students to our school.
Please ask him to return my call when he gets back.
I'm looking forward to seeing you this weekend.
It was kind of you to think of me on my birthday.

gram.name: 单方对话叙事
gram.pattern: Transcribing one person's dialogue, including pauses and reactions.
gram.function: 通过只记录对话一方的言语和反应（包括'Pause', 'Long pause'等），作者创造了一种悬念和真实感。读者和叙述者一样，被迫根据这些零碎的线索来推断对话的全部内容，从而增强了参与感和好奇心。

example.en: I heard him on the phone: 'What? No! (Pause) I can't believe it. Okay. I'll be right there.'
example.cn: 我听到他在打电话：‘什么？不！（停顿）我真不敢相信。好的。我马上就到。’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过信息不对称来制造悬念的文学技巧。

paras.en: And when she hung up, I was like, "what's up, what did he say?" And Mom said: "Well, it's actually very flattering but kind of sad, too. See, there's this boy who's starting middle school this year, and he's never been in a real school environment before because he was homeschooled, so Mr. Tushman talked to some of the lower-school teachers to find out who they thought were some of the really, really great kids coming into fifth grade, and the teachers must have told him you were an especially nice kid—which I already knew, of course—and so Mr. Tushman is wondering if he could count on you to sort of shepherd this new boy around a bit?"
paras.cn: 当她挂断电话时，我忍不住问：“怎么了，他说了什么？” 妈妈说：“嗯，这其实很令人受宠若惊，但也有点伤感。你看，今年有个男孩要开始上中学了，他以前从未在真正的学校环境里待过，因为他是在家上学的，所以塔什曼先生和一些小学部的老师谈了谈，想了解他们认为有哪些真正非常棒的孩子要升入五年级，老师们肯定告诉他你是个特别好的孩子——当然，这一点我早就知道了——所以塔什曼先生想知道他是否能指望你稍微带领一下这个新男孩？"

vocab.ex: Don't hang up on me; we need to finish this conversation.
You seem really quiet today. What's up?
It's flattering to be asked for my opinion.
More and more parents are choosing to have their children homeschooled.
You can always count on him to be honest.
The tour guide will shepherd you around the museum.

gram.name: 长句（用于讲故事）
gram.pattern: A long sentence linked by multiple conjunctions ('and', 'so').
gram.function: 妈妈使用了一个很长的、由多个连词连接的句子来解释整个情况。这种结构模仿了口语中讲故事的自然流动感，将一系列事件和推论串联成一个连贯的叙述，让听者能够一口气了解事情的来龙去脉。

example.en: I went to the store and I bought some milk, and then I remembered I needed bread, so I went back to get it.
example.cn: 我去了商店，买了些牛奶，然后我想起来我需要面包，所以我又回去拿了。

gram.constraints: 在正式写作中可能被视为累赘句，但在模仿口语时非常有效。

paras.en: "Like let him hang out with me?" I said. "Exactly," said Mom. "He called it being a 'welcome buddy.' " "But why me?" "I told you. Your teachers told Mr. Tushman that you were the kind of kid who's known for being a good egg. I mean, I'm so proud that they think so highly of you. . . ."
paras.cn: “比如让他和我一起玩？” 我说。“完全正确，” 妈妈说。“他称之为当一个‘欢迎伙伴’。” “但为什么是我？” “我告诉过你了。你的老师们告诉塔什曼先生，你是那种以‘好人’著称的孩子。我的意思是，我真为他们这么看好你而感到骄傲……”

vocab.ex: "So you mean we have to start over?" "Exactly."
Each new student was assigned a welcome buddy to help them adjust.
He's a real good egg, always willing to help others.
His boss thinks very highly of his work ethic.

gram.name: known for being... 结构
gram.pattern: be known for + VERB-ing
gram.function: 表示“以…而闻名”。'...known for being a good egg' 解释了杰克被选中的原因——他的名声是建立在“是个好人”这个特质上的。

example.en: She is known for being a very generous person.
example.cn: 她以非常慷慨而闻名。

gram.constraints: 'for' 后面跟导致名声的原因或特质。

paras.en: "Why is it sad?" "What do you mean?" "You said it's flattering but kind of sad, too." "Oh." Mom nodded. "Well, apparently this boy has some sort of . . . um, I guess there's something wrong with his face . . . or something like that. Not sure. Maybe he was in an accident. Mr. Tushman said he'd explain a bit more when you come to the school next week."
paras.cn: “为什么伤感呢？” “你什么意思？” “你说那很令人受宠若惊，但也有点伤感。” “哦。” 妈妈点了点头。“嗯，显然这个男孩有某种……嗯，我猜他的脸有点问题……或者类似那样。不确定。也许他出过事故。塔什曼先生说下周你去学校时他会多解释一点。”

vocab.ex: It's flattering to be asked for my opinion.
Apparently, the meeting has been cancelled.
He seems to be in some sort of trouble.
He said he was a writer or something like that.

gram.name: 模糊和犹豫的语言
gram.pattern: Use of phrases like 'some sort of', 'um', 'I guess', 'or something like that', 'Not sure'.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列表示不确定和犹豫的词语，作者生动地表现了母亲在谈论一个敏感和她自己也不完全了解的话题时的不适和谨慎。这种语言选择使得对话非常真实，并向听者（和读者）暗示了情况的特殊性。

example.en: I think he's, um, maybe some sort of artist or something like that. I'm not sure.
example.cn: 我想他，嗯，也许是某种艺术家之类的。我不确定。

gram.constraints: 是口语中处理敏感或不确定信息时的常见策略。

paras.en: "School doesn't start till September!" "He wants you to meet this kid before school starts." "Do I have to?" Mom looked a bit surprised. "Well, no, of course not," she said, "but it would be the nice thing to do, Jack." "If I don't have to do it," I said, "I don't want to do it." "Can you at least think about it?"
paras.cn: “学校要到九月才开学呢！” “他想让你在开学前见见这个孩子。” “我非去不可吗？” 妈妈看起来有点惊讶。“嗯，不，当然不必，” 她说，“但那样做会是件友善的事，杰克。” “如果我不是非做不可，” 我说，“我就不想做。” “你至少能考虑一下吗？”

vocab.ex: The store is open from 9 AM till 9 PM.
Do I have to go to the meeting? It sounds really boring.
Helping her carry her groceries was the nice thing to do.
If you can't finish the whole report, at least write the introduction.

gram.name: 义务与道德选择的对比
gram.pattern: 'have to' vs. 'the nice thing to do'
gram.function: 这场对话的核心冲突在于对行为动机的定义。杰克关注的是 'have to'（外部强制的义务），而妈妈则试图引导他思考 'the nice thing to do'（内在的、自愿的道德选择）。这种对比揭示了成长过程中在责任和同理心之间的挣扎。

example.en: You don't have to apologize, but it would be the right thing to do.
example.cn: 你不是非道歉不可，但那会是正确的做法。

gram.constraints: 是讨论道德决策时的常见语言模式。

paras.en: "I'm thinking about it and I don't want to do it." "Well, I'm not going to force you," she said, "but at least think about it some more, okay? I'm not calling Mr. Tushman back until tomorrow, so just sit with it a bit. I mean, Jack, I really don't think it's that much to ask that you spend a little extra time with some new kid. . . ." "It's not just that he's a new kid, Mom," I answered. "He's deformed." "That's a terrible thing to say, Jack." "He is, Mom." "You don't even know who it is!" "Yeah, I do," I said, because I knew the second she started talking about him that it was that kid named August.
paras.cn: “我正在考虑，而且我不想做。” “嗯，我不会强迫你，” 她说，“但至少再多考虑一下，好吗？我明天才给塔什曼先生回电话，所以你就先琢磨琢磨。我的意思是，杰克，我真的不认为让你花一点额外的时间陪陪某个新孩子是多大的要求……” “问题不只是他是个新孩子，妈妈，” 我回答。“他畸形。” “说这种话太可怕了，杰克。” “他就是，妈妈。” “你甚至都不知道是谁！” “不，我知道，” 我说，因为她一开始谈论他时我就知道是那个叫奥古斯特的孩子。

vocab.ex: My parents never forced me to play a musical instrument.
That's a big decision. You should sit with it for a day or two before you answer.
I don't think a simple 'thank you' is that much to ask.
The accident left his hand permanently deformed.
Saying such mean things to your friend was a terrible thing to do.
I knew it was him the second I heard his voice.

gram.name: 委婉与直率的对比
gram.pattern: A contrast between vague, gentle language and a direct, harsh term.
gram.function: 这场对话的冲突高潮体现在语言选择上。妈妈一直使用模糊、委婉的语言（'something wrong with his face'），而杰克则用一个极其直率、残酷的词（'deformed'）来回应。这种语言上的巨大反差，深刻地揭示了成年人试图保护的“礼貌”与孩子直面残酷现实的视角之间的冲突。

example.en: The company called it 'downsizing,' but the employees called it 'getting fired.'
example.cn: 公司称之为“精简”，但员工们称之为“被解雇”。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过词汇选择来展示人物冲突和不同视角的有效技巧。

paras.en: I remember seeing him for the first time in front of the Carvel on Amesfort Avenue when I was about five or six. Me and Veronica, my babysitter, were sitting on the bench outside the store with Jamie, my baby brother, who was sitting in his stroller facing us. I guess I was busy eating my ice cream cone, because I didn't even notice the people who sat down next to us.
paras.cn: 我记得我第一次见到他是在大约五六岁时，在艾姆斯福特大道的Carvel冰淇淋店前。我和我的保姆维罗妮卡，正和我的小弟弟杰米一起坐在店外的长椅上，他坐在婴儿车里面对着我们。我猜我当时正忙着吃我的冰淇淋蛋筒，因为我甚至没注意到坐在我们旁边的人。

vocab.mean: 卡维尔（一个冰淇淋品牌/店名）
vocab.ex: Let's go get some ice cream at Carvel after dinner.
We need to find a reliable babysitter for Saturday night.
They sat on a park bench and watched the ducks.
She carefully pushed the stroller over the bumpy sidewalk.
On a hot day, there's nothing better than a cold ice cream cone.

gram.name: 过去进行时（用于设置场景）
gram.pattern: was/were + VERB-ing
gram.function: 用于描述在过去某个特定时间点正在进行的背景动作或状态。通过 'were sitting' 和 'was busy eating'，作者为故事的回忆创造了一个生动的、持续的背景画面。

example.en: The sun was shining and the birds were singing when I woke up.
example.cn: 我醒来时，阳光明媚，鸟儿在歌唱。

gram.constraints: 是叙事中设置背景的常用时态。

paras.en: Then at one point I turned my head to suck the ice cream out of the bottom of my cone, and that's when I saw him: August. He was sitting right next to me. I know it wasn't cool, but I kind of went "Uhh!" when I saw him because I honestly got scared. I thought he was wearing a zombie mask or something. It was the kind of "uhh" you say when you're watching a scary movie and the bad guy like jumps out of the bushes. Anyway, I know it wasn't nice of me to do that, and though the kid didn't hear me, I know his sister did.
paras.cn: 然后有那么一刻，我转过头去吸蛋筒底部的冰淇淋，就在那时我看到了他：奥古斯特。他正坐在我旁边。我知道那样做不酷，但我看到他时还是有点“呃！”地叫了出来，因为我真的吓到了。我以为他戴着僵尸面具之类的。就是那种你在看恐怖电影，坏人突然从灌木丛里跳出来时你会发出的“呃”声。总之，我知道我那样做不好，而且虽然那个孩子没听到我，我知道他姐姐听到了。

vocab.ex: At one point during the movie, almost everyone was crying.
The baby was sucking on his thumb.
He wore a terrifying zombie mask for Halloween.
A cat suddenly jumped out from behind the car.

gram.name: That's when... (用于强调时刻)
gram.pattern: That's when + clause
gram.function: 用于强调某个特定时刻的重要性，意为“就在那时…”。它将读者的注意力集中在一个关键的转折点上。'and that's when I saw him' 标志着故事中一个决定性的、改变一切的瞬间。

example.en: I was about to give up, and that's when the phone rang with good news.
example.cn: 我正要放弃，就在那时，电话响了，带来了好消息。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中创造戏剧性效果的常用手法。

paras.en: "Jack! We have to go!" said Veronica. She had gotten up and was turning the stroller around because Jamie, who had obviously just noticed the kid, too, was about to say something embarrassing. So I jumped up kind of suddenly, like a bee had landed on me, and followed Veronica as she zoomed away. I could hear the kid's mom saying softly behind us: "Okay, guys, I think it's time to go," and I turned around to look at them one more time. The kid was licking his ice cream cone, the mom was picking up his scooter, and the sister was glaring at me like she was going to kill me. I looked away quickly.
paras.cn: “杰克！我们得走了！” 维罗妮卡说。她已经站起来，正在转动婴儿车，因为杰米，他显然也刚注意到那个孩子，正要说些令人尴尬的话。于是我有点突然地跳了起来，就像有只蜜蜂落在了我身上一样，然后跟着维罗妮卡飞快地离开了。我能听到那个孩子的妈妈在我们身后轻声说：“好了，孩子们，我想是时候走了，” 我转过身又看了他们一眼。那个孩子在舔他的冰淇淋蛋筒，妈妈在捡他的滑板车，而那个姐姐正瞪着我，好像要杀了我一样。我迅速移开了目光。

vocab.ex: He was obviously tired after the long journey.
Forgetting his name was a very embarrassing moment.
The sports car zoomed away from the traffic light.
The children love riding their scooters in the park.
The teacher glared at the student who was talking in class.

gram.name: 过去进行时并列结构
gram.pattern: Subject 1 was VERB-ing, Subject 2 was VERB-ing, and Subject 3 was VERB-ing.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列并列的过去进行时，作者描绘了一幅同时发生的、电影般的“慢镜头”画面。'The kid was licking..., the mom was picking up..., and the sister was glaring...' 冻结了那个瞬间，让读者能清晰地看到每个角色的不同反应。

example.en: It was a chaotic scene: people were shouting, sirens were wailing, and cars were speeding away.
example.cn: 那是一个混乱的场面：人们在喊叫，警报在鸣响，汽车在飞速驶离。

gram.constraints: 是一种描绘复杂、同步场景的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: "Veronica, what was wrong with that kid?" I whispered. "Hush, boy!" she said, her voice angry. I love Veronica, but when she got mad, she got mad. Meanwhile, Jamie was practically spilling out of his stroller trying to get another look as Veronica pushed him away. "But, Vonica . . . ," said Jamie. "You boys were very naughty! Very naughty!" said Veronica as soon as we were farther down the block. "Staring like that!"
paras.cn: “维罗妮卡，那个孩子怎么了？” 我低声问。“安静，孩子！” 她说，声音很生气。我爱维罗妮卡，但她生气的时候就是真的生气了。与此同时，在维罗妮卡推着他走的时候，杰米几乎要从婴儿车里翻出来了，想再看一眼。“但是，沃尼卡……” 杰米说。“你们这些男孩太顽皮了！非常顽皮！” 我们走远一点后维罗妮卡立刻说。“那样盯着看！”

vocab.ex: Hush now, the baby is sleeping.
Too many books were packed into the box, and they started to spill out of the top.
The naughty puppy chewed on the new shoes.

gram.name: 同义反复（用于强调强度）
gram.pattern: when [Subject] [verb], [Subject] [verb].
gram.function: 通过重复同一个动词来构成一个看似没有信息量的句子（'when she got mad, she got mad'），说话者实际上是在强调该行为的绝对性和强度。在这里，它传达的意思是“她生气起来可不是闹着玩的”，突出了维罗妮卡愤怒的程度。

example.en: When he decides to work, he really works.
example.cn: 当他决定工作时，他是真的在工作。

gram.constraints: 是一种依赖上下文来理解其强调含义的修辞手法。

paras.en: "I didn't mean to!" I said. "Vonica," said Jamie. "Us leaving like that," Veronica was muttering. "Oh Lord, that poor lady. I tell you, boys. Every day we should thank the Lord for our blessings, you hear me?" "Vonica!" "What is it, Jamie?" "Is it Halloween?" "No, Jamie." "Then why was that boy wearing a mask?"
paras.cn: “我不是故意的！” 我说。“沃尼卡，” 杰米说。“我们那样离开，” 维罗妮卡在咕哝。“哦上帝，那个可怜的女士。我告诉你们，孩子们。我们每天都应该感谢上帝赐予我们的福气，你们听到了吗？” “沃尼卡！” “什么事，杰米？” “是万圣节吗？” “不，杰米。” “那为什么那个男孩戴着面具？”

vocab.ex: I'm sorry I broke your vase; I didn't mean to.
He was muttering to himself as he worked.
Oh Lord, I think I left the oven on.
Having good health is a true blessing.

gram.name: 戏剧性反讽
gram.pattern: A character's words or actions are clear to the audience but not to the character.
gram.function: 当小弟弟杰米天真地问“为什么那个男孩戴着面具？”时，读者（和在场的其他角色）知道他看到的并非面具，而是奥古斯特的真实面容。这种认知上的差异创造了戏剧性反讽。杰米的纯真问题，反而以一种最直接、最令人心碎的方式，突显了奥古斯特外貌的“异常”。

example.en: In the movie, the audience knows the killer is hiding in the closet, but the character does not.
example.cn: 在电影中，观众知道杀手藏在衣柜里，但角色不知道。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过信息不对称来产生强烈情感效果的文学技巧。

paras.en: Veronica didn't answer. Sometimes, when she was mad about something, she would do that. "He wasn't wearing a mask," I explained to Jamie. "Hush, Jack!" said Veronica. "Why are you so mad, Veronica?" I couldn't help asking. I thought this would make her angrier, but actually she shook her head. "It was bad how we did that," she said. "Just getting up like that, like we'd just seen the devil. I was scared for what Jamie was going to say, you know? I didn't want him to say anything that would hurt that little boy's feelings. But it was very bad, us leaving like that. The momma knew what was going on."
paras.cn: 维罗妮卡没有回答。有时候，当她为什么事生气时，她就会那样。“他没有戴面具，” 我向杰米解释。“安静，杰克！” 维罗妮卡说。“你为什么这么生气，维罗妮卡？” 我忍不住问。我以为这会让她更生气，但实际上她摇了摇头。“我们那样做很糟糕，” 她说。“就那样站起来，好像我们刚看到了魔鬼一样。我当时害怕杰米会说出什么话，你知道吗？我不想让他说任何会伤害那个小男孩感情的话。但我们那样离开真的很糟糕。那位妈妈知道发生了什么。”

vocab.ex: The joke was so funny, I couldn't help laughing.
He ran as if he had seen the devil himself.
I was scared for his safety when he went hiking alone in the mountains.
The little girl cried out for her momma.

gram.name: that 从句作主语（倒装）
gram.pattern: It was [adjective] + how + clause.
gram.function: 使用形式主语 'It'，将真正的主语（一个由 'how' 引导的名词性从句）后置，使得句子结构更平衡、更自然。'It was bad how we did that' 的意思是“我们那样做的方式很糟糕”，强调了行为的负面性。

example.en: It is amazing how quickly she learned the language.
example.cn: 她那么快就学会了那门语言，真是令人惊叹。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的处理长主语的句法结构。

paras.en: "But we didn't mean to," I answered. "Jack, sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone. You understand?" That was the first time I ever saw August in the neighborhood, at least that I remember. But I've seen him around ever since then: a couple of times in the playground, a few times in the park. He used to wear an astronaut helmet sometimes. But I always knew it was him underneath the helmet. All the kids in the neighborhood knew it was him. Everyone has seen August at some point or another. We all know his name, though he doesn't know ours.
paras.cn: “但我们不是故意的，” 我回答。“杰克，有时候你伤害一个人并不需要是故意的。你明白吗？” 那是我第一次在社区里见到奥古斯特，至少是我记得的第一次。但从那以后我就经常在附近见到他：在操场上几次，在公园里几次。他过去有时会戴一个宇航员头盔。但我总知道头盔下面是他。社区里所有的孩子都知道是他。每个人都在某个时候见过奥古斯特。我们都知道他的名字，尽管他不知道我们的。

vocab.ex: I'm sorry I broke your vase; I didn't mean to.
This is a quiet and friendly neighborhood.
Even if you can't come, at least give me a call.
He found a hidden key underneath the welcome mat.
Everyone makes a mistake at some point or another in their life.

gram.name: 悖论陈述（用于道德教诲）
gram.pattern: You don't have to [intent] to [action].
gram.function: 通过一个看似悖论的句子 'sometimes you don't have to mean to hurt someone to hurt someone'，维罗妮卡传达了一个深刻的道德教训：行为的后果比意图更重要。这种结构通过重复动词 'hurt'，有力地区分了“主观意图”和“客观结果”，发人深省。

example.en: You don't have to want to fail to fail; sometimes just not trying is enough.
example.cn: 你不是非得想失败才会失败；有时候仅仅不努力就足够了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过语言张力来传达复杂思想的高级修辞手法。

paras.en: And whenever I've seen him, I try to remember what Veronica said. But it's hard. It's hard not to sneak a second look. It's hard to act normal when you see him.
paras.cn: 而且每当我看到他时，我都试着记住维罗妮卡说的话。但这很难。很难不偷偷再看一眼。在他面前很难表现得正常。

vocab.ex: You can call me whenever you need help.
The painting was so strange that I had to sneak a second look.
Even though he was nervous, he tried to act normal during the interview.

gram.name: 使用 'It's hard...' 的平行结构
gram.pattern: It's hard. It's hard to [action A]. It's hard to [action B].
gram.function: 通过重复 'It's hard...' 结构，作者层层递进地描述了叙述者内心的挣扎。从一个笼统的陈述（'It's hard'）到两个具体的困难（'not to sneak a second look', 'to act normal'），这种排比有力地传达了在面对奥古斯特时，想要做到“正确”是多么困难，展现了深刻的诚实和自我反思。

example.en: It's hard to start over. It's hard to trust again. It's hard to forget the past.
example.cn: 重新开始很难。再次信任很难。忘记过去很难。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过重复来表达内心挣扎和困难程度的有效手法。

paras.en: "Who else did Mr. Tushman call?" I asked Mom later that night. "Did he tell you?" "He mentioned Julian and Charlotte." "Julian!" I said. "Ugh. Why Julian?" "You used to be friends with Julian!" "Mom, that was like in kindergarten. Julian's the biggest phony there is. And he's trying so hard to be popular all the time." "Well," said Mom, "at least Julian agreed to help this kid out. Got to give him credit for that."
paras.cn: “塔什曼先生还给谁打了电话？” 那天晚上晚些时候我问妈妈。“他告诉你了吗？” “他提到了朱利安和夏洛特。” “朱利安！” 我说。“呃。为什么是朱利安？” “你以前和朱利安是朋友！” “妈，那都像是在幼儿园的时候了。朱利安是天底下最大的伪君子。而且他总是那么努力地想受欢迎。” “嗯，” 妈妈说，“至少朱利安同意帮助这个孩子。这点你得承认他做得不错。”

vocab.ex: Did he mention what time the meeting starts?
Ugh, I have to clean my room today.
He pretended to be my friend, but I could tell he was a phony.
She is the most popular student in her class.

vocab.mean: 为（某事）称赞某人；承认某人的优点
vocab.ex: I have to give her credit for trying, even though she didn't succeed.

gram.name: 口语化最高级
gram.pattern: the + superlative + Noun + there is
gram.function: 一种非正式但非常强调的最高级用法，意为“世上最大的…”或“莫过于…”。'Julian's the biggest phony there is' 是一种比简单说 'He's the biggest phony' 语气更强烈的表达。

example.en: That is the best pizza there is.
example.cn: 那是世上最好吃的披萨。

gram.constraints: 常见于口语和非正式写作中。

paras.en: I didn't say anything because she was right. "What about Charlotte?" I asked. "Is she doing it, too?" "Yes," Mom said. "Of course she is. Charlotte's such a Goody Two-Shoes," I answered. "Boy, Jack," said Mom, "you seem to have a problem with everybody these days." "It's just . . . ," I started. "Mom, you have no idea what this kid looks like." "I can imagine." "No! You can't! You've never seen him. I have."
paras.cn: 我什么也没说，因为她是对的。“夏洛特呢？” 我问。“她也做吗？” “是的，” 妈妈说。“她当然会做。夏洛特就是个乖乖牌，” 我回答。“天哪，杰克，” 妈妈说，“你最近好像看谁都有问题。” “只是……，” 我开口说。“妈，你根本不知道这个孩子长什么样。” “我能想象。” “不！你不能！你从没见过他。我见过。”

vocab.ex: She's such a Goody Two-Shoes, always following the rules and telling on others.
He seems to have a problem with anyone who disagrees with him.
It's hard to find a good job these days.
You have no idea how difficult this has been for me.

gram.name: 感叹词 Boy
gram.pattern: Boy, + [statement].
gram.function: 在句首使用 'Boy,' 是一种非正式的感叹词，用于强调接下来的陈述，通常表达惊讶、沮丧或强烈的感受。'Boy, Jack, you seem to have a problem...' 强调了妈妈对杰克态度的惊讶和担忧。

example.en: Boy, am I tired today!
example.cn: 天哪，我今天可真累！

gram.constraints: 是一种口语化的表达方式。

paras.en: "It might not even be who you're thinking it is." "Trust me, it is. And I'm telling you, it's really, really bad. He's deformed, Mom. His eyes are like down here." I pointed to my cheeks. "And he has no ears. And his mouth is like . . ." Jamie had walked into the kitchen to get a juice box from the fridge. "Ask Jamie," I said. "Right, Jamie? Remember that kid we saw in the park after school last year? The kid named August? The one with the face?"
paras.cn: “甚至可能不是你想的那个人。” “相信我，就是他。我跟你说，情况真的非常非常糟糕。他畸形，妈妈。他的眼睛像是在这儿。” 我指着我的脸颊。“而且他没有耳朵。他的嘴巴像……” 杰米走进厨房，想从冰箱里拿一盒果汁。“问杰米，” 我说。“对吧，杰米？还记得去年放学后我们在公园里看到的那个孩子吗？那个叫奥古斯特的孩子？就是那张脸的那个？"

vocab.ex: Trust me, this is the best way to do it.
The accident left his hand permanently deformed.
She packed a sandwich and a juice box for her daughter's lunch.
I'll take the one with the blue stripes.

gram.name: 话语中断与手势
gram.pattern: Verbal description combined with physical gestures and incomplete sentences.
gram.function: 当角色难以用语言描述某事时，他们可能会中断话语并辅以手势。'His eyes are like down here.' (配合指脸颊的动作) 和 'And his mouth is like...' (话语中断) 真实地反映了角色在描述一个令人不安或难以言喻的事物时的挣扎，比直接的描述更具冲击力。

example.en: The fish I caught was this big! (spreading hands apart)
example.cn: 我抓到的鱼有这么大！（张开双手）

gram.constraints: 是一种非常生动的叙事技巧，结合了言语和非言语交流。

paras.en: "Oh, that kid?" said Jamie, his eyes opening wide. "He gave me a nightmare!! Remember, Mommy? That nightmare about the zombies from last year?" "I thought that was from watching a scary movie!" answered Mom. "No!" said Jamie, "it was from seeing that kid! When I saw him, I was like, 'Ahhh!' and I ran away. . . ."
paras.cn: “哦，那个孩子？” 杰米说，眼睛睁得大大的。“他让我做了噩梦！！记得吗，妈咪？去年那个关于僵尸的噩梦？” “我以为那是看了一部恐怖电影才做的！” 妈妈回答。“不！” 杰米说，“是因为看到那个孩子！我看到他的时候，我就‘啊！’地叫了一声，然后跑开了……”

vocab.ex: His eyes opened wide in surprise when he saw the gift.
I had a terrible nightmare about being chased by a monster.
The movie was about a zombie apocalypse.
The cat ran away when it saw the dog.

gram.name: I was like... (用于描述反应)
gram.pattern: I was like, '...'
gram.function: 在非正式的口语叙事中，'be like' 不仅可以引述说的话，还可以用来描述一个反应或发出的声音。'When I saw him, I was like, 'Ahhh!'' 生动地再现了杰米当时本能的、非语言的惊吓反应。

example.en: The roller coaster dropped, and I was like, 'Whoa!'
example.cn: 过山车俯冲下去，我当时就‘哇！’地叫了出来。

gram.constraints: 主要用于非正式口语和模仿口语的写作中。

paras.en: "Wait a minute," said Mom, getting serious. "Did you do that in front of him?" "I couldn't help it!" said Jamie, kind of whining. "Of course you could help it!" Mom scolded. "Guys, I have to tell you, I'm really disappointed by what I'm hearing here." And she looked like how she sounded. "I mean, honestly, he's just a little boy—just like you! Can you imagine how he felt to see you running away from him, Jamie, screaming?"
paras.cn: “等一下，” 妈妈说，严肃起来。“你是在他面前那么做的吗？” “我忍不住！” 杰米有点 whining 地说。“你当然能忍住！” 妈妈训斥道。“孩子们，我得告诉你们，我对在这里听到的事感到非常失望。” 而且她的表情和她的语气一样。“我的意思是，说真的，他只是个小男孩——就像你一样！你能想象他看到你尖叫着从他身边跑开时是什么感受吗，杰米？”

vocab.ex: The mood in the room got serious when they started discussing the budget cuts.
The joke was so funny, I couldn't help laughing.
The child started whining because he didn't get the toy he wanted.
The teacher had to scold the student for misbehaving.
She was disappointed by the ending of the movie.

gram.name: 连接外貌与声音的明喻
gram.pattern: looked like how she sounded
gram.function: 通过一个联觉（synesthesia）式的比喻，将视觉（'looked'）和听觉（'sounded'）联系起来，创造了一种统一而强烈的感官印象，有力地传达了母亲当时失望和严肃的整体状态。

example.en: Her voice felt like a warm hug.
example.cn: 她的声音感觉像一个温暖的拥抱。

gram.constraints: 是一种高级的文学描述手法。

paras.en: "It wasn't a scream," argued Jamie. "It was like an 'Ahhh!' " He put his hands on his cheeks and started running around the kitchen. "Come on, Jamie!" said Mom angrily. "I honestly thought both my boys were more sympathetic than that." "What's sympathetic?" said Jamie, who was only going into the second grade. "You know exactly what I mean by sympathetic, Jamie," said Mom. "It's just he's so ugly, Mommy," said Jamie.
paras.cn: “那不是尖叫，” 杰米争辩道。“那更像是‘啊！’的一声。” 他把手放在脸颊上，开始在厨房里跑来跑去。“好了，杰米！” 妈妈生气地说。“我真的以为我的两个儿子都比那更有同情心。” “什么是同情心？” 杰米说，他才刚要上二年级。“你完全明白我说的同情心是什么意思，杰米，” 妈妈说。“只是他太丑了，妈咪，” 杰米说。

vocab.ex: It's pointless to argue with him when he's in that mood.
Oh, come on, you can't be serious!
She has a sympathetic ear for anyone with a problem.
Next year, my son will be going into high school.
The villain in the story was described as an ugly old witch.

gram.name: 戏剧性反讽与童真
gram.pattern: A young character's blunt honesty reveals a harsh truth.
gram.function: 杰米的童言无忌（先问 'What's sympathetic?'，然后直接说 'he's so ugly'）创造了强烈的戏剧性反讽。他因为年幼而不理解“同情心”这个抽象概念，却用最直白、最残酷的语言说出了成年人极力回避的“真相”。这种对比突显了儿童的纯真（或残忍的诚实）与成人世界复杂社交规则之间的冲突。

example.en: The child pointed at the emperor and shouted, 'But he isn't wearing any clothes!'
example.cn: 那个孩子指着皇帝喊道：‘可他什么衣服也没穿呀！’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过儿童视角来揭示成人世界伪善的经典文学手法。

paras.en: "Hey!" Mom yelled, "I don't like that word! Jamie, just get your juice box. I want to talk to Jack alone for a second." "Look, Jack," said Mom as soon as he left, and I knew she was about to give me a whole speech. "Okay, I'll do it," I said, which completely shocked her. "You will?" "Yes!" "So I can call Mr. Tushman?" "Yes! Mom, yes, I said yes!" Mom smiled. "I knew you'd rise to the occasion, kiddo. Good for you. I'm proud of you, Jackie." She messed up my hair.
paras.cn: “嘿！” 妈妈喊道，“我不喜欢那个词！杰米，去拿你的果汁盒。我想和杰克单独谈一下。” “听着，杰克，” 他一离开妈妈就说，我知道她要给我来一番长篇大论了。“好吧，我做，” 我说，这让她完全惊呆了。“你会做？” “是的！” “那我能给塔什曼先生打电话了？” “是的！妈妈，是的，我说了是的！” 妈妈笑了。“我就知道你会挺身而出的，孩子。好样的。我为你骄傲，杰奇。” 她弄乱了我的头发。

vocab.ex: I'm not in the mood for another speech about my responsibilities.
The news of his resignation will shock everyone.
When the team's star player got injured, the rookie rose to the occasion and scored the winning goal.
"Time for bed, kiddo," said the father.
You got the promotion? Good for you!
He playfully messed up his little brother's hair.

gram.name: 为回避而突然同意
gram.pattern: Anticipating a lecture and agreeing preemptively.
gram.function: 杰克预见到妈妈将要开始一番“长篇大论”（'a whole speech'），为了避免这场说教，他立刻、抢先地同意了妈妈的要求（'Okay, I'll do it'）。这是一种非常真实的孩子气的回避策略，其行为动机是避免麻烦，而非真正的思想转变。

example.en: As his mom opened her mouth to scold him, he quickly said, 'Okay, okay, I'll clean my room right now!'
example.cn: 当他妈妈张嘴要训他时，他赶紧说：‘好了，好了，我现在就去打扫我的房间！’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行动来控制对话走向的技巧。

paras.en: So here's why I changed my mind. It wasn't so I wouldn't have to hear Mom give me a whole lecture. And it wasn't to protect this August kid from Julian, who I knew would be a jerk about the whole thing. It was because when I heard Jamie talking about how he had run away from August going 'Ahhh,' I suddenly felt really bad. The thing is, there are always going to be kids like Julian who are jerks. But if a little kid like Jamie, who's usually a nice enough kid, can be that mean, then a kid like August doesn't stand a chance in middle school.
paras.cn: 所以这就是我改变主意的原因。不是为了不用听妈妈给我来一番长篇大论。也不是为了保护这个叫奥古斯特的孩子免受朱利安的伤害，我知道朱利安会对整件事表现得很混蛋。而是因为当我听到杰米谈论他如何‘啊’地一声从奥古斯特身边跑开时，我突然感觉非常糟糕。问题是，总会有像朱利安那样混蛋的孩子。但如果像杰米这样通常还算不错的孩子都能那么刻薄，那么像奥古斯特这样的孩子在中学里就毫无机会了。

vocab.ex: I don't need a lecture on being on time; I know I was late.
Sunscreen helps to protect your skin from the sun.
Don't be such a jerk to your little sister.
He's a nice enough guy, but we don't have much in common.
With such a strong opponent, he doesn't stand a chance of winning.

gram.name: 澄清动机的修辞结构
gram.pattern: It wasn't [reason A]. And it wasn't [reason B]. It was because [true reason C].
gram.function: 一种强有力的论证结构，通过首先否定几个表面上或看似合理的理由，然后再揭示出真正深刻的、内在的动机。这种“排除法”式的阐述，使得最终揭示的真正原因（对弟弟处境的深刻同情和担忧）显得格外真诚和有力。

example.en: I didn't do it for the money. I didn't do it for the fame. I did it because it was the right thing to do.
example.cn: 我不是为了钱才做的。我也不是为了名声。我这么做是因为那是正确的事。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常有效的、用于构建论点和揭示深层动机的修辞手法。

paras.en: First of all, you do get used to his face. The first couple of times I was like, whoa, I'm never going to get used to this. And then, after about a week, I was like, huh, it's not so bad.
paras.cn: 首先，你确实会习惯他的脸。最初几次我想的是，哇，我永远也习惯不了这个。然后，大约一周后，我想的是，嗯，没那么糟。

vocab.ex: First of all, let's review what we learned last week.
It took a while for him to get used to his new job.
Whoa, look at the size of that dog!
The movie wasn't great, but it was not so bad either.

gram.name: 列举标志词 (First of all...)
gram.pattern: First of all, [point 1]. Second of all, [point 2].
gram.function: 用作话语标记，清晰地引出系列要点中的第一点。它为整个段落设置了一个有组织的、清单式的结构，预示着后面还会有其他要点。

example.en: There are two reasons I can't go. First of all, I'm too busy. Second of all, I don't have a car.
example.cn: 我有两个理由不能去。首先，我太忙了。其次，我没有车。

gram.constraints: 是组织论点或陈述的常用方式。

paras.en: Second of all, he's actually a really cool dude. I mean, he's pretty funny. Like, the teacher will say something and August will whisper something funny to me that no one else hears and totally make me crack up. He's also just, overall, a nice kid. Like, he's easy to hang out with and talk to and stuff.
paras.cn: 其次，他实际上是个很酷的家伙。我的意思是，他挺好笑的。比如，老师会说些什么，然后奥古斯特会对我耳语一些别人听不到的有趣的话，完全让我笑翻。而且总的来说，他也是个好孩子。比如，他很容易相处，可以一起玩，聊天什么的。

vocab.ex: First of all, it's too expensive. Second of all, we don't need it.
He's known as a really cool dude who gets along with everyone.
His funny story made everyone in the room crack up.
There were a few minor problems, but overall, the event was a success.
He likes to hang out with his friends on the weekend.
We talked about movies, music, and stuff.

gram.name: Like (用于举例)
gram.pattern: Statement. Like, [example].
gram.function: 在非正式口语中，'Like' 常被用作话语标记，来引出一个具体的例子或进一步的解释。'he's pretty funny. Like, the teacher will say...' 和 'he's a nice kid. Like, he's easy to hang out with...' 都使用了这种方式，使叙述更具对话感和具体性。

example.en: He's very talented. Like, he can play three different instruments.
example.cn: 他非常有才华。比如，他会演奏三种不同的乐器。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常常见的口语化表达。

paras.en: Third of all, he's really smart. I thought he'd be behind everyone because he hadn't gone to school before. But in most things he's way ahead of me. I mean, maybe not as smart as Charlotte or Ximena, but he's up there. And unlike Charlotte or Ximena, he lets me cheat off of him if I really need to (though I've only needed to a couple of times). He also let me copy his homework once, though we both got in trouble for it after class.
paras.cn: 第三，他真的很聪明。我原以为他会落后于所有人，因为他以前没上过学。但在大多数事情上，他都遥遥领先于我。我的意思是，也许不像夏洛特或西梅纳那么聪明，但他也属于上游水平了。而且不像夏洛特或西梅纳，如果我真的需要，他会让我抄他的（尽管我只需要过几次）。有一次他还让我抄了他的作业，不过之后我们俩都因此惹上了麻烦。

vocab.ex: Third of all, we need to consider the budget.
After missing a week of school, she was behind in her classes.
In terms of technology, that company is way ahead of its competitors.
She's not the best student, but in math she's definitely up there.
The teacher caught him trying to cheat off of his neighbor's test.
He got in trouble at school for talking during class.

gram.name: Unlike (用于对比)
gram.pattern: Unlike + Noun, + [contrasting statement].
gram.function: 用于引出一个对比对象，强调主语与该对象在某个方面的不同之处。'And unlike Charlotte or Ximena, he lets me cheat...' 突出了奥古斯特在这一点上与其他聪明孩子的不同，从而展现了他的友善和义气。

example.en: Unlike his brother, he is very quiet and shy.
example.cn: 和他兄弟不同，他非常安静和害羞。

gram.constraints: 是一种清晰的对比手法。

paras.en: "The two of you got the exact same answers wrong on yesterday's homework," Ms. Rubin said, looking at both of us like she was waiting for an explanation. I didn't know what to say, because the explanation would have been: Oh, that's because I copied August's homework. But August lied to protect me. He was like, "Oh, that's because we did our homework together last night," which wasn't true at all.
paras.cn: “你们俩昨天作业里答错的答案一模一样，” 鲁宾女士说，看着我们俩，好像在等一个解释。我不知道该说什么，因为解释本该是：哦，那是因为我抄了奥古斯特的作业。但奥古斯特为了保护我而撒了谎。他当时就说：“哦，那是因为我们昨晚一起做的作业，” 这根本就不是真的。

vocab.ex: We showed up at the party wearing the exact same dress!
He offered a long explanation for why he was late.
He had to lie to his parents about where he had been.
The mother bear will do anything to protect her cubs.

gram.name: 隐含的第三条件句
gram.pattern: would have + past participle (without the 'if' clause)
gram.function: 用于描述一个在过去本可能发生但并未发生的行为，其条件在上下文中是隐含的。'...the explanation would have been: ...' 的意思是“（如果我说了实话）解释就会是：…”，表达了一种与过去事实相反的假设。

example.en: I was sick, otherwise I would have come to your party.
example.cn: 我病了，否则我就会来参加你的派对了。

gram.constraints: 是一种高级的虚拟语气用法，依赖上下文来理解其条件。

paras.en: "Well, doing homework together is a good thing," Ms. Rubin answered, "but you're supposed to still do it separately, okay? You could work side by side if you want, but you can't actually do your homework together, okay? Got it?" After we left the classroom, I said: "Dude, thanks for doing that." And he was like, "No problem."
paras.cn: “嗯，一起做作业是件好事，” 鲁宾女士回答，“但你们仍然应该分开做，好吗？如果你们想，可以并排坐着学习，但你们不能真的‘一起’做作业，好吗？明白了吗？” 离开教室后，我说：“老兄，谢谢你那么做。” 他当时就说：“没问题。”

vocab.ex: You were supposed to finish your homework before watching TV.
Please pay for your items separately.
They walked down the street side by side.
The deadline is Friday. Got it?
Hey dude, what's up?
"Thanks for your help!" "No problem."

gram.name: 重复以示澄清 (okay?)
gram.pattern: Repeating a tag question for confirmation.
gram.function: 老师通过重复 'okay?' 并最后加上 'Got it?'，来强调她所设定的规则的重要性，并确保学生们确实理解了“合作”和“抄袭”之间的界限。

example.en: You need to finish this by five, okay? No excuses, okay?
example.cn: 你必须在五点前完成这个，好吗？没有任何借口，好吗？

gram.constraints: 是一种在口头指令中常见的强调方式。

paras.en: That was cool. Fourthly, now that I know him, I would say I actually do want to be friends with August. At first, I admit it, I was only friendly to him because Mr. Tushman asked me to be especially nice and all that. But now I would choose to hang out with him. He laughs at all my jokes. And I kind of feel like I can tell August anything. Like he's a good friend. Like, if all the guys in the fifth grade were lined up against a wall and I got to choose anyone I wanted to hang out with, I would choose August.
paras.cn: 那很酷。第四，既然我现在了解他了，我会说我真的想和奥古斯特做朋友。起初，我承认，我对他友好只是因为塔什曼先生让我对他特别好之类的。但现在我会选择和他一起玩。他会笑我所有的笑话。而且我有点感觉我什么都可以告诉奥古斯特。就像他是个好朋友一样。比如，如果五年级所有的男生都靠墙站成一排，让我选任何我想一起玩的人，我会选奥古斯特。

vocab.ex: And fourthly, we must consider the long-term consequences.
Now that you're here, you can help me with this.
He finally had to admit that he had made a mistake.
He talked about his job, his family, and all that.
The suspects were told to line up against the wall.

gram.name: 用假设情境来证明观点
gram.pattern: If [hypothetical scenario], I would [choice].
gram.function: 通过构建一个极端的、可视化的假设情境（'if all the guys... were lined up against a wall...'），叙述者得以用一种非常有力和明确的方式来表达他情感的深度和选择的坚定性。这个“终极选择”的场景，比任何直接的陈述都更能证明他友谊的真诚。

example.en: If I could only eat one food for the rest of my life, I would choose pizza.
example.cn: 如果我余生只能吃一种食物，我会选披萨。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过想象的场景来强调情感或信念的有效修辞手法。

paras.en: Bleeding Scream? What the heck? Summer Dawson has always been a bit out there, but this was too much. All I did was ask her why August was acting like he was mad at me or something. I figured she would know. And all she said was "Bleeding Scream"? I don't even know what that means.
paras.cn: 流血鬼脸？什么鬼？萨默·道森一直都有点古怪，但这太过分了。我只是问她为什么奥古斯特表现得好像生我的气了什么的。我琢磨着她会知道。结果她只说了“流血鬼脸”？我甚至都不知道那是什么意思。

vocab.ex: What the heck are you doing in my room?
Some of his ideas are a little out there, but he's a creative thinker.
His constant complaining is just too much for me to handle.
Stop acting like a child and take some responsibility.

gram.name: 反问句（用于表达沮丧）
gram.pattern: A series of questions to express confusion and annoyance.
gram.function: 说话者通过提出一系列反问句（'Bleeding Scream?', 'What the heck?'），但并不期望得到回答，而是为了表达自己极度的困惑和沮丧。这是一种非常生动的、模仿内心独白的方式，让读者立刻感受到叙述者的情绪。

example.en: He cancelled the meeting again? What is wrong with him?
example.cn: 他又取消了会议？他到底怎么了？

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中表达强烈情感的方式。

paras.en: It's so weird because one day, me and August were friends. And the next day, whoosh, he was hardly talking to me. And I haven't the slightest idea why. When I said to him, "Hey, August, you mad at me or something?" he shrugged and walked away. So I would take that as a definite yes. And since I know for a fact that I didn't do anything to him to be mad about, I figured Summer could tell me what's up. But all I got from her was "Bleeding Scream"? Yeah, big help. Thanks, Summer.
paras.cn: 这太奇怪了，因为前一天，我和奥古斯特还是朋友。第二天，嗖的一声，他几乎不和我说话了。我一点都不知道为什么。当我跟他说：“嘿，奥古斯特，你生我气了还是怎么了？” 他耸了耸肩就走开了。所以我把那当成是明确的“是的”。而且既然我确切地知道我没做任何让他生气的事，我琢磨着萨默能告诉我怎么回事。但我从她那里得到的只有“流血鬼脸”？是啊，帮大忙了。谢了，萨默。

vocab.mean: 嗖（拟声词，表示快速移动）
vocab.ex: The car went by with a whoosh.
It was so foggy, I could hardly see the road.
I don't have the slightest idea how to fix this computer.
I know for a fact that he was not there last night.
You spilled coffee all over my work? Wow, you're a big help.

gram.name: 反讽（用于表达沮丧）
gram.pattern: Saying the opposite of what you mean.
gram.function: 通过说出与真实意图相反的话来表达不满。'Yeah, big help. Thanks, Summer.' 显然不是在真心感谢，而是一种反讽，用来表达叙述者对萨默那个神秘提示的极度沮丧和不解。

example.en: You're an hour late? Great timing!
example.cn: 你迟到了一个小时？时机真棒！

gram.constraints: 理解反讽需要依赖上下文和语气。

paras.en: You know, I've got plenty of other friends in school. So if August wants to officially be my ex-friend, then fine, that is okay by me, see if I care. I've started ignoring him like he's ignoring me in school now. This is actually kind of hard since we sit next to each other in practically every class.
paras.cn: 你知道吗，我在学校还有很多其他朋友。所以如果奥古斯特想正式成为我的前朋友，那行，我无所谓，看我是否在乎。我现在也开始在学校里像他无视我一样无视他。这其实有点难，因为我们几乎每节课都坐在一起。

vocab.ex: Don't worry, we have plenty of time.
The new park will officially open next month.
We had a big argument, and now he's my ex-friend.
If you want to leave early, that's okay by me.

vocab.mean: 看我是否在乎（表示不在乎）
vocab.ex: You can go to the party without me, see if I care.
He tried to talk to her, but she just ignored him.

gram.name: 假装不在乎
gram.pattern: A series of statements claiming not to care.
gram.function: 通过一连串表示不在乎的短语（'then fine', 'okay by me', 'see if I care'），叙述者试图说服自己（和读者）他并不在乎失去这段友谊。然而，这种强烈的、反复的声明反而暴露了他内心的在乎和受伤。这是一种通过语言来掩饰真实情感的防御机制。

example.en: So you're leaving? Fine. Go. I don't need you anyway.
example.cn: 所以你要走了？行。走吧。我反正也不需要你。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、表达“口是心非”的心理状态的方式。

paras.en: Other kids have noticed and have started asking if me and August have had a fight. Nobody asks August what's going on. Hardly anyone ever talks to him, anyway. I mean, the only person he hangs out with, other than me, is Summer. Sometimes he hangs out with Reid Kingsley a little bit, and the two Maxes got him playing Dungeons & Dragons a couple of times at recess. Charlotte, for all her Goody Two- Shoeing, doesn't ever do more than nod hello when she's passing him in the hallway. And I don't know if everyone's still playing the Plague behind his back, because no one ever really told me about it directly, but my point is that it's not like he has a whole lot of other friends he could be hanging out with instead of me. If he wants to dis me, he's the one who loses—not me.
paras.cn: 其他孩子注意到了，开始问我和奥古斯特是不是吵架了。没人问奥古斯特发生了什么。反正几乎没人跟他说话。我的意思是，除了我，他唯一一起玩的人就是萨默。有时他会和里德·金斯利玩一小会儿，两个马克斯在课间休息时拉他玩过几次《龙与地下城》。夏洛特，尽管她那么爱当乖乖牌，但在走廊里经过他时，也顶多就是点个头问好。而且我不知道大家是不是还在他背后玩“瘟疫”游戏，因为从没人直接告诉过我，但我的观点是，他并没有一大堆其他朋友可以替代我一起玩。如果他想不尊重我，吃亏的是他——不是我。

vocab.ex: Hardly anyone came to the meeting because of the bad weather.
He likes to hang out with his friends on the weekend.

vocab.mean: 龙与地下城（一种桌面角色扮演游戏）
vocab.ex: They spend their weekends playing Dungeons & Dragons in the basement.
For all her wealth, she was not a happy person.
It's going to take a whole lot of effort to finish this on time.
I can't believe he would dis me like that in front of everyone.

gram.name: My point is that...
gram.pattern: My point is that + clause.
gram.function: 用于总结前面的论述并引出核心观点。在列举了奥古斯特有限的社交圈之后，叙述者使用 'my point is that...' 来强调他的结论：奥古斯特并没有很多朋友，因此疏远“我”对他自己是更大的损失。

example.en: I know it's expensive and it takes a long time, but my point is that it's worth it in the end.
example.cn: 我知道这很贵而且要花很长时间，但我的观点是，这最终是值得的。

gram.constraints: 是一种在辩论或解释中常见的、用于澄清核心论点的短语。

paras.en: So this is how things are between us now. We only talk to each other about school stuff if we absolutely have to. Like, I'll say, "What did Rubin say the homework was?" and he'll answer. Or he'll be like, "Can I use your pencil sharpener?" and I'll get my sharpener out of my pencil case for him. But as soon as the bell rings, we go our separate ways.
paras.cn: 所以现在我们之间就是这样。我们只在绝对必要的时候才和对方谈论学校的事情。比如，我会说：“鲁宾说了作业是什么？” 然后他会回答。或者他会说：“我能用一下你的卷笔刀吗？” 然后我会从我的铅笔盒里拿出卷笔刀给他。但铃声一响，我们就分道扬镳了。

vocab.ex: We need to buy some school stuff like notebooks and pens.
You must absolutely finish this by tomorrow.
Can I borrow your pencil sharpener for a second?
He keeps all his pens and pencils in a small pencil case.
Please call me as soon as you arrive.
After the movie, we went our separate ways.

gram.name: 通过假设性对话进行说明
gram.pattern: Like, [hypothetical dialogue 1]. Or [hypothetical dialogue 2].
gram.function: 为了说明他们“只谈论必要的事情”，叙述者没有进行抽象的描述，而是创造了两个非常具体、 mundane（平淡的）的对话场景。这种通过虚构的典型对话来举例的方式，比简单的陈述更能生动地传达出他们当前关系的冷淡和纯功能性。

example.en: We never have real conversations anymore. It's always just, 'Did you pay the bill?' or 'We need milk.'
example.cn: 我们再也没有真正的交谈了。总是只有‘你付账单了吗？’或者‘我们需要牛奶了’。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过具体例子来阐明抽象观点的有效技巧。

paras.en: Why this is good is because I get to hang out with a lot more kids now. Before, when I was hanging out with August all the time, kids weren't hanging out with me because they'd have to hang out with him. Or they would keep things from me, like the whole thing about the Plague. I think I was the only one who wasn't in on it, except for Summer and maybe the D&D crowd. And the truth is, though nobody's that obvious about it: nobody wants to hang out with him. Everyone's way too hung up on being in the popular group, and he's just as far from the popular group as you can get.
paras.cn: 这样做的好处是，我现在可以和更多的孩子一起玩了。以前，当我一直和奥古斯特一起玩的时候，孩子们不和我玩，因为那样他们就得和他一起玩。或者他们会对我隐瞒一些事情，比如关于“瘟疫”的整件事。我想我是唯一一个不知情的人，除了萨默和可能玩《龙与地下城》的那群人。而事实是，尽管没人表现得那么明显：没人想和他一起玩。每个人都太过执着于进入受欢迎的团体，而他离受欢迎的团体要多远有多远。

vocab.ex: It's not good to keep things from your parents.
Everyone knew about the surprise party; I was the only one not in on it.
The D&D crowd usually meets in the library during lunch.
It was obvious that he was not happy with the decision.
She's still hung up on her ex-boyfriend and can't move on.

vocab.word: as far from... as you can get
vocab.ph: /æz fɑːr frəm... æz juː kæn ɡet/
vocab.mean: 离…要多远有多远（表示极端相反）
vocab.ex: His quiet personality is as far from his brother's loud behavior as you can get.

gram.name: 强调句型 (Why... is because...)
gram.pattern: Why + [statement] + is because + [reason].
gram.function: 一种用于解释原因的强调结构。通过将“原因”（'because...'）作为整个句子的核心，它比简单的 'This is good because...' 语气更强，更具分析性。叙述者用它来对自己目前处境的“好处”进行理性的辩解。

example.en: Why I'm late is because the traffic was terrible.
example.cn: 我迟到的原因是因为交通太糟糕了。

gram.constraints: 是一种较为复杂的、用于强调原因的结构。

paras.en: But now I can hang out with anyone I want. If I wanted to be in the popular group, I could totally be in the popular group. Why this is bad is because, well, (a) I don't actually enjoy hanging out with the popular group that much. And (b) I actually liked hanging out with August. So this is kind of messed up. And it's all August's fault.
paras.cn: 但现在我想和谁玩就可以和谁玩。如果我想进入受欢迎的团体，我完全可以进入。这样做不好的地方是，嗯，(a) 我其实不那么享受和受欢迎的团体一起玩。以及 (b) 我其实挺喜欢和奥古斯特一起玩的。所以这事有点搞砸了。而且这全是奥古斯特的错。

vocab.ex: I like movies, but not that much that I'd go every week.
The whole situation is completely messed up.
Don't blame me; it's all your fault for being late.

gram.name: 括号式列举（用于论证）
gram.pattern: (a) [point 1]. And (b) [point 2].
gram.function: 使用 '(a)' 和 '(b)' 来组织和列举自己的论点，即使是在内心独白中。这种结构模仿了一种理性的、试图逻辑分析的思维过程，但其内容（'I don't enjoy...' 和 'I liked...'）却揭示了情感上的矛盾，最终导向一个非理性的结论。

example.en: I can't go for two reasons: (a) I have no money, and (b) I'm too tired.
example.cn: 我不能去有两个原因：(a) 我没钱，以及 (b) 我太累了。

gram.constraints: 是一种清晰地组织要点的方式。

paras.en: The first snow of winter hit right before Thanksgiving break. School was closed, so we got an extra day of vacation. I was glad about that because I was so bummed about this whole August thing and I just wanted some time to chill without having to see him every day. Also, waking up to a snow day is just about my favorite thing in the world. I love that feeling when you first open your eyes in the morning and you don't even know why everything seems different than usual. Then it hits you: Everything is quiet. No cars honking. No buses going down the street. Then you run over to the window, and outside everything is covered in white: the sidewalks, the trees, the cars on the street, your windowpanes. And when that happens on a school day and you find out your school is closed, well, I don't care how old I get: I'm always going to think that that's the best feeling in the world. And I'm never going to be one of those grown-ups that use an umbrella when it's snowing—ever.
paras.cn: 冬天的第一场雪在感恩节假期前夕来临。学校停课了，所以我们多了一天假。我对此很高兴，因为我为整个奥古斯特的事情感到非常沮D. I just wanted some time to chill without having to see him every day. Also, waking up to a snow day is just about my favorite thing in the world. I love that feeling when you first open your eyes in the morning and you don't even know why everything seems different than usual. Then it hits you: Everything is quiet. No cars honking. No buses going down the street. Then you run over to the window, and outside everything is covered in white: the sidewalks, the trees, the cars on the street, your windowpanes. And when that happens on a school day and you find out your school is closed, well, I don't care how old I get: I'm always going to think that that's the best feeling in the world. And I'm never going to be one of those grown-ups that use an umbrella when it's snowing—ever.

vocab.ex: He was really bummed when he found out the concert was cancelled.
After a long week of exams, I just want to chill on the sofa.

vocab.mean: （因下雪学校或公司关闭的）雪天假日
vocab.ex: The kids were excited when they heard it was a snow day.
I was walking home, and then it hits you: I had forgotten my keys.
The driver behind me started to honk his horn.
Raindrops were trickling down the windowpane.

gram.name: 将来时（用于表达身份认同）
gram.pattern: I'm always going to... / I'm never going to...
gram.function: 使用 'be going to' 不仅可以表示计划，还可以用来宣告一个关于自己未来身份或行为的坚定信念。'I'm always going to think...' 和 'I'm never going to be...' 表达了叙述者对自我核心价值观的一种永久性承诺，定义了他想成为（或不想成为）什么样的人。

example.en: No matter what happens, I'm always going to be your friend.
example.cn: 无论发生什么，我永远都会是你的朋友。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常强烈的、表达个人信念的句式。

paras.en: Dad's school was closed, too, so he took me and Jamie sledding down Skeleton Hill in the park. They say a little kid broke his neck while sledding down that hill a few years ago, but I don't know if this is actually true or just one of those legends. On the way home, I spotted this banged-up wooden sled kind of propped up against the Old Indian Rock monument. Dad said to leave it, it was just garbage, but something told me it would make the greatest sled ever. So Dad let me drag it home, and I spent the rest of the day fixing it up. I super-glued the broken slats together and wrapped some heavy-duty white duct tape around them for extra strength. Then I spray painted the whole thing white with the paint I had gotten for the Alabaster Sphinx I was making for the Egyptian Museum project. When it was all dry, I painted LIGHTNING in gold letters on the middle piece of wood, and I made a little lightning-bolt symbol above the letters. It looked pretty professional, I have to say.
paras.cn: 爸爸的学校也停课了，所以他带我和杰米去公园的骷髅山滑雪橇。他们说几年前有个小孩在那座山上滑雪橇时摔断了脖子，但我不知道这是不是真的，或者只是那些传说之一。在回家的路上，我发现一个破旧的木制雪橇，有点像是靠在古印第安岩石纪念碑上。爸爸说别管它，那只是垃圾，但有种感觉告诉我它会成为有史以来最棒的雪橇。所以爸爸让我把它拖回了家，我花了剩下的一天时间来修理它。我用强力胶把断裂的板条粘在一起，然后在上面缠了一些重型白色管道胶带来增加强度。然后我用我为埃及博物馆项目制作雪花石膏斯芬克斯时买的油漆，把整个东西喷成了白色。等全干了以后，我在中间那块木头上用金色字母画上了“闪电”，还在字母上方画了一个小小的闪电符号。我得说，它看起来相当专业。

vocab.ex: After the big snowstorm, the children went sledding in the park.
According to local legend, a ghost haunts the old castle.
He bought a banged-up old car and spent the summer fixing it.
An old bicycle was propped up against the wall.
He was too tired to lift his suitcase, so he had to drag it behind him.
They bought an old house and spent years fixing it up.
One of the wooden slats on the fence was broken.
You'll need some heavy-duty boots for this hiking trail.
He temporarily fixed the broken pipe with duct tape.
A bright lightning-bolt lit up the night sky.
Although he's just an amateur photographer, his work looks very professional.

gram.name: Something told me... (表达直觉)
gram.pattern: Something told me + that + clause.
gram.function: 一种拟人化的、非常地道的表达方式，用于描述一种强烈的直觉或预感，意为“有种感觉告诉我…”。它将一种内在的、难以言喻的感觉人格化，使其成为一个外部的“声音”或“信息来源”。

example.en: I was about to leave, but something told me to wait a few more minutes.
example.cn: 我正要离开，但有种感觉告诉我再多等几分钟。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、描述直觉的口语化表达。

paras.en: The next day, we went back to Skeleton Hill with Lightning. It was the fastest thing I've ever ridden—so, so, so much faster than the plastic sleds we'd been using. And because it had gotten warmer outside, the snow had become crunchier and wetter: good packing snow. Me and Jamie took turns on Lightning all afternoon. We were in the park until our fingers were frozen and our lips had turned a little blue. Dad practically had to drag us home.
paras.cn: 第二天，我们带着“闪电”回到了骷髅山。这是我骑过的最快的东西——比我们之前用的塑料雪橇快得太太太多了。而且因为外面变暖和了，雪变得更脆、更湿：是适合堆雪的好雪。我和杰米整个下午都在轮流玩“闪电”。我们在公园里待到手指冻僵，嘴唇都变得有点发青。爸爸几乎是把我们拖回家的。

vocab.ex: Have you ever ridden a horse before?
I love the taste of fresh, crunchy apples.
After the storm, the ground was covered in good packing snow for building a snowman.
The siblings take turns washing the dishes.
My hands were frozen after playing outside in the snow.
I've been working on this all day; I'm practically finished.

gram.name: 重复 'so' 以示强调
gram.pattern: so, so, so much + comparative
gram.function: 通过重复副词 'so'，叙述者极大地加强了比较级的语气，生动地传达了新雪橇速度之快带给他的强烈感受。这是一种模仿儿童说话时天真而夸张语气的有效方式。

example.en: I am so, so tired after that long hike.
example.cn: 那次长途跋涉之后，我真是太累太累了。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常口语化和非正式的强调方式。

paras.en: By the end of the weekend, the snow had started turning gray and yellow, and then a rainstorm turned most of the snow to slush. When we got back to school on Monday, there was no snow left.
paras.cn: 到周末结束时，雪开始变灰变黄，然后一场暴雨把大部分雪变成了雪泥。周一我们回到学校时，一点雪都没剩了。

vocab.ex: By the end of the movie, half the audience had left.
We were caught in a heavy rainstorm on our way home.
The streets were filled with dirty gray slush after the snow started to melt.
I'm sorry, there's no cake left.

gram.name: 使用时间标记的叙事顺序
gram.pattern: Time marker 1 + event, and then + event 2. Time marker 2 + event 3.
gram.function: 通过使用清晰的时间标记（'By the end of the weekend', 'and then', 'When we got back to school on Monday'），作者按时间顺序清晰地叙述了一系列事件，有效地描绘了雪从纯白到融化消失的全过程，象征着假期的结束。

example.en: First, we went to the museum. Then, we had lunch. After that, we went shopping.
example.cn: 首先，我们去了博物馆。然后，我们吃了午饭。那之后，我们去购物了。

gram.constraints: 是构建清晰叙事流的基本技巧。

paras.en: It was rainy and yucky the first day back from vacation. A slushy day. That's how I was feeling inside, too. I nodded "hey" to August the first time I saw him. We were in front of the lockers. He nodded "hey" back. I wanted to tell him about Lightning, but I didn't.
paras.cn: 假期回来的第一天阴雨绵绵，令人讨厌。一个泥泞的日子。我内心的感觉也是这样。我第一次见到奥古斯特时，对他点了点头说了声“嘿”。我们在储物柜前。他也点头回了声“嘿”。我想告诉他关于“闪电”的事，但我没有。

vocab.ex: I don't want to eat this; it looks yucky.
The sidewalks were wet and slushy after the snow melted.
We didn't have time to talk, so we just nodded 'hey' as we passed.

gram.name: 内在感受的隐喻
gram.pattern: [External description]. That's how I was feeling inside.
gram.function: 通过将外部的天气状况（'A slushy day'）直接等同于自己的内心感受，作者创造了一个强有力的隐喻。这种内外景的统一，生动地传达了叙述者在假期结束后重返学校时的那种混乱、不洁和沮丧的情绪。

example.en: It was a dark and stormy night. That's how I felt inside, too.
example.cn: 那是一个风雨交加的黑夜。我内心的感觉也是如此。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过外部环境来反映内心世界的经典文学技巧。

paras.en: Mr. Browne's December precept was: Fortune favors the bold. We were all supposed to write a paragraph about some time in our lives when we did something very brave and how, because of it, something good happened to us.
paras.cn: 布朗先生十二月份的信条是：天佑勇者。我们都被要求写一段话，关于我们生命中某个我们做了非常勇敢的事情的时刻，以及因此，有什么好事发生在我们身上。

vocab.ex: One of his guiding precepts was to always be honest.

vocab.mean: 天佑勇者；幸运眷顾勇敢的人
vocab.ex: She was nervous about starting her own business, but she remembered the saying, 'fortune favors the bold.'
You were supposed to finish your homework before watching TV.
It was brave of him to admit his mistake.

gram.name: 谚语作为陈述
gram.pattern: A well-known saying presented as a direct statement.
gram.function: 使用谚语或格言作为核心主题，可以为叙述或讨论提供一个文化上公认的框架。'Fortune favors the bold' 不仅是一个句子，更是一个浓缩了智慧的文化符号，为接下来的写作任务设定了明确的主题。

example.en: His motto was simple: actions speak louder than words.
example.cn: 他的座右铭很简单：行动胜于雄辩。

gram.constraints: 其有效性依赖于读者对该谚语的文化理解。

paras.en: I thought about this a lot, to be truthful. I have to say that I think the bravest thing I ever did was become friends with August. But I couldn't write about that, of course. I was afraid we'd have to read these out loud, or Mr. Browne would put them up on the bulletin board like he does sometimes. So, instead, I wrote this lame thing about how I used to be afraid of the ocean when I was little. It was dumb but I couldn't think of anything else.
paras.cn: 说实话，我对此想了很多。我得说，我认为我做过的最勇敢的事就是和奥古斯特成为朋友。但当然，我不能写这个。我怕我们得大声朗读这些，或者布朗先生会像他有时做的那样，把它们贴在布告板上。所以，我反而写了一件很蹩脚的事，关于我小时候如何害怕大海。那很傻，但我想不出别的了。

vocab.ex: To be truthful, I didn't really enjoy the movie.
Firefighters are some of the bravest people in our community.
The teacher asked the student to read the poem out loud to the class.
Check the bulletin board for the latest announcements.
He gave a lame excuse for being late that nobody believed.
That was a dumb mistake to make.

gram.name: 内心想法与外在行为的对比
gram.pattern: [True feeling/thought]... But I couldn't [act on it]... So, instead, I [did something else].
gram.function: 通过一个清晰的对比和替代结构，叙述者揭示了她内心真实的想法（'the bravest thing... was become friends with August'）和她最终的外在行为（'I wrote this lame thing...'）之间的巨大差异。这种结构深刻地展现了由于社交恐惧（害怕被公开）而导致的自我审查，是一种非常真实的青少年心理写照。

example.en: I wanted to tell him the truth, but I couldn't bring myself to do it. So, instead, I just smiled and nodded.
example.cn: 我想告诉他真相，但我没法强迫自己那么做。所以，我反而只是笑了笑，点了点头。

gram.constraints: 是一种展示内心挣扎和最终妥协的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: I wonder what August wrote about. He probably had a lot of things to choose from.
paras.cn: 我想知道奥古斯特写了什么。他大概有很多事情可以选择。

vocab.ex: I wonder what time the movie starts tonight.
There are so many options on the menu, it's hard to choose from them all.

gram.name: 含蓄的结论性思考
gram.pattern: A simple statement with deep, unstated implications.
gram.function: 在描述了自己难以找到“勇敢”事迹可写之后，以一个关于奥古斯特的、看似简单的推测结尾。'He probably had a lot of things to choose from' 这句话充满了深刻的、未言明的潜台词。它通过一种含蓄的方式，承认了奥古斯特的生活充满了需要勇气的挑战，这既是对他朋友的敬佩，也是对自己“正常”生活的反思，为章节画上了一个充满同理心和深度的句号。

example.en: She complained about her small apartment. He, who had grown up homeless, said nothing.
example.cn: 她抱怨她的小公寓。而他，一个从小无家可归的人，什么也没说。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过“少即是多”的原则来传达强烈情感和复杂思想的文学技巧。

paras.en: My parents are not rich. I say this because people sometimes think that everyone who goes to private school is rich, but that isn't true with us. Dad's a teacher and Mom's a social worker, which means they don't have those kinds of jobs where people make gazillions of dollars. We used to have a car, but we sold it when Jamie started kindergarten at Beecher Prep. We don't live in a big townhouse or in one of those doorman buildings along the park. We live on the top floor of a five-story walk-up we rent from an old lady named Doña Petra all the way on the "other" side of Broadway. That's "code" for the section of North River Heights where people don't want to park their cars. Me and Jamie share a room. I overhear my parents talk about things like "Can we do without an air conditioner one more year?" or "Maybe I can work two jobs this summer."
paras.cn: 我父母不富裕。我这么说是因为人们有时认为所有上私立学校的人都很有钱，但我们家不是这样。爸爸是老师，妈妈是社会工作者，这意味着他们的工作不是那种能赚大钱的。我们以前有辆车，但在杰米开始上比彻预备学校的幼儿园时卖掉了。我们不住在大联排别墅里，也不住那些公园旁有门卫的大楼里。我们住在百老汇“另一边”尽头一栋五层无电梯公寓的顶层，房子是从一位叫多娜·佩特拉的老太太那里租的。那是北河高地区人们不想停车那片的“代号”。我和杰米共用一个房间。我无意中听到我父母谈论诸如“我们能再一年不用空调吗？”或“也许我这个夏天可以打两份工。”之类的事情。

vocab.ex: The tuition for that private school is very expensive.
A social worker helps families and individuals cope with problems in their everyday lives.
He's a tech billionaire who made gazillions of dollars.
Living in a doorman building in New York City is a sign of luxury.
They found an affordable apartment in a five-story walk-up.
Since the coffee machine is broken, we'll have to do without coffee this morning.

gram.name: 引号（用于表示“暗语”或特殊含义）
gram.function: 将一个普通的词（'other' 和 'code'）放在引号里，可以赋予它一层特殊的、弦外之音的含义。'"other" side' 暗示这是一个社会经济地位较低、不受欢迎的区域。'"code"' 则明确指出前一个词是一种委婉的说法或暗语。

example.en: He told me he was feeling "tired," but I knew he meant he was sad.
example.cn: 他告诉我他感觉“累了”，但我知道他的意思是伤心。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过标点来传达潜台词的 subtle（微妙的）修辞手法。

paras.en: So today at recess I was hanging out with Julian and Henry and Miles. Julian, who everyone knows is rich, was like, "I hate that I have to go back to Paris this Christmas. It's so boring!" "Dude, but it's, like, Paris," I said like an idiot. "Believe me, it's so boring," he said. "My grandmother lives in this house in the middle of nowhere. It's like an hour away from Paris in this tiny, tiny, tiny village. I swear to God, nothing happens there! I mean, it's like, oh wow, there's another fly on the wall! Look, there's a new dog sleeping on the sidewalk. Yippee."
paras.cn: 所以今天课间休息时，我正和朱利安、亨利和迈尔斯一起玩。朱利安，大家都知道他很有钱，当时就说：“我讨厌我今年圣诞节还得回巴黎。太无聊了！” “老兄，但那可是，比如，巴黎啊，” 我像个白痴一样说。“相信我，无聊透了，” 他说。“我祖母住在一个鸟不拉屎的地方的房子里。那地方离巴黎大概一小时车程，在一个非常非常非常小的村庄里。我向上帝发誓，那里什么事都不会发生！我的意思是，就好像，哦哇，墙上又多了只苍蝇！看，人行道上睡了条新狗。好耶。”

vocab.ex: The children played soccer during recess.
I felt like an idiot when I realized I had been pushing a door that said 'pull'.

vocab.mean: 在鸟不拉屎的地方；偏僻处
vocab.ex: Their car broke down in the middle of nowhere with no cell service.
The model ship was decorated with tiny flags.

vocab.mean: 我向上帝发誓（用于极度强调）
vocab.ex: I swear to God, I had no idea this was going to happen.
More homework on a Friday? Yippee.

gram.name: 反讽性轻描淡写与夸张
gram.pattern: Using mundane examples to illustrate extreme boredom.
gram.function: 朱利安通过列举极其平淡无奇的事件（'another fly on the wall', 'a new dog sleeping'）并配上一个表示兴奋的感叹词 'Yippee'，来反讽地强调那个地方的极度无聊。这种将小事夸大为“大事件”的手法，是一种有效的幽默和反讽技巧，生动地传达了他的不满。

example.en: What did I do all weekend? Oh, you know, the usual excitement. I watched some paint dry. Thrilling.
example.cn: 我整个周末做了什么？哦，你知道的，老一套的刺激活动。我看了一些油漆变干。太刺激了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来产生幽默或讽刺效果的修辞手法。

paras.en: "Though my parents are talking about throwing a big party this year instead of going to Paris. I hope so. What are you doing over break?" said Julian. "Just hanging out," I said. "You're so lucky," he said. "I hope it snows again," I answered. "I got this new sled that is so amazing." I was about to tell them about Lightning but Miles started talking first. "I got a new sled, too!" he said. "My dad got it from Hammacher Schlemmer. It's so state of the art." "How could a sled be state of the art?" said Julian.
paras.cn: “不过我父母在商量今年办个大派对，而不是去巴黎。我希望如此。你假期做什么？” 朱利安说。“就待着玩玩，” 我说。“你真幸运，” 他说。“我希望再下雪，” 我回答。“我弄到了一个超棒的新雪橇。” 我正要告诉他们关于“闪电”的事，但迈尔斯先开口了。“我也弄到了一个新雪橇！” 他说。“我爸爸从 Hammacher Schlemmer 买的。它非常先进。” “一个雪橇怎么能是先进的？” 朱利安说。

vocab.ex: They're going to throw a party for her birthday.
What are your plans over the holiday break?
The children used a plastic sled to slide down the snowy hill.
The hospital is equipped with state-of-the-art medical technology.

gram.name: 社会阶层的并置
gram.pattern: Contrast between a homemade object and a luxury brand item.
gram.function: 通过将杰克自己修理的、充满个人情感的雪橇“闪电”（读者已知）与迈尔斯从昂贵品牌 Hammacher Schlemmer 购买的“最先进的”雪橇并置，作者巧妙地揭示了孩子们之间存在的社会阶层差异。这种对比为后续的情节发展（关于旧雪橇的真相）埋下了伏笔。

example.en: She treasured her handmade doll, while her friend showed off her expensive new tablet.
example.cn: 她珍爱着她手工制作的娃娃，而她的朋友则炫耀着她昂贵的新平板电脑。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过物品来暗示人物背景和差异的文学技巧。

paras.en: "It was like eight hundred dollars or something." "Whoa!" "We should all go sledding and have a race down Skeleton Hill," I said. "That hill is so lame," answered Julian. "Are you kidding?" I said. "Some kid broke his neck there. That's why it's called Skeleton Hill." Julian narrowed his eyes and looked at me like I was the biggest moron in the world. "It's called Skeleton Hill because it was an ancient Indian burial ground, duh," he said.
paras.cn: “它大概要八百美元左右。” “哇！” “我们应该都去滑雪橇，在骷髅山下来一场比赛，” 我说。“那座山太逊了，” 朱利安回答。“你在开玩笑吗？” 我说。“有个孩子在那里摔断了脖子。所以它才叫骷髅山。” 朱利安眯起眼睛看着我，好像我是世界上最大的白痴。“它叫骷髅山是因为它曾是一个古老的印第安人墓地，咄，” 他说。

vocab.ex: After the big snowstorm, the children went sledding in the park.
That's a lame excuse for not doing your homework.

vocab.mean: 你在开玩笑吗？（表示不相信）
vocab.ex: You're quitting your job? Are you kidding me?

vocab.mean: 眯起眼睛（表示怀疑或不悦）
vocab.ex: She narrowed her eyes at him, trying to tell if he was lying.
He felt like a moron after making such a simple mistake.
The ancient burial ground was considered a sacred site.

vocab.mean: （非正式，表示某事显而易见）咄；废话
vocab.ex: A: Is the sky blue? B: Well, duh.

gram.name: 居高临下的语气
gram.pattern: Using dismissive language and nonverbal cues to assert superiority.
gram.function: 朱利安通过一系列行为和语言来建立自己的优越感。他的非语言线索（'narrowed his eyes'）、侮辱性比喻（'like I was the biggest moron'）以及表示对方无知的感叹词（'duh'），都共同构成了一种居高临下的、轻蔑的语气，旨在贬低对方并确立自己在团体中的主导地位。

example.en: He explained the simple concept slowly, as if talking to a child.
example.cn: 他慢慢地解释那个简单的概念，就好像在对一个孩子说话一样。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过贬低他人来抬高自己的社交策略。

paras.en: "Anyway, it should be called Garbage Hill now, it's so freakin' junky. Last time I was there it was so gross, like with soda cans and broken bottles and stuff." He shook his head. "I left my old sled there," said Miles. "It was the crappiest piece of junk—and someone took it, too!" "Maybe a hobo wanted to go sledding!" laughed Julian.
paras.cn: “不管怎样，它现在应该叫垃圾山了，它太他妈的破烂了。我上次去的时候那里太恶心了，到处是汽水罐、碎瓶子之类的东西。” 他摇了摇头。“我把我旧的雪橇留在了那里，” 迈尔斯说。“那是个最烂的破烂货——而且还有人把它拿走了！” “也许是个流浪汉想去滑雪橇！” 朱利安大笑道。

vocab.ex: This is a freakin' amazing concert!
He needs to clean out his garage; it's full of junky old furniture.
There was a dead spider on the wall, it was so gross.
This is the crappiest movie I have ever seen.
My old car is a real piece of junk; it breaks down all the time.
The old story was about a kind hobo who traveled the country by train.

gram.name: 戏剧性反讽
gram.pattern: The audience knows something the characters do not.
gram.function: 当迈尔斯和朱利安嘲笑那个“破烂货”雪橇和拿走它的“流浪汉”时，读者已经知道拿走并修复了那个雪橇的人正是杰克。这种信息的不对称创造了强烈的戏剧性反讽。角色们的无心之言，在读者听来却成了对杰克及其家庭状况的直接侮辱，极大地增强了情节的张力和情感冲击力。

example.en: In the play, we know Juliet is only sleeping, but Romeo thinks she is dead.
example.cn: 在剧中，我们知道朱丽叶只是睡着了，但罗密欧却以为她死了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过信息不对称来产生强烈情感效果的文学技巧。

paras.en: "Here's what we can do," said Julian. "Next time it snows, my dad could drive us all up to this golf course in Westchester that makes Skeleton Hill look like nothing. Hey, Jack, where are you going?" I had started to walk away. "I've got to get a book out of my locker," I lied. I just wanted to get away from them fast. I didn't want anyone to know that I was the "hobo" who had taken the sled.
paras.cn: “我们可以这样做，” 朱利安说。“下次下雪，我爸爸可以开车带我们都去威斯特彻斯特的一个高尔夫球场，那里让骷髅山看起来不值一提。嘿，杰克，你去哪儿？” 我已经开始走开了。“我得去储物柜拿本书，” 我撒了谎。我只是想快点离开他们。我不想让任何人知道我就是那个拿了雪橇的“流浪汉”。

vocab.ex: He spends his weekends playing golf on the local golf course.
His new sports car makes my old car look like nothing.
After the argument, he just turned and walked away.
He had to lie to his parents about where he had been.
I need to get away from the city for a few days.

gram.name: 用负面词语进行自我认同
gram.pattern: Identifying oneself with a pejorative term used by others.
gram.function: 当杰克在内心独白中将自己定义为那个“'hobo' who had taken the sled”时，他内化了朋友们无意中施加于他的侮辱。这种自我认同揭示了社会阶层差异给他带来的深刻的羞耻感和被排斥感。引号的使用表明他是在引用别人的话，突显了他与那个词语之间的痛苦联系。

example.en: They called him a 'nerd,' and for a long time, he believed he was just that: a 'nerd.'
example.cn: 他们叫他“书呆子”，很长一段时间里，他也相信自己就是那样：一个“书呆子”。

gram.constraints: 是一种深刻揭示人物内心伤害和自我认知的文学技巧。

paras.en: I'm not the greatest student in the world. I know some kids actually like school, but I honestly can't say I do. I like some parts of school, like PE and computer class. And lunch and recess. But all in all, I'd be fine without school. And the thing I hate the most about school is all the homework we get. It's not enough that we have to sit through class after class and try to stay awake while they fill our heads with all this stuff we will probably never need to know, like how to figure out the surface area of a cube or what the difference is between kinetic and potential energy. I'm like, who cares? I've never, ever heard my parents say the word "kinetic" in my entire life!
paras.cn: 我不是世界上最棒的学生。我知道有些孩子确实喜欢学校，但我真的不能说我喜欢。我喜欢学校的某些部分，比如体育课和电脑课。还有午餐和课间休息。但总的来说，没有学校我也能过得很好。而我最讨厌学校的一点就是我们所有的作业。我们不得不在一节又一节的课上坐着，努力保持清醒，而他们则用所有这些我们可能永远都不需要知道的东西填满我们的脑袋，这还不够，比如如何计算一个立方体的表面积，或者动能和势能之间有什么区别。我就想，谁在乎啊？我这辈子从来、从来没听我父母说过“动能”这个词！

vocab.ex: There were a few minor issues, but all in all, the event was a great success.

vocab.mean: 耐着性子坐到（会议、表演等）结束
vocab.ex: I had to sit through a long and boring lecture.
Don't fill your head with such negative thoughts.
It took me a while to figure out the solution to the puzzle.
He said he doesn't like my new shirt, but who cares?

gram.name: 抱怨的修辞结构
gram.pattern: It's not enough that [grievance A], [there's also grievance B].
gram.function: 一种用于层层递进地表达不满的结构。通过先说“A还不够”，然后引出更令人烦恼的B，来强调问题的严重性。'It's not enough that we have to sit through class... while they fill our heads with... stuff...' 强烈地表达了叙述者对学校学习内容的双重不满：既无聊又无用。

example.en: It's not enough that the flight was delayed; they also lost my luggage.
example.cn: 航班延误还不够，他们还把我的行李弄丢了。

gram.constraints: 是一种有效的、加强抱怨语气的修辞手法。

paras.en: I hate science the most out of all my classes. We get so much work it's not even funny! And the teacher, Ms. Rubin, is so strict about everything—even the way we write our headings on the top of our papers! I once got two points off a homework assignment because I didn't put the date on top. Crazy stuff.
paras.cn: 在我所有的课中，我最讨厌科学。我们的作业多到一点都不好笑！而且老师鲁宾女士对所有事情都那么严格——甚至包括我们在试卷顶部写标题的方式！有一次我因为没在上面写日期，一项家庭作业被扣了两分。真是疯狂。

vocab.ex: Of all my hobbies, I like reading the most.

vocab.mean: 一点都不好笑（表示情况很严重或令人恼火）
vocab.ex: He failed the test so badly it's not even funny.
The coach is very strict about punctuality.
Please write your name in the heading of the paper.
I got points off my essay for spelling mistakes.
You won't believe the crazy stuff that happened at the party.

gram.name: 破折号（用于强调）
gram.pattern: Statement — [emphasized example].
gram.function: 用于引出一个具体的例子来强调前面的陈述。'...so strict about everything—even the way we write our headings...' 中，破折号后面的例子有力地证明了老师“对所有事情都严格”的程度。

example.en: He loves all kinds of animals—even snakes and spiders.
example.cn: 他喜欢各种动物——甚至包括蛇和蜘蛛。

gram.constraints: 破折号比逗号或括号更具强调意味。

paras.en: When me and August were still friends, I was doing okay in science because August sat next to me and always let me copy his notes. August has the neatest handwriting of anybody I've ever seen who's a boy. Even his script is neat: up and down perfectly, with really small round loopy letters. But now that we're ex-friends, it's bad because I can't ask him to let me copy his notes anymore.
paras.cn: 当我和奥古斯特还是朋友的时候，我的科学成绩还行，因为奥古斯特坐我旁边，而且总是让我抄他的笔记。奥古斯特有我见过的所有男孩中最整洁的字迹。甚至他的手写体也很整洁：完美地上下对齐，字母是小小的、圆圆的、带圈的。但既然我们现在是前朋友了，情况就糟了，因为我不能再让他让我抄他的笔记了。

vocab.ex: I didn't win the race, but I think I did okay.
She keeps her room very neat and tidy.
Her elegant script was beautiful to look at.
She practiced writing the loopy letters of the alphabet in cursive.
After their big fight, they became ex-friends.

gram.name: 对比时间框架（友谊）
gram.pattern: When [past situation], [past result]. But now that [present situation], [present result].
gram.function: 通过使用清晰的时间框架对比（'When me and August were still friends...' vs. 'But now that we're ex-friends...'），叙述者清楚地展示了友谊状态的变化如何直接影响到他的学业表现，强调了失去这段友谊带来的实际后果。

example.en: When I had a car, I could go anywhere. But now that it's broken, I have to take the bus.
example.cn: 当我还有车的时候，我能去任何地方。但既然它坏了，我就得坐公交车了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比过去和现在来解释情况变化的有效结构。

paras.en: So I was kind of scrambling today, trying to take notes about what Ms. Rubin was saying (my handwriting is awful), when all of a sudden she started talking about the fifth-grade science-fair project, how we all had to choose a science project to work on. While she was saying this, I was thinking, We just finished the freakin' Egypt project, now we have to start a whole new thing? And then in my head I was going, Oh noooooo! like that kid in Home Alone with his mouth hanging open and his hands on his face. That was the face I was making on the inside. And then I thought of those pictures of melting ghost faces I've seen somewhere, where the mouths are open wide and they're screaming. And then all of a sudden this picture flew into my head, this memory, and I knew what Summer had meant by "bleeding scream." It's so weird how it all just came to me in this flash. Someone in homeroom had dressed up in a Bleeding Scream costume on Halloween. I remember seeing him a few desks away from me. And then I remember not seeing him again.
paras.cn: 所以今天我有点手忙脚乱，努力地记下鲁宾女士在说什么（我的字迹很糟糕），就在那时，她突然开始谈论五年级的科学展览项目，说我们都必须选择一个科学项目来做。她说这话的时候，我在想，我们刚做完那个该死的埃及项目，现在又得开始一个全新的东西？然后我脑子里就在想，哦不————！就像《小鬼当家》里那个嘴巴张着、双手捂脸的孩子一样。那是我内心正在做的表情。然后我想到了我在哪里见过的那些融化的鬼脸图片，它们的嘴巴张得大大的，在尖叫。然后突然之间，这张画面飞入我的脑海，这段记忆，我知道了萨默说的“流血鬼脸”是什么意思了。这一切就这么一瞬间涌上心头，真是太奇怪了。万圣节那天，班级教室里有人穿了流血鬼脸的戏服。我记得看到他坐在离我几个座位远的地方。然后我记得就再没见过他了。

vocab.ex: He was scrambling to finish his report before the deadline.
She won first prize at the school's annual science fair.
This is a freakin' amazing concert!

vocab.mean: （非正式，用于描述发出的声音或内心的想法）想；说
vocab.ex: The cat saw the dog and went, 'Hiss!'
He might look calm, but on the inside, he's very nervous.
The perfect idea for her story suddenly flew into her head.
The solution to the problem came to him in a flash.

gram.name: 流行文化典故
gram.pattern: Reference to a well-known movie, character, or image.
gram.function: 通过引用广为人知的电影《小鬼当家》中的经典画面，作者用一个简洁、生动的文化符号来传达角色内心的极度震惊和绝望感。这种典故能够快速地在读者和角色之间建立情感共鸣。

example.en: He faced the challenge with the courage of a Jedi Knight.
example.cn: 他以绝地武士般的勇气面对挑战。

gram.constraints: 其效果依赖于读者对所引用文化符号的熟悉程度。

paras.en: Oh man. It was August! All of this hit me in science class while the teacher was talking. Oh man. I'd been talking to Julian about August. Oh man. Now I understood! I was so mean. I don't even know why. I'm not even sure what I said, but it was bad. It was only a minute or two. It's just that I knew Julian and everybody thought I was so weird for hanging out with August all the time, and I felt stupid. And I don't know why I said that stuff. I just was going along. I was stupid. I am stupid. Oh God. He was supposed to come as Boba Fett! I would never have said that stuff in front of Boba Fett. But that was him, that Bleeding Scream sitting at the desk looking over at us. The long white mask with the fake squirting blood. The mouth open wide. Like the ghoul was crying. That was him.
paras.cn: 哦天哪。是奥古斯特！所有这一切都在科学课上老师说话的时候冲击着我。哦天哪。我曾和朱利安谈论过奥古斯特。哦天哪。现在我明白了！我太刻薄了。我甚至不知道为什么。我甚至不确定我说了什么，但那很糟糕。也就一两分钟的事。只是我知道朱利安和所有人都觉得我一直和奥古斯特一起玩很奇怪，我觉得自己很傻。我不知道我为什么说那些话。我只是在附和。我当时很蠢。我现在也很蠢。哦上帝。他本该扮成波巴·费特的！我绝不会在波巴·费特面前说那些话。但那就是他，那个坐在课桌旁看着我们的流血鬼脸。长长的白色面具，带着假的喷射血液。嘴巴张得大大的。就像那个食尸鬼在哭泣。那就是他。

vocab.ex: Oh man, I completely forgot about our meeting!

vocab.mean: （想法）突然冲击某人；使某人突然意识到
vocab.ex: Then the truth hit me: he had been lying all along.
It was mean of him to say such hurtful things.
He didn't agree with the plan, but he decided to go along with it to avoid an argument.
You were supposed to be here an hour ago!
The child laughed as the squirting flower sprayed water in his face.
The horror story was about a ghoul that haunted the graveyard.

gram.name: 意识流（用于表现顿悟）
gram.pattern: A series of short, fragmented, and repetitive sentences mimicking the flow of thought.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列短句、片段、重复（'Oh man'）、自我否定（'I don't even know...'）和自我谴责（'I was stupid. I am stupid.'），作者模拟了角色在顿悟和悔恨瞬间的混乱思绪。这种意识流的写法让读者直接体验到角色的震惊、内疚和思维的快速跳跃，极具情感冲击力。

example.en: The key. Of course. Why didn't I think of it? So simple. It was in my pocket the whole time. How could I be so blind?
example.cn: 钥匙。当然了。我怎么就没想到呢？那么简单。它一直就在我口袋里。我怎么能这么瞎？

gram.constraints: 是一种高级的文学技巧，用于展现角色的内在心理活动。

paras.en: I felt like I was going to puke.
paras.cn: 我感觉我就要吐了。

vocab.ex: After eating too much cake, I feel like I'm going to be sick.
The boat's rocking motion made him feel like he was going to puke.

gram.name: 生理性反应的结论句
gram.pattern: A short, final sentence describing a strong physical sensation.
gram.function: 在一段充满强烈情感和心理冲击的叙述之后，以一个描述剧烈生理反应的短句结尾，可以将抽象的内疚和悔恨转化为一种具体的、读者可以感同身受的感觉。'I felt like I was going to puke' 将角色的心理痛苦具象化，为整个顿悟过程画上了一个极其有力的、令人不适的句号。

example.en: He read the rejection letter, and his stomach dropped.
example.cn: 他读着拒信，心往下一沉。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过生理感受来传达强烈情感的有效技巧。

paras.en: I didn't hear a word of what Ms. Rubin was saying after that. Blah blah blah. Science-fair project. Blah blah blah. Partners. Blah blah. It was like the way grown-ups talk in Charlie Brown movies. Like someone talking underwater. Mwah-mwah-mwahhh, mwah mwahh.
paras.cn: 那之后鲁宾女士在说什么，我一个字也没听进去。吧啦吧啦吧啦。科学展览项目。吧啦吧啦吧啦。搭档。吧啦吧啦。就像《查理·布朗》电影里大人说话的方式。就像有人在水下说话。哇-哇-哇——，哇哇。

vocab.mean: （非正式）诸如此类，等等（表示内容无聊或重复）
vocab.ex: He went on and on about his car, blah blah blah, and I just tuned him out.

vocab.mean: 查理·布朗（《花生漫画》主角，其动画中大人说话声音模糊不清）
vocab.ex: The teacher's lecture sounded like the adults in a Charlie Brown special.
It's difficult to hear clearly when you are underwater.

vocab.mean: （拟声词）哇哇声（模仿模糊不清的说话声）
vocab.ex: I couldn't understand the announcement over the loudspeaker; it was just 'mwah-mwah-mwahhh'.

gram.name: 拟声词与明喻（用于表现脱离感）
gram.pattern: A series of auditory images to represent mental state.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列听觉意象，如填充词 'Blah blah blah'、流行文化典故（'Charlie Brown movies'）、明喻（'Like someone talking underwater'）和拟声词（'Mwah-mwah-mwahhh'），作者有力地传达了叙述者因内心震惊而与外部世界听觉脱节的状态。所有声音都变得模糊、无意义。

example.en: After the bad news, all I could hear was a buzzing sound in my ears.
example.cn: 听到那个坏消息后，我耳朵里能听到的只有嗡嗡声。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过感官描述来表现人物心理状态的文学技巧。

paras.en: Then all of a sudden Ms. Rubin started pointing to kids around the class. "Reid and Tristan, Maya and Max, Charlotte and Ximena, August and Jack." She pointed to us when she said this. "Miles and Amos, Julian and Henry, Savanna and . . ." I didn't hear the rest.
paras.cn: 然后突然之间，鲁宾女士开始指着教室里的孩子们。“里德和特里斯坦，玛雅和马克斯，夏洛特和西梅纳，奥古斯特和杰克。” 她说这话时指向了我们。“迈尔斯和阿莫斯，朱利安和亨利，萨凡纳和……” 后面的我没听见。

vocab.ex: We were walking in the park when all of a sudden it started to rain.
The guide will point to the historical landmarks on our tour.
I ate some of the pizza and saved the rest for later.

gram.name: 列举配对（用于分配任务）
gram.pattern: [Name] and [Name], [Name] and [Name]...
gram.function: 通过快速地、不间断地列举出一系列配对的名字，作者营造了一种紧张感，模仿了现实中宣布名单时的情景。这种结构将读者的注意力引向了最后一个被念出的、也是最重要的配对：“August and Jack”。

example.en: The teams are: Team A and Team C, Team B and Team D.
example.cn: 队伍分别是：A队和C队，B队和D队。

gram.constraints: 是一种高效的信息传达方式。

paras.en: "Huh?" I said. The bell rang. "So don't forget to get together with your partners to choose a project from the list, guys!" said Ms. Rubin as everyone started taking off. I looked up at August, but he had already put his backpack on and was practically out the door.
paras.cn: “嗯？” 我说。铃响了。“那么别忘了和你们的搭档聚一聚，从列表里选一个项目，伙计们！” 鲁宾女士说，这时大家已经开始离开了。我抬头看向奥古斯特，但他已经背上背包，几乎已经走出门口了。

vocab.ex: Huh? What did you just say?
Let's get together with some friends this weekend.
As soon as the meeting was over, he took off.
I've been working on this all day; I'm practically finished.

gram.name: 对比反应（静止 vs. 行动）
gram.pattern: Character A's delayed reaction vs. Character B's swift action.
gram.function: 通过将杰克的困惑和静止（'Huh?', 'I looked up'）与奥古斯特迅速的、逃避式的行动（'had already put his backpack on and was practically out the door'）进行对比，作者突显了两人在听到配对消息后截然不同的心理状态和应对方式。

example.en: When the fire alarm rang, he froze, but she was already running for the exit.
example.cn: 火警响起时，他呆住了，但她已经朝出口跑去了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行为来揭示人物内心的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: I must have had a stupid look on my face because Julian came over and said: "Looks like you and your best bud are partners." He was smirking when he said this. I hated him so much right then. "Hello, earth to Jack Will?" he said when I didn't answer him. "Shut up, Julian." I was putting my loose-leaf binder away in my backpack and just wanted him away from me.
paras.cn: 我脸上肯定是一副蠢样，因为朱利安走过来说：“看来你和你最好的哥们成搭档了。” 他说这话时在窃笑。那一刻我恨死他了。“喂，呼叫杰克·威尔？” 当我没回答他时，他说。“闭嘴，朱利安。” 我正在把我的活页夹放进背包里，只想让他离我远点。

vocab.ex: He had a stupid look on his face after hearing the confusing instructions.
He's going to the movies with his best bud tonight.
He couldn't help but smirk when he saw that his rival had made a mistake.

vocab.mean: 呼叫[某人]（用于唤醒走神的人）
vocab.ex: Hello, earth to Mark? Are you listening to me?
His parents told him to shut up, but he kept talking.
She organized her notes for each class in a different loose-leaf binder.

gram.name: must have (用于对过去的推断)
gram.pattern: must have + past participle
gram.function: 用于对过去发生的事情进行非常肯定的推测或推断。'I must have had a stupid look...' 是叙述者根据朱利安的反应，对自己当时表情的一个强烈推测。

example.en: You look exhausted. You must have worked late last night.
example.cn: 你看起来筋疲力尽。你昨晚肯定工作到很晚。

gram.constraints: 只用于对过去事件的推测。

paras.en: "You must be so bummed you got stuck with him," he said. "You should tell Ms. Rubin you want to switch partners. I bet she'd let you." "No she wouldn't," I said. "Ask her." "No, I don't want to."
paras.cn: “你肯定很郁闷被分到和他一组，” 他说。“你应该告诉鲁宾女士你想换搭档。我打赌她会让你换的。” “不她不会的，” 我说。“问她啊。” “不，我不想。”

vocab.ex: He was really bummed when he found out the concert was cancelled.
At the group project, I got stuck with the laziest person in the class.
Would you like to switch seats with me?
I bet it's going to rain later.

gram.name: 断奏式对话（用于冲突）
gram.pattern: A series of very short, one- or two-word lines.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列极短的、包含指令和拒绝的对话（'Ask her.' 'No, I don't want to.'），作者创造了一种快速、紧张的节奏，生动地表现了朱利安的施压和杰克的坚决抵抗，突显了两人之间的冲突。

example.en: A: Go. B: No. A: Please? B: Never.
example.cn: A：去。B：不去。A：求你了？B：绝不。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对话的节奏来传达潜台词和情感张力的有效技巧。

paras.en: "Ms. Rubin?" Julian said, turning around and raising his hand at the same time. Ms. Rubin was erasing the chalkboard at the front of the room. She turned when she heard her name. "No, Julian!" I whisper-screamed. "What is it, boys?" she said impatiently. "Could we switch partners if we wanted to?" said Julian, looking very innocent. "Me and Jack had this science-fair project idea we wanted to work on together. . . ." "Well, I guess we could arrange that . . . ," she started to say. "No, it's okay, Ms. Rubin," I said quickly, heading out the door. "Bye!"
paras.cn: “鲁宾女士？” 朱利安说，同时转过身并举起了手。鲁宾女士正在教室前面擦黑板。她听到自己的名字时转过身来。“不，朱利安！” 我低声尖叫道。“什么事，孩子们？” 她不耐烦地说。“如果我们想，可以换搭档吗？” 朱利安说，看起来非常无辜。“我和杰克有个科学展览项目的想法想一起做……” “嗯，我猜我们可以安排……” 她开始说。“不，没关系的，鲁宾女士，” 我迅速说，朝门口走去。“再见！”

vocab.ex: Please erase the board after class.
She let out a little whisper-scream when she saw the spider, trying not to wake anyone.
He tapped his foot impatiently while waiting in line.
He had an innocent look on his face, but I knew he was up to something.
Can we arrange a meeting for next week?
It's getting late, I think we should head out.

gram.name: 创造性复合动词（矛盾修饰法）
gram.pattern: Verb + Verb
gram.function: 通过将两个矛盾的动作（'whisper' 和 'scream'）组合成一个新词 'whisper-screamed'，作者创造了一个强有力的意象，描绘了一个人试图同时保持安静和发出紧急警告的状态。它完美地捕捉了杰克当时的恐慌和绝望。

example.en: He laugh-cried when he heard the bittersweet news.
