example.cn: 听到那个苦乐参半的消息时，他哭笑不得。

gram.constraints: 是一种文学性的、非标准的构词法，用于表达复杂的情感。

paras.en: Julian ran after me. "Why'd you do that?" he said, catching up to me at the stairs. "We could have been partners. You don't have to be friends with that freak if you don't want to be, you know. . . ." And that's when I punched him. Right in the mouth.
paras.cn: 朱利安追着我跑。“你为什么那么做？” 他在楼梯口追上我说。“我们本可以成为搭档的。你不必和那个怪物做朋友，如果你不想的话，你知道的……” 就在那时，我打了他。正中嘴巴。

vocab.mean: （Why did you的口语缩略形式）你为什么…
vocab.ex: Why'd you leave the party so early?
You walk too fast; I can't catch up to you.
We could have been great friends if we had met under different circumstances.
The bullies called him a freak just because he dressed differently.
In a fit of anger, he punched the wall.

gram.name: 突兀的结论性动作
gram.pattern: A final, short sentence describing a sudden, violent action.
gram.function: 在一段充满语言挑衅和内心挣扎的叙述之后，章节以一个极其简短、有力的句子描述一个身体动作来结尾。'And that's when I punched him.' 和补充的片段 'Right in the mouth.' 创造了一个突然的、戏剧性的高潮。它用行动替代了语言，作为对朱利安侮辱性言语的最终回应，给读者留下了强烈的冲击感和悬念。

example.en: He kept talking and talking. And then she slapped him. Right across the face.
example.cn: 他不停地说着说那。然后她打了他一巴掌。正中脸颊。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行动来制造高潮和结束场景的经典叙事技巧。

paras.en: Some things you just can't explain. You don't even try. You don't know where to start. All your sentences would jumble up like a giant knot if you opened your mouth. Any words you used would come out wrong.
paras.cn: 有些事你就是没法解释。你甚至都不去尝试。你不知道从何说起。如果你张开嘴，你所有的句子都会像一个巨大的结一样缠绕在一起。你用的任何词语都会表达错意。

vocab.ex: Can you explain the rules of the game to me?
The threads got jumbled up in the sewing machine.
He tied a tight knot in the rope.
I tried to compliment her, but my words came out wrong and she was offended.

gram.name: 简短陈述句（用于表达无法言说）
gram.pattern: A series of short, simple, second-person sentences.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列简短、直接的第二人称陈述句，作者创造了一种普遍化的、感同身受的氛围，描绘了那种因情绪激动或情况复杂而无法言说的状态。这种手法让读者直接代入角色，感受其内心的混乱。

example.en: You can't move. You can't speak. You can't even think.
example.cn: 你动弹不得。你说不出话。你甚至无法思考。

gram.constraints: 其力量来自于句子的简洁和重复性。

paras.en: "Jack, this is very, very serious," Mr. Tushman was saying. I was in his office, sitting on a chair across from his desk and looking at this picture of a pumpkin on the wall behind him. "Kids get expelled for this kind of thing, Jack! I know you're a good kid and I don't want that to happen, but you have to explain yourself." "This is so not like you, Jack," said Mom. She had come from work as soon as they had called her. I could tell she was going back and forth between being really mad and really surprised.
paras.cn: “杰克，这非常、非常严重，” 塔什曼先生正在说。我在他的办公室里，坐在他书桌对面的椅子上，看着他身后墙上那幅南瓜的画。“孩子们会因为这种事被开除的，杰克！我知道你是个好孩子，我不想那样的事发生，但你必须为自己解释。” “这太不像你了，杰克，” 妈妈说。他们一给她打电话，她就从公司赶来了。我看得出她正在非常生气和非常惊讶两种情绪之间摇摆。

vocab.ex: This is a serious matter that requires our immediate attention.
He was expelled from school for cheating on the final exam.
You were an hour late; you need to explain yourself.
You're usually so cheerful. Being this quiet is not like you.
I'm going back and forth between choosing the red car and the blue one.

gram.name: 描述情感波动 (go back and forth between...)
gram.pattern: be going back and forth between [emotion A] and [emotion B]
gram.function: 通过使用这个习语，作者生动地描绘了一个人内心在两种强烈且矛盾的情感之间挣扎的状态。'going back and forth between being really mad and really surprised' 精确地捕捉了母亲当时复杂的心情。

example.en: She was going back and forth between feeling excited and terrified about her new job.
example.cn: 对于新工作，她时而感到兴奋，时而感到恐惧。

gram.constraints: 是一种形象地描述内心矛盾的表达方式。

paras.en: "I thought you and Julian were friends," said Mr. Tushman. "We're not friends," I said. My arms were crossed in front of me. "But to punch someone in the mouth, Jack?" said Mom, raising her voice. "I mean, what were you thinking?" She looked at Mr. Tushman. "Honestly, he's never hit anyone before. He's just not like that." "Julian's mouth was bleeding, Jack," said Mr. Tushman. "You knocked out a tooth, did you know that?" "It was just a baby tooth," I said. "Jack!" said Mom, shaking her head. "That's what Nurse Molly said!" "You're missing the point!" Mom yelled.
paras.cn: “我以为你和朱利安是朋友，” 塔什曼先生说。“我们不是朋友，” 我说。我双臂交叉在胸前。“但是打了别人的嘴，杰克？” 妈妈提高了声音说。“我的意思是，你在想什么？” 她看着塔什曼先生。“说真的，他以前从没打过人。他不是那样的。” “朱利安的嘴流血了，杰克，” 塔什曼先生说。“你打掉了一颗牙，你知道吗？” “只是一颗乳牙，” 我说。“杰克！” 妈妈摇着头说。“莫莉护士就是这么说的！” “你没抓住重点！” 妈妈喊道。

vocab.ex: He got into a fight and was punched in the mouth.
There's no need to raise your voice; I can hear you perfectly.
The impact of the fall was strong enough to knock out a tooth.
Children usually start losing their baby teeth around age six.
You're focusing on the small details and completely missing the point of the argument.

gram.name: 肢体语言作为角色线索
gram.pattern: A description of a character's physical posture.
gram.function: 通过描述角色的肢体语言 'My arms were crossed in front of me'，作者无需直接说明，就有效地传达了角色的防御、固执和不愿合作的态度。这是一种“展示而非告知”（Show, don't tell）的叙事技巧。

example.en: He tapped his fingers on the table, showing his impatience.
example.cn: 他在桌上敲着手指，显示出他的不耐烦。

gram.constraints: 肢体语言是揭示人物内心状态的有力工具。

paras.en: "I just want to know why," said Mr. Tushman, raising his shoulders. "It'll just make everything worse," I sighed. "Just tell me, Jack." I shrugged but I didn't say anything. I just couldn't. If I told him that Julian had called August a freak, then he'd go talk to Julian about it, then Julian would tell him how I had badmouthed August, too, and everybody would find out about it.
paras.cn: “我只是想知道为什么，” 塔什曼先生耸着肩说。“那只会让一切变得更糟，” 我叹了口气。“告诉我吧，杰克。” 我耸了耸肩，但什么也没说。我就是不能说。如果我告诉他朱利安叫奥古斯特怪物，那他就会去找朱利安谈这件事，然后朱利安就会告诉他我也说了奥古斯特的坏话，然后所有人就都会知道了。

vocab.mean: 耸肩（常表示无奈或不解）
vocab.ex: He raised his shoulders in a gesture of confusion.
She sighed with relief when the difficult task was finally over.
When I asked him where the money was, he just shrugged.
It's unprofessional to bad-mouth your colleagues.

gram.name: 揭示困境的内心独白
gram.pattern: A chain of conditional reasoning explaining a character's inaction.
gram.function: 通过一段内心独白，角色清晰地阐述了他保持沉默背后的复杂逻辑链条。这个“如果我做A，那么就会发生B，接着就会发生C”的推理过程，向读者揭示了他所处的两难困境（dilemma）：揭露朱利安的同时也会暴露自己，最终伤害所有人。这深刻地解释了他为什么说“只会让一切变得更糟”。

example.en: I couldn't report the crime. If I did, the gang would find out, and then my family would be in danger.
example.cn: 我不能报案。如果我那么做，那个团伙会发现，然后我的家人就会有危险。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过展示角色思维过程来推动情节和塑造人物的有效技巧。

paras.en: "Jack!" said Mom. I started to cry. "I'm sorry . . ." Mr. Tushman raised his eyebrows and nodded, but he didn't say anything. Instead, he kind of blew into his hands, like you do when your hands are cold. "Jack," he said, "I don't really know what to say here. I mean, you punched a kid. We have rules about that kind of thing, you know? Automatic expulsion. And you're not even trying to explain yourself." I was crying a lot by now, and the second Mom put her arms around me, I started to bawl.
paras.cn: “杰克！” 妈妈说。我开始哭了。“对不起……” 塔什曼先生扬了扬眉毛，点了点头，但什么也没说。相反，他有点像往手上哈气，就像你手冷时做的那样。“杰克，” 他说，“我真的不知道该说什么了。我的意思是，你打了一个孩子。我们对那种事有规定，你知道吗？自动开除。而你甚至都不想为自己解释。” 我现在哭得很厉害，妈妈一把我搂进怀里，我就开始嚎啕大哭。

vocab.mean: 扬起眉毛（表示惊讶或怀疑）
vocab.ex: He raised his eyebrows when I told him the surprising news.
Forgetting your passport means automatic denial of entry.
Fighting in school can lead to immediate expulsion.
The baby started to bawl when he dropped his toy.

gram.name: the second (表示即时性)
gram.pattern: the second + clause
gram.function: 用作连词，意为“一…就…”，强调两个动作之间几乎没有时间间隔，后者是前者的直接、即时反应。'the second Mom put her arms around me, I started to bawl' 强调了母亲的拥抱是触发他情绪彻底崩溃的直接原因。

example.en: The second I walked in the door, the phone started ringing.
example.cn: 我一进门，电话就响了。

gram.constraints: 是一种比 'when' 语气更强的表达方式。

paras.en: "Let's, um . . . ," said Mr. Tushman, taking his glasses off to clean them, "let's do this, Jack. We're out for winter break as of next week anyway. How about you stay home for the rest of this week, and then after winter break you'll come back and everything will be fresh and brand new. Clean slate, so to speak." "Am I being suspended?" I sniffled. "Well," he said, shrugging, "technically yes, but it's only for a couple of days. And I'll tell you what. While you're at home, you take the time to think about what's happened. And if you want to write me a letter explaining what happened, and a letter to Julian apologizing, then we won't even put any of this in your permanent record, okay? You go home and talk about it with your mom and dad, and maybe in the morning you'll figure it all out a bit more."
paras.cn: “我们，嗯……” 塔什曼先生说，摘下眼镜擦拭着，“我们这样做吧，杰克。反正下周起我们就要放寒假了。这周剩下的时间你待在家里怎么样，然后寒假过后你回来，一切都会是崭新和全新的。可以说，一笔勾销。” “我是被停学了吗？” 我抽泣着问。“嗯，” 他耸着肩说，“严格来说是的，但只有几天。而且我跟你说。你在家的时候，花点时间想想发生了什么。如果你想给我写封信解释发生了什么，再给朱利安写封道歉信，那么我们甚至不会把这些记入你的永久档案，好吗？你回家和你的爸爸妈妈谈谈，也许到早上你会更想明白一点。”

vocab.ex: We're going skiing over winter break.
As of today, the new rules are in effect.
After moving to a new city, she was happy to have a clean slate.
He was suspended from school for three days for fighting.
She started to sniffle during the sad part of the movie.
Technically, a tomato is a fruit, not a vegetable.
Getting expelled from school will go on your permanent record.

gram.name: 外交语言与框架效应
gram.pattern: Using softeners ('Well'), qualifiers ('technically'), and reframing a negative as an opportunity.
gram.function: 塔什曼先生通过一系列语言技巧来处理这个棘手的情况。他用 'Well' 和 'technically' 来软化“停学”这个惩罚，并立即将其重新定义（frame）为一个“花时间思考”和“写信”的机会，从而将一个负面的后果转化为一个具有教育意义和可以补救的过程。这展现了他高超的管理和沟通技巧。

example.en: You didn't get the promotion. But think of it as an opportunity to gain more experience in your current role.
example.cn: 你没有得到晋升。但把它看作是在你当前职位上获得更多经验的机会吧。

gram.constraints: 是一种在管理和教育中常见的、将负面情况积极化的沟通策略。

paras.en: "That sounds like a good plan, Mr. Tushman," said Mom, nodding. "Thank you." "Everything is going to be okay," said Mr. Tushman, walking over to the door, which was closed. "I know you're a nice kid, Jack. And I know that sometimes even nice kids do dumb things, right?" He opened the door. "Thank you for being so understanding," said Mom, shaking his hand at the door. "No problem." He leaned over and told her something quietly that I couldn't hear. "I know, thank you," said Mom, nodding.
paras.cn: “这听起来是个好计划，塔什曼先生，” 妈妈点着头说。“谢谢您。” “一切都会好起来的，” 塔什曼先生说，走向那扇关着的门。“我知道你是个好孩子，杰克。而且我知道有时候即使是好孩子也会做傻事，对吧？” 他打开了门。“谢谢您的理解，” 妈妈在门口和他握手时说。“没问题。” 他俯身过去，悄悄地对她说了些我听不见的话。“我知道，谢谢您，” 妈妈点着头说。

vocab.mean: 听起来像个好计划（表示同意）
vocab.ex: A: Let's go to the movies tonight. B: Sounds like a good plan!
That was a dumb mistake to make.
Thank you for being so understanding about my situation.

gram.name: 通过普遍化进行温和安抚
gram.pattern: Affirmation + generalized truth.
gram.function: 塔什曼先生没有直接评判杰克的行为，而是采用了一种“肯定-普遍化”的安抚策略。他首先肯定了杰克的本性（'I know you're a nice kid'），然后将他的错误行为归入一个普遍的人类经验中（'sometimes even nice kids do dumb things'）。这种方式既没有否认错误的严重性，又将杰克从一个孤立的“坏孩子”身份中解放出来，体现了极高的教育智慧和同理心。

example.en: You're a good student. And sometimes even good students fail a test. It's okay.
example.cn: 你是个好学生。而有时即使是好学生也会考试不及格。没关系的。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常有效的、在不纵容错误的情况下给予安慰和鼓励的沟通技巧。

paras.en: "So, kiddo," he said to me, putting his hands on my shoulders. "Think about what you've done, okay? And have a great holiday. Happy Chanukah! Merry Christmas! Happy Kwanzaa!" I wiped my nose with my sleeve and started walking out the door. "Say thank you to Mr. Tushman," said Mom, tapping my shoulder. I stopped and turned around, but I couldn't look at him. "Thank you, Mr. Tushman," I said. "Bye, Jack," he answered. Then I walked out the door.
paras.cn: “那么，孩子，” 他对我说，把手放在我的肩膀上。“想想你都做了什么，好吗？祝你假期愉快。光明节快乐！圣诞快乐！宽扎节快乐！” 我用袖子擦了擦鼻子，开始朝门外走。“跟塔什曼先生说谢谢，” 妈妈拍着我的肩膀说。我停下来，转过身，但我无法看着他。“谢谢您，塔什曼先生，” 我说。“再见，杰克，” 他回答。然后我走出了门。

vocab.ex: "Time for bed, kiddo," said the father.
Where are you going for the winter holiday?
They light the menorah every night during Chanukah.

vocab.mean: 宽扎节（非裔美国人的文化节日）
vocab.ex: Kwanzaa is a celebration of African-American heritage.
Please wipe your feet before you come inside.
He rolled up his sleeves and started to work.

gram.name: 包容性列举
gram.pattern: A list of items from different groups/cultures.
gram.function: 通过列举来自不同文化和宗教传统的节日祝福（犹太教的光明节、基督教的圣诞节、非裔美国人的宽扎节），角色展现了他的包容性、善意和对多元文化的尊重。这个小小的细节进一步塑造了他作为一个充满智慧和同理心的教育者的形象。

example.en: Our potluck dinner included dishes from all over the world: Italian pasta, Mexican tacos, and Chinese dumplings.
example.cn: 我们的百乐餐晚宴包含了来自世界各地的菜肴：意大利面、墨西哥玉米饼和中式饺子。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过语言来体现包容性和文化意识的方式。

paras.en: Weirdly enough, when we got back home and Mom brought in the mail, there were holiday cards from both Julian's family and August's family. Julian's holiday card was a picture of Julian wearing a tie, looking like he was about to go to the opera or something. August's holiday card was of a cute old dog wearing reindeer antlers, a red nose, and red booties. There was a cartoon bubble above the dog's head that read: "Ho-Ho-Ho!" On the inside of the card it read: To the Will family, Peace on Earth. Love, Nate, Isabel, Olivia, August (and Daisy)
paras.cn: 说也奇怪，当我们回到家，妈妈拿进邮件时，里面有朱利安家和奥古斯特家两家的节日贺卡。朱利安的节日贺卡是朱利安打着领带的照片，看起来像要去歌剧院之类的。奥古斯特的节日贺卡是一只可爱的老狗，戴着驯鹿角、一个红鼻子和红色的小靴子。狗的头顶上有一个卡通对话框，上面写着：“嗬-嗬-嗬！” 卡片里面写着：致威尔一家，世界和平。爱你们的，内特、伊莎贝尔、奥利维亚、奥古斯特（还有黛西）

vocab.ex: I was just thinking about him, and weirdly enough, he called me a minute later.
We send out holiday cards to our family and friends every December.
She has a beautiful voice and dreams of singing in an opera.
For the Christmas party, he wore a silly headband with reindeer antlers.
We bought tiny little booties for the new puppy to protect its paws from the cold.
The artist drew a cartoon bubble above the character's head to show what he was thinking.
The holiday message was a simple wish for 'Peace on Earth'.

gram.name: 并置手法（用于塑造人物）
gram.pattern: Description of [item A] contrasted with description of [item B].
gram.function: 通过将朱利安家的贺卡（正式、以个人为中心）与奥古斯特家的贺卡（幽默、温暖、以家庭和宠物为中心）并置，作者无需直接评论，就巧妙地揭示了两个家庭截然不同的价值观和性格。这种对比为读者提供了关于角色背景和本质的深刻线索。

example.en: His room was perfectly organized, every book in its place. Her room, in contrast, was a beautiful chaos of art supplies and unfinished projects.
example.cn: 他的房间井井有条，每本书都在其位。相比之下，她的房间则是艺术用品和未完成项目的“美丽混沌”。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来塑造人物和主题的有效文学技巧。

paras.en: "Cute card, huh?" I said to Mom, who had hardly said a word to me all the way home. I think she honestly just didn't know what to say. "That must be their dog," I said. She took the card from my hands and looked at the picture carefully. Then she raised her eyebrows and her shoulders and gave me back the card. "We're very lucky, Jack. There's so much we take for granted. . . ." "I know," I said. I knew what she was talking about without her having to say it.
paras.cn: “很可爱的卡片，是吧？” 我对妈妈说，她回家的路上几乎没和我说过一句话。我想她真的只是不知道该说什么。“那一定是他们的狗，” 我说。她从我手中拿过卡片，仔细地看着照片。然后她扬了扬眉毛和肩膀，把卡片还给了我。“我们很幸运，杰克。有太多东西我们都认为是理所当然的……” “我知道，” 我说。我不用她说出来就知道她在说什么。

vocab.ex: Look at that little kitten playing with the yarn; it's so cute!
It was so foggy, I could hardly see the road.

vocab.mean: 扬起眉毛（表示惊讶或怀疑）
vocab.ex: He raised his eyebrows when I told him the surprising news.
I feel so lucky to have such wonderful friends.
We should never take our health for granted.

gram.name: 未说出口的理解
gram.pattern: A character understands another's meaning without explicit explanation.
gram.function: 通过 'I knew what she was talking about without her having to say it' 这句话，作者展现了母子之间深刻的情感联系和默契。妈妈的话语（'We're very lucky'）是含蓄的，但杰克立刻就理解了其中的潜台词——与奥古斯特的家庭相比，他们所拥有的“正常”是一种幸运。这是一种比直接对话更能体现人物关系深度的叙事技巧。

example.en: He just gave me a look, and I knew exactly what he meant.
example.cn: 他只是看了我一眼，我就完全明白了他的意思。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过展示默契来深化人物关系的有效方式。

paras.en: "I heard that Julian's mom actually Photoshopped August's face out of the class picture when she got it. She gave a copy to a couple of the other moms." "That's just awful," said Mom. "People are just . . . they're not always so great." "I know." "Is that why you hit Julian?" "No." And then I told her why I punched Julian. And I told her that August was my ex-friend now. And I told her about Halloween.
paras.cn: “我听说朱利安的妈妈拿到班级合影后，真的用Photoshop把奥古斯特的脸P掉了。她还给了其他几个妈妈一份副本。” “那真是太糟了，” 妈妈说。“人们就是……他们不总是那么好。” “我知道。” “那就是你打朱利安的原因吗？” “不。” 然后我告诉了她我为什么打了朱利安。而且我告诉她奥古斯特现在是我的前朋友了。而且我告诉了她关于万圣节的事。

vocab.ex: He asked the photographer to Photoshop out the stranger in the background of his picture.
Please make a copy of this document for me.
That was an awful thing to say to someone.
We had a big argument, and now he's my ex-friend.

gram.name: 首语重复法（用于高潮式坦白）
gram.pattern: Repetition of a phrase like 'And I told her...'
gram.function: 通过在连续的句子开头重复 'And I told her...'，作者创造了一种信息“倾泻而出”的感觉。这种排比结构模仿了当一个人终于决定坦白时，话语不受控制地涌出的状态，有力地表现了这是一个情感的决堤时刻，所有之前隐藏的秘密都被一次性揭示出来。

example.en: And he told them about his journey. And he told them about his struggles. And he told them about his final victory.
example.cn: 然后他告诉了他们他的旅程。然后他告诉了他们他的挣扎。然后他告诉了他们他最终的胜利。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过重复来营造高潮和情感释放的有效修辞手法。

paras.en:
December 18

Dear Mr. Tushman,

I am very, very sorry for punching Julian. It was very, very wrong for me to do that. I am writing a letter to him to tell him that, too. If it's okay, I would really rather not tell you why I did what I did because it doesn't really make it right anyway. Also, I would rather not make Julian get in trouble for having said something he should not have said.

Very sincerely,
Jack Will
paras.cn:
12月18日

亲爱的塔什曼先生：

我为打了朱利安感到非常、非常抱歉。我那么做是十分十分错误的。我也正在给他写信告诉他这一点。如果可以的话，我真的宁愿不告诉您我为什么那么做，因为它反正也无法让我的行为变得正确。而且，我宁愿不让朱利安因为说了他不该说的话而惹上麻烦。

您真诚的，
杰克·威尔

vocab.ex: He got into a fight and punched the other boy in the arm.
I would rather not discuss this topic right now.
I'm sorry I broke your vase; I'll buy you a new one to make it right.
He got in trouble at school for talking during class.
He ended the letter with the closing, 'Sincerely, John Smith.'

gram.name: 正式信件格式
gram.pattern: Date, Salutation, Body, Closing, Signature.
gram.function: 遵循了正式信件的基本格式，包括日期、称呼（'Dear Mr. Tushman,'）、正文、结束语（'Very sincerely,'）和签名。这表明了写信人对收信人的尊重以及对此事的严肃态度。

example.en: Dear Ms. Jones,... Sincerely, Student.
example.cn: 亲爱的琼斯女士……您真诚的，学生。

gram.constraints: 是进行正式书面沟通的标准方式。

paras.en:
December 18

Dear Julian,

I am very, very, very sorry for hitting you. It was wrong of me. I hope you are okay. I hope your grownup tooth grows in fast. Mine always do.

Sincerely,
Jack Will
paras.cn:
12月18日

亲爱的朱利安：

我为打了你感到非常、非常、非常抱歉。那是我的错。我希望你没事。我希望你的恒牙快点长出来。我的总是长得很快。

真诚的，
杰克·威尔

vocab.ex: It is never okay to hit another person.
It was wrong of me to say that, and I apologize.
After his baby tooth fell out, his grownup tooth started to come in.
His beard started to grow in when he was a teenager.

gram.name: 孩子气的道歉与安慰
gram.pattern: Formal apology + personal, somewhat naive reassurance.
gram.function: 这封信的结构展现了孩子气的真诚。它以一个非常正式且充满悔意的道歉开始，但结尾却转向了一个非常个人化、孩子气的安慰（'Mine always do.'）。这种从严肃到天真的转变，使得道歉显得非常真实，反映了写信人试图以自己能理解的方式来弥补和表达善意。

example.en: I'm sorry I broke your toy. I hope we can fix it. My dad is good at fixing things.
example.cn: 对不起我弄坏了你的玩具。我希望我们能修好它。我爸爸很擅长修东西。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过结合正式和非正式元素来表达真诚的方式。

paras.en:
December 26

Dear Jack,

Thank you so much for your letter. One thing I've learned after being a middle-school director for twenty years: there are almost always more than two sides to every story. Although I don't know the details, I have an inkling about what may have sparked the confrontation with Julian. While nothing justifies striking another student—ever —I also know good friends are sometimes worth defending. This has been a tough year for a lot of students, as the first year of middle school usually is.

Keep up the good work, and keep being the fine boy we all know you are.

All the best,
Lawrence Tushman
Middle-School Director
paras.cn:
12月26日

亲爱的杰克：

非常感谢你的来信。在担任中学校长二十年后我学到了一件事：每个故事几乎总是有不止两面。虽然我不知道细节，但我对可能引发与朱利安冲突的原因有点感觉。虽然没有任何事情可以为打另一个学生辩护——永远没有——但我也知道好朋友有时是值得捍卫的。对于很多学生来说，这是艰难的一年，中学的第一年通常都是如此。

继续好好表现，继续做我们都知道的那个好孩子。

一切顺利，
劳伦斯·塔什曼
中学校长

vocab.word: more than two sides to every story
vocab.ph: /mɔːr ðæn tuː saɪdz tuː ˈevri ˈstɔːri/
vocab.mean: 每个故事都有不止两面（意指事情很复杂）
vocab.ex: Before you judge, remember there are always more than two sides to every story.
I had an inkling that something was wrong.
His comment sparked a heated debate.
He tried to avoid a direct confrontation with his boss.
Nothing can justify such cruel behavior.
She will always defend her friends, no matter what.
Your project is looking great! Keep up the good work.

gram.name: 含蓄的认可与引导
gram.pattern: Acknowledge the rule, then offer a counterbalancing perspective.
gram.function: 塔什曼先生的信展现了高超的沟通技巧。他首先明确了规则（'nothing justifies striking...'），然后立刻通过一个转折（'I also know good friends are sometimes worth defending'）来含蓄地表达他对杰克动机的理解和某种程度的认可。这种“先规则后人情”的结构，既维护了校规的权威，又给予了学生情感上的支持和引导，体现了教育的智慧。

example.en: While lying is generally wrong, I also understand that sometimes a small lie can prevent a lot of hurt.
example.cn: 虽然撒谎通常是错的，但我也明白有时一个小谎言可以避免很大的伤害。

gram.constraints: 是一种在维护原则的同时表达同理心的有效沟通策略。

paras.en:
To: ltushman@beecherschool.edu
Cc: johnwill@phillipsacademy.edu; amandawill@ copperbeech.org
Fr: melissa.albans@rmail.com
Subject: Jack Will

Dear Mr. Tushman,

I spoke with Amanda and John Will yesterday, and they expressed their regret at Jack's having punched our son, Julian, in the mouth. I am writing to let you know that my husband and I support your decision to allow Jack to return to Beecher Prep after a two-day suspension. Although I think hitting a child would be valid grounds for expulsion in other schools, I agree such extreme measures aren't warranted here. We have known the Will family since our boys were in kindergarten, and are confident that every measure will be taken to ensure this doesn't happen again.

To that end, I wonder if Jack's unexpectedly violent behavior might have been a result of too much pressure being placed on his young shoulders? I am speaking specifically of the new child with special needs who both Jack and Julian were asked to "befriend." In retrospect, and having now seen the child in question at various school functions and in the class pictures, I think it may have been too much to ask of our children to be able to process all that. Certainly, when Julian mentioned he was having a hard time befriending the boy, we told him he was "off the hook" in that regard. We think the transition to middle school is hard enough without having to place greater burdens or hardships on these young, impressionable minds. I should also mention that, as a member of the school board, I was a little disturbed that more consideration was not given during this child's application process to the fact that Beecher Prep is not an inclusion school. There are many parents—myself included—who question the decision to let this child into our school at all. At the very least, I am somewhat troubled that this child was not held to the same stringent application standards (i.e. interview) that the rest of the incoming middle-school students were.

Best,
Melissa Perper Albans
paras.cn:
收件人: ltushman@beecherschool.edu
抄送: johnwill@phillipsacademy.edu; amandawill@copperbeech.org
发件人: melissa.albans@rmail.com
主题: 杰克·威尔

亲爱的塔什曼先生：

我昨天和阿曼达及约翰·威尔谈过了，他们对杰克打了我们儿子朱利安的嘴表示了歉意。我写信是为了告知您，我丈夫和我支持您在杰克停学两天后允许他返回比彻预备学校的决定。尽管我认为在其他学校，打孩子会是开除的充分理由，但我同意在这里没有必要采取如此极端的措施。我们自从我们的孩子们上幼儿园起就认识威尔一家，并相信将会采取一切措施确保此事不再发生。

为此，我想知道杰克意想不到的暴力行为是否可能是因为他年轻的肩膀上承担了太多的压力？我特指那个有特殊需求的新来的孩子，杰克和朱利安都被要求去“和他交朋友”。回想起来，并且现在在各种学校活动和班级照片中看到了这个孩子，我认为要求我们的孩子去处理所有这些可能太过分了。当然，当朱利安提到他很难和那个男孩交朋友时，我们告诉他在那方面他可以“不用管了”。我们认为，在这些年轻、易受影响的心灵上，不应再施加更大的负担或困难，中学过渡本身就已经够难了。我还应该提到，作为校董会的一员，我有点不安的是，在这个孩子的申请过程中，没有更多地考虑到比彻预备学校不是一所全纳学校这一事实。有很多家长——包括我自己——都质疑让这个孩子进入我们学校的决定。至少，我有点困扰的是，这个孩子没有被要求遵守与其他新入学的初中生相同的严格申请标准（即面试）。

祝好，
梅丽莎·佩珀·奥尔本斯

gram.name: 被动攻击性语言
gram.pattern: Using superficially polite language to express criticism or hostility.
gram.function: 朱利安的母亲在邮件中使用了大量看似礼貌、理性的语言（'I support your decision', 'I wonder if...', 'I think it may have been too much to ask'），但其真实意图是批评学校的决定，并将责任转移到奥古斯特身上。这种通过委婉语、含蓄指责和伪装关切来表达不满的方式，是典型的被动攻击性沟通。

example.en: 'It's just so interesting how some people choose to do things,' she said, clearly criticizing my method.
example.cn: “有些人做事的方式真是太有趣了，” 她说，显然是在批评我的方法。

gram.constraints: 是一种间接的、不坦诚的冲突方式。

paras.en:
To: melissa.albans@rmail.com
Fr: ltushman@beecherschool.edu
Cc: johnwill@phillipsacademy.edu; amandawill@ copperbeech.org
Subject: Jack Will

Dear Mrs. Albans,

Thanks for your email outlining your concerns. Were I not convinced that Jack Will is extremely sorry for his actions, and were I not confident that he would not repeat those actions, rest assured that I would not be allowing him back to Beecher Prep.

As for your other concerns regarding our new student August, please note that he does not have special needs. He is neither disabled, handicapped, nor developmentally delayed in any way, so there was no reason to assume anyone would take issue with his admittance to Beecher Prep—whether it is an inclusion school or not. In terms of the application process, the admissions director and I both felt it within our right to hold the interview off-site at August's home for reasons that are obvious. We felt that this slight break in protocol was warranted but in no way prejudicial—in one way or another—to the application review. August is an extremely good student, and has secured the friendship of some truly exceptional young people, including Jack Will.

At the beginning of the school year, when I enlisted certain children to be a "welcoming committee" to August, I did so as a way of easing his transition into a school environment. I did not think asking these children to be especially kind to a new student would place any extra "burdens or hardships" on them. In fact, I thought it would teach them a thing or two about empathy, and friendship, and loyalty.

As it turns out, Jack Will didn't need to learn any of these virtues—he already had them in abundance.

Thank you again for being in touch.

Sincerely,
Lawrence Tushman
paras.cn:
收件人: melissa.albans@rmail.com
发件人: ltushman@beecherschool.edu
抄送: johnwill@phillipsacademy.edu; amandawill@copperbeech.org
主题: 杰克·威尔

亲爱的奥尔本斯夫人：

感谢您概述您担忧的邮件。要不是我确信杰克·威尔对自己的行为极其抱歉，要不是我自信他不会重复那些行为，请放心，我是不会允许他返回比彻预备学校的。

至于您关于我们新生奥古斯特的其他担忧，请注意他没有特殊需求。他在任何方面都没有残疾、缺陷或发育迟缓，所以没有理由假设任何人会对他的入学提出异议——无论比彻预备学校是不是一所全纳学校。在申请流程方面，招生主任和我都觉得，出于显而易见的原因，我们在奥古斯特家进行非现场面试是我们的权利。我们觉得这次对流程的微小突破是必要的，但在任何方面都对申请审核没有任何偏见。奥古斯特是一名极其优秀的学生，并已获得了一些真正杰出的年轻人的友谊，包括杰克·威尔。

在学年开始时，当我招募某些孩子作为奥古斯特的“欢迎委员会”时，我这样做是为了缓解他向学校环境的过渡。我不认为要求这些孩子对一个新生特别友善会给他们带来任何额外的“负担或困难”。事实上，我认为这会教给他们一些关于同理心、友谊和忠诚的东西。

结果是，杰克·威尔不需要学习这些美德中的任何一种——他早已拥有丰富的这些品质。

再次感谢您的联系。

真诚的，
劳伦斯·塔什曼

gram.name: 倒装条件句（正式）
gram.pattern: Were + Subject + not...

example.en: Were it not for your help, I would have failed.

paras.en: Despite what Tushman said, there was no "clean slate" when I went back to school in January. In fact, things were totally weird from the second I got to my locker in the morning. I'm next to Amos, who's always been a pretty straight-up kid, and I was like, "Yo, what up?" and he basically just nodded a half hello and closed his locker door and left. I was like, okay, that was bizarre. And then I said: "Hey, what up?" to Henry, who didn't even bother half-smiling but just looked away. Okay, so something's up. Dissed by two people in less than five minutes. Not that anyone's counting. I thought I'd try one more time, with Tristan, and boom, same thing. He actually looked nervous, like he was afraid of talking to me.
paras.cn: 尽管塔什曼先生那么说，但一月份我回到学校时，并没有什么“全新的开始”。事实上，从我早上到储物柜的那一秒起，事情就完全不对劲了。我旁边是阿莫斯，他一直是个挺爽快的孩子，我当时就说：“哟，你好吗？” 他基本上只是半点了个头算是打了招呼，就关上储物柜门走了。我心想，好吧，这太古怪了。然后我对亨利说：“嘿，你好吗？”，他甚至都懒得半笑一下，只是移开了目光。好吧，所以是出事了。不到五分钟就被两个人鄙视了。倒也不是说有人在数。我想我再试一次，和特里斯坦，然后砰的一声，同样的事情。他看起来其实很紧张，好像怕和我说话似的。

vocab.ex: After moving to a new city, she was happy to have a clean slate.
His behavior was very weird today.
I appreciate his straight-up answer, even if it wasn't what I wanted to hear.
He told a bizarre story about a talking cat.
He's been quiet all day; I think something's up.
He felt hurt after his best friend dissed him in front of everyone.

vocab.mean: 倒也不是说有人在数（反讽）
vocab.ex: That's the third time you've been late this week, not that anyone's counting.

gram.name: 讽刺性旁白
gram.pattern: A parenthetical comment that means the opposite of what it says.
gram.function: 在陈述一个具体数字（'two people in less than five minutes'）后，加上一句 'Not that anyone's counting'，是一种反讽。叙述者通过假装不在乎（“没人会数”），实际上恰恰强调了他非常在乎，并且一直在数着自己被冷落的次数，以此来表达内心的受伤和无奈。

example.en: He ate the last cookie... not that I wanted it anyway.
example.cn: 他吃了最后一块饼干……倒也不是说我本来想吃。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过假装不在乎来强调在乎的修辞手法。

paras.en: I've got a form of the Plague now, is what I thought. This is Julian's payback. And that's pretty much how it went all morning. Nobody talked to me. Not true: the girls were totally normal with me. And August talked to me, of course. And, actually, I have to say both Maxes said hello, which made me feel kind of bad for never, ever hanging out with them in the five years I've been in their class.
paras.cn: 我现在也得了某种形式的“瘟疫”，我心想。这是朱利安的报复。整个上午差不多都是这样。没人跟我说话。也不全是：女孩们对我完全正常。当然，奥古斯特也跟我说话了。而且，实际上，我得说两个马克斯都跟我打了招呼，这让我为过去五年在他们班上却从来、从来没和他们一起玩过而感到有点内疚。

vocab.ex: The new student was afraid of getting 'the Plague' from the unpopular kids.
Losing the game was tough, but getting payback in the final match felt great.
I've pretty much finished all my work for the day.
Everyone hated the movie. Well, not true, my brother liked it.
I felt bad for yelling at him earlier.

gram.name: 叙事中的自我修正
gram.pattern: Absolute statement, followed by a correction ('Not true', 'Actually', etc.).
gram.function: 通过在一个绝对化的陈述（'Nobody talked to me'）之后，立刻用 'Not true:' 进行自我修正，并列举出例外情况，作者模仿了一种真实、诚实的思考过程。这使得叙述更加可信，并展示了角色在情绪化的概括之后，努力进行客观反思的内心活动。

example.en: I failed every test I took. Okay, not true, I did pass one.
example.cn: 我参加的每场考试都不及格。好吧，也不全是，我确实通过了一场。

gram.constraints: 是一种增加叙事真实感和层次感的技巧。

paras.en: I hoped lunch would be better, but it wasn't. I sat down at my usual table with Luca and Isaiah. I guess I thought since they weren't in the super-popular group but were kind of middle-of-the-road jock kids that I'd be safe with them. But they barely nodded when I said hello. Then, when our table was called, they got their lunches and never came back. I saw them find a table way over at the other end of the cafeteria. They weren't at Julian's table, but they were near him, like on the fringe of popularity. So anyway, I'd been ditched. I knew table switching was something that happened in the fifth grade, but I never thought it would happen to me.
paras.cn: 我希望午餐时间会好一些，但并没有。我和卢卡、以赛亚坐在我平常的桌子旁。我猜我以为既然他们不属于超级受欢迎的团体，只是那种中不溜丢的运动员型孩子，和他们在一起我会很安全。但当我说“你好”时，他们几乎没点头。然后，当叫到我们桌时，他们拿了午餐就再也没回来。我看到他们在餐厅很远的另一头找了张桌子。他们不在朱利安那桌，但在他附近，就像在受欢迎圈子的边缘。所以不管怎样，我被甩了。我知道换桌子是五年级会发生的事，但我从没想过会发生在我身上。

vocab.ex: He's not a radical thinker; his political views are very middle-of-the-road.
The stereotype is that jocks are not very interested in academics.
It was so foggy, I could barely see the road.

He lived on the fringe of society, never quite fitting in.
He decided to ditch his friends and go to the movies alone.

vocab.ex: Table switching is common in middle school as new friendships form.

gram.name: 社会地位的隐喻
gram.pattern: Using spatial terms ('fringe', 'center', 'top') to describe social standing.
gram.function: 通过使用空间术语，作者将抽象的“受欢迎程度”这一概念具体化、视觉化。'on the fringe of popularity' 生动地描绘了那些孩子所处的社交位置——渴望接近权力中心（朱利安的桌子），但又不够格进入，只能在边缘徘徊。

example.en: She was at the center of the school's social circle.
example.cn: 她是学校社交圈的中心人物。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过空间关系来解释抽象社会关系的有效手法。

gram.name: 社交焦虑的递进表达
gram.pattern: Statement of external perception -> Statement of internal emotional consequence.
gram.function: 作者通过一个清晰的递进结构来展现社交焦虑的心理过程。首先是外部感知（'I felt like everyone was watching me'），然后是这种感知所导致的直接的、内在的情感后果（'It also made me feel like I had no friends'）。这种因果链条让读者深刻地体验到角色的孤独和痛苦。

example.en: The whole room went silent when he walked in. It made him feel like an unwelcome outsider.
example.cn: 他走进来时，整个房间都安静了。这让他感觉自己像个不受欢迎的外人。

gram.constraints: 是一种展示心理因果关系的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: It was Charlotte who had the inside scoop on why everyone was dissing me. I found a note inside my locker at the end of the day. Meet me in room 301 right after school. Come by yourself! Charlotte. She was already inside the room when I walked in. "Sup," I said. "Hey," she said. She went over to the door, looked left and right, and then closed the door and locked it from the inside. Then she turned to face me and started biting her nail as she talked. "Look, I feel bad about what's going on and I just wanted to tell you what I know. Promise you won't tell anyone I talked to you?" "Promise."
paras.cn: 是夏洛特掌握了为什么大家都在鄙视我的内幕消息。一天结束时，我在储物柜里发现了一张纸条。“放学后马上到301室见我。自己来！夏洛特。” 我走进去时她已经在房间里了。“嘿，” 我说。“嗨，” 她说。她走到门口，左右看了看，然后关上门并从里面锁上了。接着她转过身来面对我，一边说话一边开始咬指甲。“听着，我对正在发生的事感到很难过，我只是想告诉你我知道的情况。保证你不会告诉任何人我和你谈过话？” “保证。”

vocab.ex: As a journalist, he always had the inside scoop on the latest political scandals.
He felt hurt after his best friend dissed him in front of everyone.
The invitation said to come by yourself, as it was a small gathering.
He walked by and gave a cool nod, saying, 'Sup?'
I still feel bad about what I said to her yesterday.

gram.name: 叙事张力构建
gram.pattern: A series of actions creating suspense.
gram.function: 通过一系列充满神秘感和紧张感的动作（发现纸条、秘密会面、左右查看、锁门、咬指甲），作者有效地为接下来的重要信息揭露构建了悬念和戏剧张力。这些行为暗示了即将要分享的信息是敏感且有风险的。

example.en: He lowered his voice, looked over his shoulder, and then leaned in to whisper the secret.
example.cn: 他压低了声音，回头看了看，然后凑上前去低声说出那个秘密。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过角色行为来营造氛围和悬念的经典叙事技巧。

paras.en: "So Julian had this huge holiday party over winter break," she said. "I mean, huge. My sister's friend had had her sweet sixteen at the same place last year. There were like two hundred people there, so I mean it's a huge place." "Yeah, and?" "Yeah, and . . . well, pretty much everybody in the whole grade was there." "Not everybody," I joked. "Right, not everybody. Duh. But like even parents were there, you know. Like my parents were there. You know Julian's mom is the vice president of the school board, right? So she knows a lot of people.
paras.cn: “所以朱利安在寒假期间办了个超大的节日派对，” 她说。“我是说，超大。我姐姐的朋友去年在同一个地方办了她的十六岁生日派对。那里大概有两百人，所以我的意思是那是个很大的地方。” “嗯，然后呢？” “嗯，然后……嗯，几乎整个年级的每个人都在那儿。” “不是每个人，” 我开玩笑说。“对，不是每个人。咄。但比如连家长都在那儿，你知道的。比如我父母就在。你知道朱利安的妈妈是校董会的副主席，对吧？所以她认识很多人。”

vocab.ex: She's planning a huge sweet sixteen party with all her friends.
I've pretty much finished all my work for the day.

vocab.mean: （非正式，表示某事显而易见）咄；废话
vocab.ex: A: Is the sky blue? B: Well, duh.
