gram.name: 重复以示强调
gram.pattern: Repeating a key word for emphasis.
gram.function: 通过重复形容词 'huge' 并用 'I mean' 来进一步加强，夏洛特生动地向杰克（和读者）传达了派对的规模之大，以此来铺垫这次派对作为信息传播中心的重要性。

example.en: It was cold that day. I mean, really, really cold.
example.cn: 那天很冷。我的意思是，真的非常非常冷。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的口语化强调方式。

paras.en: Anyway, so basically what happened at the party was that Julian went around telling everyone that you punched him because you had emotional problems. . . ." "What?!" "And that you would have gotten expelled, but his parents begged the school not to expel you . . ." "What?!" "And that none of it would have happened in the first place if Tushman hadn't forced you to be friends with Auggie. He said his mom thinks that you, quote unquote, snapped under the pressure. . . ."
paras.cn: 不管怎样，所以在派对上发生的事基本上是，朱利安到处告诉每个人，你打他是因为你有情绪问题……” “什么？！” “还有，你本会被开除的，但是他父母求学校不要开除你……” “什么？！” “而且如果不是塔什曼先生一开始就强迫你和奥吉做朋友，这一切根本就不会发生。他说他妈妈认为你，原话如此，在压力下崩溃了……”

vocab.ex: He's always going around telling people what to do.
The character in the book was dealing with serious emotional problems.
He was expelled from school for cheating on the final exam.
I should never have trusted him in the first place.

vocab.mean: 原话如此（用于口头引用或强调）
vocab.ex: He said he was, quote unquote, 'too busy' to help.
After weeks of working long hours, he finally snapped under the pressure.

gram.name: 链式间接引语
gram.pattern: A character reports what another character said another person thinks.
gram.function: 这是一个复杂的信息传递链条：夏洛特（说话者）在转述朱利安说过的话，而朱利安的话里又引用了他妈妈的想法（'his mom thinks that you... snapped'）。这种层层嵌套的间接引语，生动地展示了谣言是如何被加工、传播和归因的。

example.en: She told me that her brother said he thinks our plan won't work.
example.cn: 她告诉我她哥哥说他认为我们的计划行不通。

gram.constraints: 是一种展示复杂社交互动和信息传播的技巧。

paras.en: I couldn't believe what I was hearing. "No one bought into that, right?" I said. She shrugged. "That's not even the point. The point is he's really popular. And, you know, my mom heard that his mom is actually pushing the school to review Auggie's application to Beecher." "Can she do that?" "It's about Beecher not being an inclusion school. That's a type of school that mixes normal kids with kids with special needs." "That's just stupid. Auggie doesn't have special needs."
paras.cn: 我简直不敢相信我听到的。“没人信那些话，对吧？” 我说。她耸了耸肩。“那甚至不是重点。重点是他真的很受欢迎。而且，你知道，我妈妈听说他妈妈实际上在推动学校重新审查奥吉在比彻的申请。” “她能那么做吗？” “这是关于比彻不是一所全纳学校的事。那是一种将普通孩子和有特殊需求的孩子混合在一起的学校。” “那太蠢了。奥吉没有特殊需求。”

vocab.ex: He's trying to sell me this crazy story, but I don't buy into it.
I know you're tired, but the point is, we have to finish this tonight.
She is the most popular student in her class.
The community is pushing for a new park to be built.
The committee will review all the applications.
An inclusion school aims to provide a supportive environment for all students, including those with special needs.

gram.name: That's not the point
gram.pattern: That's not the point. The point is...
gram.function: 用于将对话的焦点从一个次要问题（人们是否相信谣言）转移到一个更重要、更核心的问题（朱利安的社会权力和其母亲的行为）。这是一种控制对话走向、强调核心论点的有效策略。

example.en: A: But you were only five minutes late! B: That's not the point. The point is that you promised to be on time.
example.cn: A：但你只迟到了五分钟！B：那不是重点。重点是你答应过要准时的。

gram.constraints: 是一种在辩论或解释中常见的、用于澄清焦点的短语。

paras.en: "Yeah, they did. Didn't you notice they changed the theme of the New Year Art Show? In past years fifth graders painted self-portraits, but this year they made us do those ridiculous self-portraits as animals, remember?" "So big freakin' deal." "I know! I'm not saying I agree, I'm just saying that's what she's saying." "I know, I know. This is just so messed up. . . ."
paras.cn: “是啊，他们改了。你没注意到他们改了新年艺术展的主题吗？往年五年级学生都画自画像，但今年他们让我们做那些荒谬的动物自画像，记得吗？” “所以那又算什么大事。” “我知道！我不是说我同意，我只是说她就是那么说的。” “我知道，我知道。这真是太乱了……”

vocab.ex: The theme of the party was 'Hollywood Stars'.
The artist painted a famous self-portrait when he was in his twenties.
He was wearing a ridiculous hat with a propeller on top.
So you got a B instead of an A? Big freakin' deal.
The whole situation is completely messed up.

gram.name: I'm not saying... I'm just saying...
gram.pattern: I'm not saying [A], I'm just saying [B].
gram.function: 一种用于澄清自己立场的复杂结构。说话者首先否定一个可能的误解（“我同意她的做法”），然后陈述自己的真正意图（“我只是在转述她说的话”）。这是一种在传递负面或有争议信息时，用来与信息本身保持距离、避免承担责任的常见社交策略。

example.en: I'm not saying you're wrong, I'm just saying you should consider other options.
example.cn: 我不是说你错了，我只是说你应该考虑其他选项。

gram.constraints: 是一种委婉地表达不同意见或传递信息的技巧。

paras.en: "I know. Anyway, Julian said that he thinks being friends with Auggie is bringing you down, and that for your own good you need to stop hanging out with him so much. And if you start losing all your old friends, it'll be like a big wake-up call. So basically, for your own good, he's going to stop being your friend completely." "News flash: I stopped being his friend completely first!"
paras.cn: “我知道。不管怎样，朱利安说他觉得和奥吉做朋友正在拉低你，而且为了你好，你需要停止那么常和他一起玩。如果你开始失去所有老朋友，那会像一个重要的警钟。所以基本上，为了你好，他要完全停止和你做朋友。” “新闻快讯：是我先完全不和他做朋友的！”

vocab.ex: Don't let his negative attitude bring you down.
I know you don't like taking medicine, but it's for your own good.
Losing his job was a wake-up call for him to start saving money.

vocab.mean: （反讽）新闻快讯（用于告知对方一个显而易见或自己早已知道的事）
vocab.ex: News flash: I already knew about the surprise party.

gram.name: 反讽性框架 ('for your own good')
gram.pattern: Presenting a hostile action under the guise of benevolence.
gram.function: 通过重复 'for your own good' 这个短语，夏洛特揭示了朱利安如何将一个充满敌意和控制欲的行为（孤立杰克）包装成一种善意的、为对方着想的举动。这种语言上的伪装，深刻地暴露了朱利安操纵人心和虚伪的性格。

example.en: He said he was criticizing me 'for my own good,' but it just felt like an insult.
example.cn: 他说他批评我是“为了我好”，但这感觉就像是一种侮辱。

gram.constraints: 是一种典型的、用善意来掩盖恶意的操控性语言。

paras.en: "Yeah, but he's convinced all the boys to stop being your friend—for your own good. That's why nobody's talking to you." "You're talking to me." "Yeah, well, this is more of a boy thing," she explained. "The girls are staying neutral. Except Savanna's group, because they're going out with Julian's group. But to everybody else this is really a boy war." I nodded. She tilted her head to one side and pouted like she felt sorry for me. "Is it okay that I told you all this?" she said.
paras.cn: “是啊，但他已经说服了所有的男孩不再和你做朋友——为了你好。那就是为什么没人跟你说话的原因。” “你在跟我说话。” “嗯，好吧，这更多是男孩之间的事情，” 她解释说。“女孩们保持中立。除了萨凡纳的圈子，因为她们在和朱利安的圈子约会。但对其他所有人来说，这其实是一场男孩战争。” 我点了点头。她把头歪向一边，撅着嘴，好像在为我感到难过。“我告诉你所有这些没关系吧？” 她说。

vocab.ex: He tried to convince me to invest in his new company.
Don't worry about their rough play; it's just a boy thing.
During their argument, I tried to stay neutral and not take sides.
He's been going out with her for six months.

vocab.mean: 男孩战争（指男孩间的冲突）
vocab.ex: The playground disagreement quickly escalated into a full-blown boy war.
The child started to pout when he didn't get what he wanted.

gram.name: 用社交标签来定义冲突
gram.pattern: Using labels like 'boy thing' and 'boy war' to categorize a conflict.
gram.function: 夏洛特通过使用 'a boy thing' 和 'a boy war' 这样的标签，将这场社交冲突归类为一种特定于性别的行为模式。这不仅解释了为什么女孩们“保持中立”，也反映了中学社交环境中常见的、基于性别划分小团体的现象。

example.en: She dismissed their argument as 'just typical office politics.'
example.cn: 她把他们的争论斥为“不过是典型的办公室政治”。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过归类来解释和简化复杂社交动态的方式。

paras.en: "Yeah! Of course! I don't care who talks to me or not," I lied. "This is all just so dumb." She nodded. "Hey, does Auggie know any of this?" "Of course not. At least, not from me." "And Summer?" "I don't think so. Look, I better go. Just so you know, my mom thinks Julian's mom is a total idiot. She said she thinks people like her are more concerned about what their kids' class pictures look like than doing the right thing. You heard about the Photoshopping, right?" "Yeah, that was just sick." "Totally," she answered, nodding. "Anyway, I better go. I just wanted you to know what was up and stuff." "Thanks, Charlotte." "I'll let you know if I hear anything else," she said. Before she went out, she looked left and right outside the door to make sure no one saw her leaving. I guess even though she was neutral, she didn't want to be seen with me.
paras.cn: “是啊！当然！我不在乎谁跟不跟我说话，” 我撒谎道。“这一切都太傻了。” 她点了点头。“嘿，奥吉知道这些事吗？” “当然不了。至少，不是从我这里知道的。” “那萨默呢？” “我想她也不知道。听着，我最好走了。只是让你知道，我妈妈觉得朱利安的妈妈是个十足的白痴。她说她觉得像她那样的人更关心她们孩子的班级合影看起来怎么样，而不是做正确的事。你听说过那个P图的事了，对吧？” “是啊，那太恶心了。” “完全是，” 她点着头回答。“不管怎样，我最好走了。我只是想让你知道怎么回事之类的。” “谢谢你，夏洛特。” “如果我听到别的什么，我会告诉你的，” 她说。在她出去之前，她在门外左右看了看，确保没人看到她离开。我猜尽管她是中立的，她也不想被看到和我在一起。

vocab.ex: You can say what you want; I don't care.
That was a dumb decision to make.
Just so you know, the meeting has been moved to 3 PM.
I felt like a total idiot when I realized I had left my keys in the car.
He is more concerned about his reputation than about telling the truth.
His cruel jokes are just sick.
It's getting late; I better go now.

gram.name: 言行不一
gram.pattern: A character's actions contradict their stated position.
gram.function: 夏洛特声称自己“中立”，并且对杰克表达了支持和同情。然而，她最后“左右查看以确保没人看到她离开”的行为，与她的言辞形成了鲜明的对比。这种言行不一深刻地揭示了她内心的真实恐惧——害怕因为与杰克产生关联而损害自己的社交地位。这比任何直接的陈述都更能体现出中学社交压力的强大。

example.en: He said he wasn't afraid, but his trembling hands told a different story.
example.cn: 他说他不怕，但他颤抖的双手却说明了另一回事。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行为来揭示人物真实动机和内心冲突的有效技巧。

paras.en: The next day at lunch, stupid me, I sat down at a table with Tristan, Nino, and Pablo. I thought maybe they were safe because they weren't really considered popular, but they weren't out there playing D&D at recess, either. They were sort of in-betweeners. And, at first, I thought I scored because they were basically too nice to not acknowledge my presence when I walked over to the table. They all said "Hey," though I could tell they looked at each other. But then the same thing happened that happened yesterday: our lunch table was called, they got their food, and then headed toward a new table on the other side of the cafeteria.
paras.cn: 第二天午餐时，愚蠢的我，和特里斯坦、尼诺、巴勃罗坐在一张桌子旁。我想也许他们是安全的，因为他们不怎么被认为是受欢迎的，但他们也不会在课间休息时去玩《龙与地下城》。他们算是中间派。而且，起初，我以为我得分了，因为当我走到桌边时，他们基本上都太好人了，不好意思不理会我的存在。他们都说了“嘿”，尽管我看得出他们互相看了看。但接着和昨天一样的事情发生了：我们的午餐桌被叫到了，他们拿了食物，然后就走向了餐厅另一边的一张新桌子。

vocab.ex: I locked my keys in the car again. Stupid me.
He is considered an expert in his field.
Some of his ideas are a little out there, but he's a creative thinker.

vocab.mean: 中间派；介于两者之间的人
vocab.ex: She wasn't a jock or a nerd; she was more of an in-betweener.
I managed to get the last concert ticket. I really scored!
He walked right past me and didn't even acknowledge my presence.
After the movie, we decided to head toward the nearest ice cream shop.

gram.name: 自嘲式叙事开篇
gram.pattern: [Self-deprecating phrase], + [action].
gram.function: 通过使用一个自嘲的短语 'stupid me' 作为句子的开头，叙述者立刻为接下来的事件设定了一种带有懊悔和自我批评的基调。这是一种非常个人化和口语化的叙事方式，让读者直接进入角色的内心世界，预感到接下来的事情不会顺利。

example.en: Silly me, I forgot to bring an umbrella.
example.cn: 傻傻的我，竟然忘了带伞。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过自我评价来引导读者情绪的技巧。

paras.en: Unfortunately, Mrs. G, who was the lunch teacher that day, saw what happened and chased after them. "That's not allowed, boys!" she scolded them loudly. "This is not that kind of school. You get right back to your table." Oh great, like that was going to help. Before they could be forced to sit back down at the table, I got up with my tray and walked away really fast. I could hear Mrs. G call my name, but I pretended not to hear and just kept walking to the other side of the cafeteria, behind the lunch counter.
paras.cn: 不幸的是，那天当值的餐厅老师G夫人看到了发生的一切，并追了上去。“那是不允许的，孩子们！” 她大声训斥他们。“这不是那种学校。你们马上回到你们的桌子去。” 哦太好了，说得好像那会有帮助似的。在他们可能被强迫坐回桌子前，我端着餐盘站起来，飞快地走开了。我能听到G夫人在叫我的名字，但我假装没听到，只是继续走向餐厅的另一边，午餐柜台的后面。

vocab.ex: Unfortunately, we have to cancel the trip.
The dog started to chase after the squirrel.
The teacher had to scold the student for misbehaving.
You left your room a mess; get right back in there and clean it up.
After the argument, he just turned and walked away.

gram.name: 反讽性修辞评论
gram.pattern: A sarcastic comment on an ongoing event.
gram.function: 通过一个反讽的内心独白 'Oh great, like that was going to help'，叙述者表达了他对老师干预行为的极度不满和无奈。他知道这种公开的干预只会让情况变得更糟，使他更加尴尬。这是一种通过内心评论来揭示角色对情境深刻理解的方式。

example.en: My flight is cancelled. Oh, perfect. Just what I needed today.
example.cn: 我的航班取消了。哦，太完美了。正是我今天所需要的。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过反语来表达强烈负面情绪的技巧。

paras.en: "Sit with us, Jack." It was Summer. She and August were sitting at their table, and they were both waving me over.
paras.cn: “和我们一起坐，杰克。” 是萨默。她和奥古斯特正坐在他们的桌子旁，他们俩都在朝我招手。

vocab.ex: I'm going to sit with my friends at the front of the theater.
She saw me across the room and waved me over to her table.

gram.name: 高潮式邀请与解决
gram.pattern: A short, direct invitation that resolves the central conflict of the scene.
gram.function: 在经历了连续的社交排斥和内心挣扎之后，一个非常简单、直接的祈使句 'Sit with us, Jack' 突然出现，为整个场景的紧张气氛提供了一个戏剧性的转折和解决方案。这个邀请不仅仅是一个座位，更是一种接纳和友谊的象征，与之前的拒绝形成了强烈的对比，从而产生了巨大的情感力量。

example.en: He was lost and alone. Then a voice called out, 'Come inside.'
example.cn: 他迷失而孤独。然后一个声音喊道：‘进来吧。’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过简单的语言来创造强烈情感高潮的文学技巧。

title: Why I Didn't Sit with August the First Day of School

paras.en: Okay, I'm a total hypocrite. I know. That very first day of school I remember seeing August in the cafeteria. Everybody was looking at him. Talking about him. Back then, no one was used to his face or even knew that he was coming to Beecher, so it was a total shocker for a lot of people to see him there on the first day of school. Most kids were even afraid to get near him.
paras.cn: 好吧，我真是个十足的伪君子。我知道。我记得开学第一天，我在餐厅里看到了奥古斯特。每个人都在看他，谈论他。那时候，没人习惯他的脸，甚至不知道他要来比彻上学，所以第一天在学校看到他，对很多人来说都是个十足的震撼。大多数孩子甚至害怕靠近他。

vocab.ex: He's a hypocrite for telling people not to smoke while he does it himself.
Students eat their lunch in the school cafeteria.
Back then, we didn't have smartphones.
It was a real shocker when the underdog team won the championship.
The cat hissed at the dog when it tried to get near.

gram.name: 直率的自我忏悔
gram.pattern: A direct, first-person statement of a negative self-assessment.
gram.function: 通过一个非常直接、不加掩饰的自我谴责（'Okay, I'm a total hypocrite. I know.'）来作为章节的开篇，叙述者立刻就建立了一种忏悔的、诚实的基调。这种方式能迅速拉近与读者的距离，让读者准备好去聆听一个充满内心挣扎的故事。

example.en: Let me be honest: I was a coward.
example.cn: 让我说实话吧：我曾是个懦夫。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过坦诚来建立读者信任的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: So when I saw him going into the cafeteria ahead of me, I knew he'd have no one to sit with, but I just couldn't bring myself to sit with him. I had been hanging out with him all morning long because we had so many classes together, and I guess I was just kind of wanting a little normal time to chill with other kids. So when I saw him move to a table on the other side of the lunch counter, I purposely found a table as far away from there as I could find. I sat down with Isaiah and Luca even though I'd never met them before, and we talked about baseball the whole time, and I played basketball with them at recess. They became my lunch table from then on.
paras.cn: 所以当我看到他走在我前面进入餐厅时，我知道他会没人一起坐，但我就是没法强迫自己和他坐在一起。我整个上午都和他待在一起，因为我们有很多课在一起，我猜我只是有点想要一点正常的时间和其他孩子放松一下。所以当我看到他移到午餐柜台另一边的一张桌子时，我故意找了一张离那里尽可能远的桌子。我和以赛亚、卢卡坐在一起，尽管我以前从未见过他们，我们整个时间都在谈论棒球，课间休息时我还和他们一起打了篮球。从那时起，他们就成了我的午餐桌伙伴。

vocab.ex: She finished the race far ahead of the other runners.

vocab.mean: 没法强迫自己去（做某事）
vocab.ex: I knew I should apologize, but I just couldn't bring myself to do it.
After a long week of exams, I just want to chill on the sofa.
I think he purposely ignored me at the party.
He moved to a town as far away as he could get from his old life.
He discovered his love for painting, and from then on, he painted every day.

gram.name: 认知与行为的冲突
gram.pattern: [Statement of knowledge/empathy] + 'but' + [contrary action/inability to act].
gram.function: 通过一个清晰的对比结构，叙述者揭示了他内心的道德挣扎。他清楚地知道正确的做法（'I knew he'd have no one to sit with'），但由于社交压力或个人欲望，他无法做到（'but I just couldn't bring myself to...'），并最终采取了相反的行动（'I purposely found a table as far away'）。这深刻地展现了角色的弱点和伪善。

example.en: She knew she should tell the truth, but she couldn't bring herself to confess.
example.cn: 她知道自己应该说实话，但就是没法强迫自己坦白。

gram.constraints: 是展示人物内心挣扎的有效技巧。

paras.en: I heard Summer had sat down with August, which surprised me because I knew for a fact she wasn't one of the kids that Tushman had talked to about being friends with Auggie. So I knew she was doing it just to be nice, and that was pretty brave, I thought.
paras.cn: 我听说萨默和奥古斯特坐在一起了，这让我很惊讶，因为我确切地知道她不是塔什曼先生找来和奥吉做朋友的那些孩子之一。所以我知道她这么做只是出于善意，而且我觉得那相当勇敢。

vocab.ex: I know for a fact that he was not there last night.
He didn't want the gift, but he accepted it just to be nice.
It was brave of him to admit his mistake.

gram.name: 推断动机
gram.pattern: Contrasting known information to deduce the true reason for an action.
gram.function: 通过对比一个已知事实（萨默不是被“安排”的）和她的行为（和奥古斯特坐在一起），叙述者推断出了她行为背后的真实动机（'just to be nice'）。这个推理过程不仅揭示了他对萨默行为的钦佩（'pretty brave'），也通过对比，间接反映了他对自己先前行为的羞愧。

example.en: He wasn't getting paid for the extra work, so I knew he was doing it out of kindness.
example.cn: 他做额外的工作没有报酬，所以我知道他是出于善意。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过逻辑推理来塑造人物和主题的叙事技巧。

paras.en: So now here I was sitting with Summer and August, and they were being totally nice to me as always. I filled them in about everything Charlotte had told me, except for the whole big part about my having "snapped" under the pressure of being Auggie's friend, or the part about Julian's mom saying that Auggie had special needs, or the part about the school board. I guess all I really told them about was how Julian had had a holiday party and managed to turn the whole grade against me.
paras.cn: 所以现在我正和萨默、奥古斯特坐在一起，他们像往常一样对我非常友善。我把夏洛特告诉我的所有事都跟他们说了，除了关于我在做奥吉朋友的压力下“崩溃”的那一大部分，或者关于朱利安妈妈说奥吉有特殊需求的那部分，或者关于校董会的那部分。我猜我真正告诉他们的，只有朱利安如何办了个节日派对并设法让整个年级都来反对我。

vocab.ex: Can you fill me in on what happened at the meeting I missed?
The room was empty except for a single chair in the corner.
After weeks of working long hours, he finally snapped under the pressure.
The school has excellent resources for children with special needs.
The school board voted to approve the new budget.
The politician's lies made the public turn against him.

gram.name: 叙事性选择省略
gram.pattern: Stating a general action of sharing, then explicitly listing the parts that were withheld using 'except for'.
gram.function: 通过先说“我告诉了他们所有事”，然后立刻用 'except for' 列出一系列被隐瞒的关键信息，叙述者揭示了他内心的自我保护机制。他选择性地分享信息，将自己塑造成一个单纯的受害者，而隐瞒了那些可能让他看起来不那么无辜的复杂部分，这深刻地展现了他的内疚和挣扎。

example.en: I told her all about my trip, except for the part where I lost my wallet.
example.cn: 我告诉了她我旅行的所有事，除了我丢钱包那部分。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过展示角色选择“不说什么”来揭示其内心状态的有效技巧。

paras.en: "It just feels so weird," I said, "to not have people talking to you, pretending you don't even exist." Auggie started smiling. "Ya think?" he said sarcastically. "Welcome to my world!"
paras.cn: “没人跟你说话，假装你根本不存在，这种感觉太奇怪了，” 我说。奥吉开始笑了。“你觉得呢？” 他讽刺地说。“欢迎来到我的世界！”

vocab.ex: The children pretended to be asleep when their mom came in.
Do you believe that ghosts really exist?
A: 'Wow, it's really hot today.' B: 'Ya think?'
When I arrived late, he sarcastically said, 'Nice of you to join us.'

vocab.mean: 欢迎来到我的世界（表示“我一直都这样”）
vocab.ex: You're stressed about one exam? Welcome to my world, I have three this week.

gram.name: 反讽性视角转换
gram.pattern: A character complains about a temporary negative experience to someone who lives with that experience permanently.
gram.function: 这是一个极具冲击力的时刻。当杰克抱怨被暂时孤立时，他无意中描述了奥古斯特的日常生活。奥古斯特通过讽刺性的回应（'Ya think?', 'Welcome to my world!'），利用杰克自身的短暂痛苦，迫使他（和读者）去理解自己长期承受的、更为深刻的孤立。这瞬间颠覆了对话的视角，创造了强烈的戏剧性反讽和共情。

example.en: A millionaire complaining about a one-dollar price increase to a homeless person would be an ironic reversal of perspective.
example.cn: 一个百万富翁向一个无家可归的人抱怨物价涨了一美元，这将是一种反讽性的视角转换。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过情境对比来产生深刻启示的强大文学技巧。

paras.en: "So here are the official sides," said Summer at lunch the next day. She pulled out a folded piece of loose-leaf paper and opened it. It had three columns of names.  Jack's Side: Jack August Reid Max G Max W Julian's Sides: Miles Henry Amos Simon Tristan Pablo Nino LucaIsaiah Jake Toland Roman Ben Emmanuel Zele Tomaso Neutrals: Malik Remo Jose Leif Ram Ivan Russell "Where did you get this?" said Auggie, looking over my shoulder as I read the list.
paras.cn: “所以这是官方的站队情况，” 第二天午餐时萨默说。她拿出一张折叠的活页纸并打开了它。上面有三列名字。杰克这边：杰克 奥古斯特 里德 马克斯·G 马克斯·W 朱利安那边：迈尔斯 亨利 阿莫斯 西蒙 特里斯坦 巴勃罗 尼诺 卢卡以赛亚 杰克·托兰 罗曼 本 伊曼纽尔 泽勒 托马索 中立派：马利克 雷莫 何塞 利夫 拉姆 伊凡 罗素 “你从哪儿弄到这个的？” 奥吉说，在我读名单时从我肩膀上看过来。

vocab.ex: The official announcement will be made tomorrow.
Whose side are you on in this argument?
She wrote her notes on a piece of loose-leaf paper.
Please write your name in the first column of the spreadsheet.
In their argument, I tried to remain a neutral.
It's annoying when someone reads over your shoulder.

gram.name: 列表作为叙事工具
gram.pattern: A literal list embedded in the narrative to convey information.
gram.function: 通过直接呈现一个实体列表，作者以一种非常直接、视觉化的方式向读者展示了五年级社交圈的分裂情况。这个列表比任何描述性语言都更能清晰、冷酷地传达出“战争”的规模、阵营的划分以及杰克被孤立的程度。

example.en: His to-do list was long: Finish report. Call clients. Schedule meeting.
example.cn: 他的待办事项清单很长：完成报告。给客户打电话。安排会议。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过非传统叙事形式来传递信息的有效技巧。

paras.en: "Charlotte made it," Summer answered quickly. "She gave it to me last period. She said she thought you should know who was on your side, Jack." "Yeah, not many people, that's for sure," I said. "Reid is," she said. "And the two Maxes." "Great. The nerds are on my side." "Don't be mean," said Summer. "I think Charlotte likes you, by the way." "Yeah, I know." "Are you going to ask her out?"
paras.cn: “夏洛特做的，” 萨默迅速回答。“她上节课给我的。她说她觉得你应该知道谁站在你这边，杰克。” “是啊，没多少人，那是肯定的，” 我说。“里德是，” 她说。“还有两个马克斯。” “太好了。书呆子们站我这边。” “别这么刻薄，” 萨默说。“顺便说一下，我觉得夏洛特喜欢你。” “嗯，我知道。” “你准备约她出去吗？”

vocab.ex: No matter what happens, I'll always be on your side.
It's going to be a difficult game, that's for sure.
He was considered a nerd in high school because he loved studying.
Don't be mean to your little brother.
He was too shy to ask her out.

gram.name: 轻蔑性标签化
gram.pattern: Using a pejorative label to devalue something or someone.
gram.function: 当杰克将支持他的人归类为“书呆子”（'nerds'）时，他表现出了一种复杂的心理状态。一方面，这是一种因被“受欢迎”团体排斥而产生的沮丧和不屑；另一方面，这也反映了他自己内心对社交地位的在意。他通过贬低自己的支持者来表达对自己当前处境的不满。

example.en: He dismissed her thoughtful gift as 'just some cheap trinket.'
example.cn: 他把她那份充满心意的礼物贬低为“不过是个廉价的小玩意儿”。

gram.constraints: 是一种揭示人物内心冲突和不安全感的有效方式。

paras.en: "Are you kidding? I can't, now that everybody's acting like I have the Plague." The second I said it, I realized I shouldn't have said it. There was this awkward moment of silence. I looked at Auggie. "It's okay," he said. "I knew about that." "Sorry, dude," I said. "I didn't know they called it the Plague, though," he said.
paras.cn: “你在开玩笑吗？我现在不能，既然大家都表现得好像我得了瘟疫一样。” 我一说出口，就意识到我不该说这话。出现了一阵尴尬的沉默。我看着奥吉。“没关系，” 他说。“我知道那事。” “对不起，哥们，” 我说。“不过，我不知道他们管那叫瘟疫，” 他说。

vocab.mean: 你在开玩笑吗？（表示不相信或反对）
vocab.ex: You want me to finish all this work by tomorrow? Are you kidding me?
Now that you're here, you can help me with this.

vocab.mean: 瘟疫（此处指一个社交排斥游戏）
vocab.ex: The new student was afraid of getting 'the Plague' from the unpopular kids.
I'm sorry, that was a mean comment. I shouldn't have said it.
After his inappropriate joke, there was an awkward moment of silence.

gram.name: the second (表示即时醒悟)
gram.pattern: the second + clause
gram.function: 用作连词，意为“一…就…”，强调一个动作紧接着另一个认知或反应发生。'The second I said it, I realized...' 强调了叙述者在说出不当言论后立刻就感到了后悔，突显了他话语的失误和即时的自我反省。

example.en: The second the words left my mouth, I knew I had made a mistake.
example.cn: 话一出口，我就知道我犯了个错误。

gram.constraints: 是一种比 'when' 语气更强、更具即时性的表达方式。

paras.en: "I figured it was more like the Cheese Touch or something." "Oh, yeah, like in Diary of a Wimpy Kid." I nodded. "The Plague actually sounds cooler," he joked. "Like someone could catch the 'black death of ugliness.' " As he said this, he made air quotes.
paras.cn: “我琢磨着那更像是‘奶酪之触’之类的。” “哦，是啊，就像《小屁孩日记》里那样。” 我点了点头。“‘瘟疫’听起来其实更酷，” 他开玩笑说。“就像有人会染上‘丑陋黑死病’一样。” 他说这话时，做了个空中引号的手势。

vocab.ex: I figure it's going to rain later, so I'll bring an umbrella.

vocab.mean: 奶酪之触（《小屁孩日记》中的概念）
vocab.ex: In elementary school, nobody wanted to get the imaginary Cheese Touch.
The Black Death was a devastating pandemic in the 14th century.

vocab.mean: 空中引号（用手指在空中比划引号）
vocab.ex: He used air quotes when he said the word 'healthy' to show he was being sarcastic.

gram.name: 自嘲式幽默（作为应对机制）
gram.pattern: Making a joke about one's own painful situation.
gram.function: 奥吉通过开玩笑（'The Plague actually sounds cooler'）和创造一个夸张、自嘲的短语（'black death of ugliness'），将一个极其伤人的社交游戏转化成了一个幽默的谈资。这是一种高级的心理防御和应对机制，不仅化解了杰克的尴尬，也展示了他非凡的韧性和智慧。

example.en: After failing the exam, he joked, 'Well, I'm just setting a new record for the lowest score!'
example.cn: 考试不及格后，他开玩笑说：‘嗯，我只是在刷新最低分的新纪录！’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过幽默来掌控痛苦局面的强大能力。

paras.en: "I think it's awful," said Summer, but Auggie shrugged while taking a big sip from his juice box. "Anyway, I'm not asking Charlotte out," I said. "My mom thinks we're all too young to be dating anyway," she answered. "What if Reid asked you out?" I said. "Would you go?" I could tell she was surprised. "No!" she said. "I'm just asking," I laughed.
paras.cn: “我觉得这太糟了，” 萨默说，但奥吉耸了耸肩，同时大口地喝着他的果汁盒。“不管怎样，我不会约夏洛特出去的，” 我说。“反正我妈妈觉得我们都太小了，不该约会，” 她回答。“如果里德约你出去呢？” 我说。“你会去吗？” 我看得出她很惊讶。“不！” 她说。“我只是问问，” 我笑了。

vocab.ex: That was an awful thing to do to a friend.
He took a small sip of his coffee.
She thinks high school is too early to start dating.
What if it rains during our picnic?

gram.name: 对不公的对比反应
gram.pattern: Character A expresses outrage while Character B displays nonchalance.
gram.function: 通过将萨默直接的情感反应（'I think it's awful'）与奥吉平静的、不屑一顾的身体语言（'shrugged while taking a big sip'）并置，作者深刻地对比了两种不同的应对方式。萨默的反应代表了旁观者的正义感，而奥吉的反应则揭示了一个长期经受不公的人所发展出的、更为内化的、复杂的应对机制。

example.en: She was furious about the mistake, but he just calmly started fixing it.
example.cn: 她对那个错误非常愤怒，但他只是平静地开始修复它。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比行为来揭示人物性格和经历差异的有效技巧。

paras.en: She shook her head and smiled. "Why? What do you know?" "Nothing! I'm just asking!" I said. "I actually agree with my mom," she said. "I do think we're too young to be dating. I mean, I just don't see what the rush is." "Yeah, I agree," said August. "Which is kind of a shame, you know, what with all those babes who keep throwing themselves at me and stuff?"
paras.cn: 她摇了摇头，笑了。“为什么？你知道什么了？” “没什么！我只是问问！” 我说。“我其实同意我妈妈的看法，” 她说。“我确实觉得我们谈恋爱太早了。我的意思是，我就是不明白急什么。” “是啊，我同意，” 奥古斯特说。“这有点可惜，你知道，鉴于所有那些美女不停地向我投怀送抱之类的？”

vocab.ex: The train doesn't leave for an hour, what's the rush?
It's a shame that you can't come to the party.
I'm exhausted, what with the long hours at work and the new baby at home.
He thinks he's popular with all the babes.
She was so famous that fans would throw themselves at her wherever she went.

gram.name: 反讽性自夸
gram.pattern: Making a humorously boastful statement that is clearly untrue.
gram.function: 奥吉通过一个明显与事实相反的、夸张的自夸（'what with all those babes who keep throwing themselves at me'），再次使用了自嘲式幽默。这个玩笑之所以高明，是因为它建立在所有人都知道的残酷现实（没人愿意接近他）之上。通过主动调侃这个最痛苦的事实，他不仅展示了惊人的智慧和自信，也完全掌控了局面，将可能令人尴尬的“约会”话题变成了一个让所有人都能笑出来的轻松时刻。

example.en: After tripping on the sidewalk, he stood up and said, 'Don't worry, that was just my new dance move.'
example.cn: 在人行道上绊倒后，他站起来说：‘别担心，那只是我的新舞步。’

gram.constraints: 是一种非常高级的、通过反差来创造幽默和化解尴尬的沟通技巧。

paras.en: He said this in such a funny way that the milk I was drinking came out my nose when I laughed, which made us all totally crack up.
paras.cn: 他用一种非常滑稽的方式说出这话，以至于我笑的时候，正在喝的牛奶从我鼻子里喷了出来，这让我们所有人都笑翻了。

vocab.mean: 以一种如此…的方式以至于…
vocab.ex: He told the story in such a dramatic way that everyone was on the edge of their seats.
Please wait for the cookies to cool before they come out of the oven.
His funny story made everyone in the room crack up.

gram.name: 生理反应作为叙事高潮
gram.pattern: A climactic moment described through a visceral, uncontrolled physical reaction.
gram.function: 这个场景的高潮并非通过语言，而是通过一个极具画面感的、无法控制的生理反应来体现的——“牛奶从我鼻子里喷了出来”。这个有些狼狈但非常真实的细节，比任何“我们都笑了”的描述都更能有力地证明奥吉玩笑的成功，以及他们之间友谊的真诚和轻松。它象征着紧张气氛的彻底瓦解和友谊的回归。

example.en: The joke was so unexpected, he choked on his water.
example.cn: 那个玩笑太出乎意料了，他喝水都呛到了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过具体、生动的身体反应来传达强烈情感和事件结果的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: It was already the middle of January, and we still hadn't even chosen what science-fair project we were going to work on. I guess I kept putting it off because I just didn't want to do it. Finally, August was like, "Dude, we have to do this." So we went to his house after school. I was really nervous because I didn't know if August had ever told his parents about what we now called the Halloween Incident. Turns out the dad wasn't even home and the mom was out running errands. I'm pretty sure from the two seconds I'd spent talking to her that Auggie had never mentioned a thing about it. She was super cool and friendly toward me.
paras.cn: 已经一月中旬了，我们甚至还没选好要做哪个科学展览项目。我猜我一直在拖延，因为我就是不想做。最后，奥古斯特说：“老兄，我们必须做这个了。” 于是我们放学后去了他家。我真的很紧张，因为我不知道奥古斯特有没有告诉过他父母关于我们现在称之为“万圣节事件”的事。结果他爸爸甚至不在家，妈妈也出去办事了。从我和她交谈的那两秒钟来看，我敢肯定奥吉从未提过一丁点关于那件事。她对我超级酷，很友好。

vocab.ex: He keeps putting off his dental appointment because he's afraid.
And then he cancelled, and I was like, 'Are you serious?'
The police are investigating the incident at the bank.
The weather forecast said it would rain, but it turned out to be a sunny day.
I have to run some errands this afternoon, like going to the post office and the bank.
Please don't mention a thing about the surprise party to him.

gram.name: 命名事件作为叙事简写
gram.pattern: Referring to a past event by a capitalized, specific name.
gram.function: 通过将一个复杂的、充满情感的过去事件命名为“the Halloween Incident”，作者创造了一个叙事上的“简写”。这个专有名词不仅能让读者立刻回想起之前的情节，也反映了角色们是如何在他们之间定义和理解这段共同经历的，暗示了这件事的重大影响。

example.en: After what they called 'the Great Cookie Disaster,' no one was allowed to bake in the kitchen again.
example.cn: 在他们称之为“饼干大灾难”的事件之后，再也没人被允许在厨房里烘焙了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过命名来赋予事件特殊意义的文学技巧。

paras.en: When I first walked into Auggie's room, I was like, "Whoa, Auggie, you have got a serious Star Wars addiction." He had ledges full of Star Wars miniatures, and a huge The Empire Strikes Back poster on his wall. "I know, right?" he laughed. He sat down on a rolling chair next to his desk and I plopped down on a beanbag chair in the corner. That's when his dog waddled into the room right up to me.
paras.cn: 我第一次走进奥吉的房间时，我当时就说：“哇，奥吉，你可真是有严重的星球大战瘾。” 他的壁架上摆满了星球大战的微缩模型，墙上还挂着一张巨大的《帝国反击战》海报。“可不是嘛？” 他笑了。他坐在书桌旁的一把滚轮椅上，我则扑通一声坐到角落里的一个豆袋椅上。就在那时，他的狗摇摇摆摆地走进房间，径直朝我走来。

vocab.ex: He has a serious addiction to video games and plays for hours every day.
She placed a small plant on the window ledge.
He collects tiny miniatures of famous buildings.
She spun around in her rolling chair at her desk.
After a long day, he plopped down on the sofa.
The kids love jumping on the big beanbag chair in the living room.
The toddler waddled across the room toward his mother.

gram.name: That's when... (用于叙事转折点)
gram.pattern: That's when + clause
gram.function: 用于强调某个特定时刻的重要性，标志着一个新事件的开始或一个转折点。'That's when his dog waddled into the room...' 将叙述的焦点从对房间的观察，突然转移到一个新的、正在发生的动作上，推动了情节发展。

example.en: I was about to leave, and that's when he finally told me the truth.
example.cn: 我正要离开，就在那时他终于告诉了我真相。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中创造戏剧性效果的常用手法。

paras.en: "He was on your holiday card!" I said, letting the dog sniff my hand. "She," he corrected me. "Daisy. You can pet her. She doesn't bite." When I started petting her, she basically just rolled over onto her back. "She wants you to rub her tummy," said August. "Okay, this is the cutest dog I've ever seen," I said, rubbing her stomach. "I know, right? She's the best dog in the world. Aren't you, girlie?" As soon as she heard Auggie's voice say that, the dog started wagging her tail and went over to him.
paras.cn: “它上过你的节日贺卡！” 我说，让那只狗闻我的手。“是‘她’，” 他纠正我。“黛西。你可以摸她。她不咬人。” 当我开始抚摸她时，她基本上就直接翻过身来，四脚朝天。“她想让你揉她的肚子，” 奥古斯特说。“好吧，这是我见过最可爱的狗了，” 我一边揉着她的肚子一边说。“可不是嘛？她是世界上最好的狗。是不是啊，小姑娘？” 狗一听到奥吉这么说，就开始摇尾巴，并向他走去。

vocab.ex: The dog started to sniff the strange new object on the floor.
He loves to sit on the sofa and pet his cat.
The trainer taught the dog how to roll over and play dead.
My dog loves it when I rub his tummy.
That is the cutest puppy I have ever seen in my life.
The happy dog started to wag its tail as soon as its owner came home.

gram.name: 直接对动物说话
gram.pattern: Speaking to an animal as if it is a person.
gram.function: 角色通过直接对小狗说话（'Aren't you, girlie?'）并使用附加疑问句，展现了他与宠物之间亲密、充满爱意的关系。这种拟人化的交流方式，也向读者揭示了角色温柔、充满爱心的一面。

example.en: She looked at her cat and said, 'You're the prettiest cat in the world, aren't you?'
example.cn: 她看着她的猫说：‘你是世界上最漂亮的猫，不是吗？’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过人与动物的互动来塑造人物性格的有效技巧。

paras.en: "Who's my little girlie? Who's my little girlie?" Auggie was saying as she licked him all over the face. "I wish I had a dog," I said. "My parents think our apartment's too small." I started looking around at the stuff in his room while he turned on the computer. "Hey, you've got an Xbox 360? Can we play?" "Dude, we're here to work on the science-fair project." "Do you have Halo ?" "Of course I have Halo." "Please can we play?"
paras.cn: “谁是我的小姑娘？谁是我的小姑娘？” 奥吉在她舔遍他整张脸时说。“我希望我有一只狗，” 我说。“我父母觉得我们的公寓太小了。” 他打开电脑时，我开始环顾他房间里的东西。“嘿，你有个Xbox 360？我们能玩吗？” “老兄，我们是来做科学展览项目的。” “你有《光环》吗？” “我当然有《光环》。” “求你了，我们能玩吗？”

vocab.mean: （对女孩或雌性动物的昵称）小姑娘
vocab.ex: He calls his little daughter his favorite girlie.
When she entered the beautiful room, she just stood there and looked around in awe.
They spent the whole weekend playing games on their Xbox 360.
Halo is a very popular first-person shooter game.

gram.name: 对话焦点的对比
gram.pattern: Character A wants to be social/play, while Character B tries to stay on task.
gram.function: 通过两个角色之间对话焦点的鲜明对比，作者塑造了他们不同的性格和当时的心态。杰克不断被房间里的东西分心，想玩游戏，表现出一种随性、贪玩的态度。而奥吉则一直试图把话题拉回到“科学项目”这个主要任务上，表现出更强的责任感和专注力。

example.en: A: We need to finish this report. B: Hey, is that a new painting on your wall?
example.cn: A：我们需要完成这份报告。B：嘿，你墙上那是一幅新画吗？

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对话来揭示人物性格和优先事项的有效技巧。

paras.en: He had logged on to the Beecher website and was now scrolling down Ms. Rubin's teacher page through the list of science-fair projects. "Can you see from there?" he said. I sighed and went to sit on a little stool that was right next to him. "Cool iMac," I said. "What kind of computer do you have?" "Dude, I don't even have my own room, much less my own computer. My parents have this ancient Dell that's practically dead."
paras.cn: 他已经登录了比彻学校的网站，现在正在鲁宾女士的教师页面上向下滚动科学展览项目的列表。“你能从那里看到吗？” 他说。我叹了口气，走过去坐在他旁边的一张小凳子上。“很酷的iMac，” 我说。“你用的是什么电脑？” “老兄，我连自己的房间都没有，更别提自己的电脑了。我父母有台古老的戴尔电脑，基本上快报废了。”

vocab.ex: You need a password to log on to the website.
Just scroll down to the bottom of the page to find the 'submit' button.
He sat on a tall stool at the kitchen counter.
I can't even afford a bicycle, much less a car.

vocab.mean: 古老的（此处为夸张用法）
vocab.ex: My phone is so old; it feels like an ancient artifact.
The battery on my laptop is practically dead; it only lasts for ten minutes.

gram.name: not even... much less... (用于递进强调)
gram.pattern: not even [A], much less [B].
gram.function: 一种强有力的递进否定结构，用于强调情况的欠缺。通过先否定一个相对基本的事物（'my own room'），然后再用 'much less' 引出一个更高级的事物（'my own computer'），叙述者有力地突显了自己家庭的经济状况，与奥吉的富裕形成对比。

example.en: He can't even boil an egg, much less cook a full meal.
example.cn: 他连煮个鸡蛋都不会，更不用说做一顿正餐了。

gram.constraints: 是一种在对比中进行强调的有效修辞手法。

paras.en: "Okay, how about this one?" he said, turning the screen in my direction so I would look. I made a quick scan of the screen and my eyes literally started blurring. "Making a sun clock," he said. "That sounds kind of cool." I leaned back. "Can't we just make a volcano?" "Everyone makes volcanoes." "Duh, because it's easy," I said, petting Daisy again.
paras.cn: “好吧，这个怎么样？” 他说，把屏幕转向我的方向好让我看。我快速扫了一眼屏幕，我的眼睛真的开始模糊了。“制作一个日晷，” 他说。“那听起来挺酷的。” 我向后靠去。“我们就不能只做个火山吗？” “每个人都做火山。” “咄，因为它简单啊，” 我说，又摸了摸黛西。

vocab.ex: He threw the ball in my direction.
She did a quick scan of the headlines before starting her day.
Tears started to blur her vision.
A sun clock, or sundial, uses the position of the sun to tell time.
He leaned back in his chair and relaxed.
The classic science fair project is a model volcano that erupts.

vocab.mean: （非正式，表示某事显而易见）咄；废话
vocab.ex: A: Is the sky blue? B: Well, duh.

gram.name: 反问句（用于提建议）
gram.pattern: Can't we just + infinitive?
gram.function: 通过一个否定的反问句 'Can't we just make a volcano?'，说话者并非在询问可能性，而是在提出一个建议，并暗示这是一种更简单、更可取的选择。这种方式比直接说 'Let's make a volcano' 语气更委婉，但也带有一种抱怨或寻求捷径的意味。

example.en: Can't we just order pizza instead of cooking?
example.cn: 我们就不能只点披萨而不是自己做饭吗？

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、非正式的建议方式。

paras.en: "What about: How to make crystal spikes out of Epsom salt?" "Sounds boring," I answered. "So why'd you call her Daisy?" He didn't look up from the screen. "My sister named her. I wanted to call her Darth. Actually, technically speaking, her full name is Darth Daisy, but we never really called her that." "Darth Daisy! That's funny! Hi, Darth Daisy!" I said to the dog, who rolled onto her back again for me to rub her tummy.
paras.cn: “这个怎么样：如何用泻盐制作水晶尖刺？” “听起来很无聊，” 我回答。“那你为什么叫她黛西？” 他没有从屏幕上抬起头。“我姐姐给她起的名。我想叫她达斯。其实，严格来说，她的全名是达斯·黛西，但我们从没真的那么叫过她。” “达斯·黛西！太好笑了！嗨，达斯·黛西！” 我对那只狗说，她又翻过身来让我揉她的肚子。

vocab.ex: I don't like this idea. What about we try something else?
The science experiment was about growing beautiful crystal spikes.
Soaking in a bath with Epsom salt can help relax sore muscles.
The lecture was so boring that I almost fell asleep.
Technically speaking, a whale is a mammal, not a fish.

gram.name: 转换话题（用于回避）
gram.pattern: Responding to a proposal with a completely unrelated question.
gram.function: 当奥吉提出一个科学项目建议时，杰克不仅用 'Sounds boring' 否定了它，还立刻通过一个毫不相关的问题 'So why'd you call her Daisy?' 来彻底转换话题。这是一种非常直接的回避策略，表明了他对讨论科学项目的极度不情愿。

example.en: A: We need to talk about the budget. B: So, did you see the game last night?
example.cn: A：我们需要谈谈预算。B：所以，你昨晚看比赛了吗？

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、在对话中改变方向的技巧。

paras.en: "Okay, this one is the one," said August, pointing to a picture on the screen of a bunch of potatoes with wires poking out of them. "How to build an organic battery made of potatoes. Now, that's cool. It says here you could power a lamp with it. We could call it the Spud Lamp or something. What do you think?" "Dude, that sounds way too hard. You know I suck at science." "Shut up, you do not." "Yeah I do! I got a fifty-four on my last test. I suck at science!" "No you don't! And that was only because we were still fighting and I wasn't helping you. I can help you now. This is a good project, Jack. We've got to do it."
paras.cn: “好了，就是这个了，” 奥古斯特说，指着屏幕上一张插着电线的一堆土豆的图片。“如何用土豆制作一个有机电池。这个才叫酷。这里说你可以用它点亮一盏灯。我们可以叫它‘土豆灯’之类的。你觉得怎么样？” “老兄，那听起来也太难了。你知道我科学烂透了。” “闭嘴，你才没有。” “我就是有！我上次考试才得了五十四分。我科学烂透了！” “你没有！那只是因为我们还在吵架，我没帮你。我现在可以帮你了。这是个好项目，杰克。我们必须做这个。”

vocab.ex: A piece of paper was poking out of his pocket.
The student won the science fair with her innovative organic battery.
The engine is powerful enough to power a small boat.
For dinner, we're having steak and spuds.
I love watching basketball, but I really suck at playing it.
It's getting late; we've got to go.

gram.name: 安慰与重塑过去失败
gram.pattern: Denying a negative self-assessment and providing an alternative explanation.
gram.function: 奥吉没有简单地接受杰克的自我贬低（'I suck at science'）。他首先直接否定（'No you don't!'），然后提供了一个新的、将责任归于外部环境（他们当时在吵架）的解释。这种“重塑框架”的沟通方式，不仅是一种安慰，更是通过承担部分“责任”来修复友谊和建立对方信心的强大工具。

example.en: A: I'm so stupid for failing that test. B: You're not stupid! That was only because you were sick all week.
example.cn: A：我考砸了，真是太蠢了。B：你不蠢！那只是因为你病了一整周。

gram.constraints: 是一种展现高情商和同理心的沟通技巧。

paras.en: "Fine, whatever." I shrugged. Just then there was a knock on the door. A teenage girl with long dark wavy hair poked her head inside the door. She wasn't expecting to see me. "Oh, hey," she said to both of us. "Hey, Via," said August, looking back at the computer screen. "Via, this is Jack. Jack, that's Via." "Hey," I said, nodding hello. "Hey," she said, looking at me carefully. I knew the second Auggie said my name that he had told her about the stuff I had said about him. I could tell from the way she looked at me. In fact, the way she looked at me made me think she remembered me from that day at Carvel on Amesfort Avenue all those years ago.
paras.cn: “行吧，随便。” 我耸了耸肩。就在那时，门口传来了敲门声。一个留着长长深色卷发的少女把头探进门里。她没想到会看到我。“哦，嗨，” 她对我们俩说。“嗨，维娅，” 奥古斯特说，回头看着电脑屏幕。“维娅，这是杰克。杰克，那是维娅。” “嘿，” 我说，点头问好。“嘿，” 她说，仔细地看着我。奥吉一说出我的名字，我就知道他已经告诉了她我说的关于他的那些话。我能从她看我的方式中看出来。事实上，她看我的方式让我想起，她还记得多年前在艾姆斯福特大道Carvel店的那一天。

vocab.mean: （表示不情愿的同意）行吧，随便
vocab.ex: You want to go to that movie instead? Fine, whatever.
There was a loud knock on the door late at night.
My boss just poked his head in to say hello.
Please read the instructions carefully before you begin.

gram.name: 从非语言线索推断信息
gram.pattern: I knew/could tell + [conclusion] + from the way [someone] [action].
gram.function: 叙述者通过观察一个非语言线索（维娅看他的方式），推断出了两个重要的信息：1）奥吉已经告诉了她万圣节的事；2）她可能还记得多年前的另一件事。这种通过观察细微行为来解读他人内心状态和背景知识的能力，是小说中一个反复出现的主题，也展现了叙述者的高度敏感性。

example.en: I could tell he was lying from the way he avoided my gaze.
example.cn: 我能从他躲避我目光的样子看出他在撒谎。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过“展示而非告知”来推动叙事和塑造人物的有效技巧。

paras.en: "Auggie, I have a friend I want you to meet, okay?" she said. "He's coming over in a few minutes." "Is he your new boyfriend ?" August teased. Via kicked the bottom of his chair. "Just be nice," she said, and left the room. "Dude, your sister's hot," I said. "I know." "She hates me, right? You told her about the Halloween Incident?" "Yeah." "Yeah, she hates me or yeah, you told her about Halloween?" "Both."
paras.cn: “奥吉，我有个朋友想让你见见，好吗？” 她说。“他几分钟后就过来。” “他是你的新男朋友吗？” 奥古斯特逗他。维娅踢了一下他椅子的底部。“客气点就行，” 她说，然后离开了房间。“老兄，你姐姐真辣，” 我说。“我知道。” “她讨厌我，对吧？你告诉她万圣节事件了？” “是啊。” “是啊她讨厌我，还是是啊你告诉她万圣节的事了？” “都是。”

vocab.ex: Why don't you come over for dinner on Friday?
His older brothers always tease him about his new haircut.
All the guys in the class thought the new student was hot.
I hate the taste of broccoli.
A: Do you want coffee or tea? B: I'll have both, please.

gram.name: 用于澄清的对话结构
gram.pattern: A or B? -> C (Both).
gram.function: 当一个回答（'Yeah'）可能有两种解释时，提问者通过一个 'A or B?' 的选择问句来寻求精确的澄清。奥吉用一个单词 'Both' 来回答，不仅简洁地确认了两种情况都属实，也以一种非常直接、不加掩饰的方式结束了对话，其坦率本身就带有一种幽默感和终结性。

example.en: A: Did you forget or were you just late? B: Both, actually.
example.cn: A：你是忘了还是只是迟到了？B：其实，两者都有。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常真实的、模仿日常对话中澄清歧义过程的技巧。

paras.en: Two minutes later the sister came back with this guy named Justin. Seemed like a cool enough dude. Longish hair. Little round glasses. He was carrying a big long shiny silver case that ended in a sharp point on one end. "Justin, this is my little brother, August," said Via. "And that's Jack." "Hey, guys," said Justin, shaking our hands. He seemed a little nervous. I guess maybe it was because he was meeting August for the first time. Sometimes I forget what a shock it is the first time you meet him. "Cool room."
paras.cn: 两分钟后，姐姐带着一个叫贾斯汀的家伙回来了。看起来是个足够酷的家伙。半长的头发。小圆眼镜。他提着一个又大又长、闪闪发光的银色箱子，一端是尖的。“贾斯汀，这是我的小弟弟，奥古斯特，” 维娅说。“那是杰克。” “嘿，伙计们，” 贾斯汀说，和我们握着手。他似乎有点紧张。我猜可能是因为他第一次见到奥古斯特。有时候我忘了第一次见到他时是多大的震撼。“很酷的房间。”

vocab.ex: He's a pretty cool dude.
She cut her hair to a longish bob.
Be careful with that knife; it has a very sharp point.
He always gets nervous before a big presentation.
It was a huge shock to hear that the company was closing.

gram.name: 描述性片段
gram.pattern: A series of noun phrases used for description.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列语法上不完整的句子片段（'Longish hair. Little round glasses.'），作者创造了一种快速、印象式的描述风格，模仿了人们在初次见面时快速捕捉对方外貌特征的过程。

example.en: I remember my first car. Old. Blue. A little rusty.
example.cn: 我记得我的第一辆车。旧的。蓝色的。有点生锈。

gram.constraints: 是一种在非正式叙事中创造生动、快速印象的文学技巧。

paras.en: "Are you Via's boyfriend?" Auggie asked mischievously, and his sister pulled his cap down over his face. "What's in your case?" I said. "A machine gun?" "Ha!" answered the boyfriend. "That's funny. No, it's a, uh . . . fiddle." "Justin's a fiddler," said Via. "He's in a zydeco band." "What the heck is a zydeco band?" said Auggie, looking at me.
paras.cn: “你是维娅的男朋友吗？” 奥吉淘气地问，他姐姐把他的帽子拉下来盖住了他的脸。“你箱子里是什么？” 我说。“机关枪吗？” “哈！” 那个男朋友回答。“真好笑。不，是，呃……一把小提琴。” “贾斯汀是个小提琴手，” 维娅说。“他在一个柴迪科乐队里。” “什么鬼是柴迪科乐队？” 奥吉看着我问。

vocab.ex: The little boy smiled mischievously as he hid his sister's toy.
He pulled down the window shade to block the sun.
The action movie featured a long scene with a machine gun.

vocab.mean: （尤指用于民间音乐的）小提琴
vocab.ex: The musician played a lively tune on his fiddle.
The band needed a new fiddler for their country music tour.

vocab.mean: 柴迪科乐队（一种路易斯安那州的音乐风格）
vocab.ex: We danced all night to the energetic music of the zydeco band.

gram.name: 连珠炮式提问
gram.pattern: A quick succession of questions from different characters.
gram.function: 通过两个男孩提出的一系列快速、直接、毫不掩饰好奇心的问题，作者生动地刻画了他们孩子气的、直率的性格。这种对话节奏不仅推动了情节，也揭示了贾斯汀这个“闯入者”所面临的来自家庭内部的“审问”。

example.en: As soon as he walked in, they hit him with questions: 'Where were you? Who are you with? Why didn't you call?'
example.cn: 他一进门，他们就向他连珠炮式地发问：‘你去哪了？你和谁在一起？你为什么不打电话？’

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中创造动态和揭示人物关系的有效技巧。

paras.en: "It's a type of music," said Justin. "Like Creole music." "What's Creole?" I said. "You should tell people that's a machine gun," said Auggie. "Nobody would ever mess with you." "Ha, I guess you're right," Justin said, nodding and tucking his hair behind his ears. "Creole's the kind of music they play in Louisiana," he said to me. "Are you from Louisiana?" I asked. "No, um," he answered, pushing up his glasses. "I'm from Brooklyn."
paras.cn: “是一种音乐类型，” 贾斯汀说。“像克里奥尔音乐。” “什么是克里奥尔？” 我说。“你应该告诉别人那是机关枪，” 奥吉说。“就没人敢惹你了。” “哈，我猜你说得对，” 贾斯汀说，点着头并把头发撩到耳后。“克里奥尔是他们在路易斯安那州演奏的那种音乐，” 他对我说。“你来自路易斯安那州吗？” 我问。“不，嗯，” 他推了推眼镜回答。“我来自布鲁克林。”

vocab.ex: New Orleans is famous for its delicious Creole cuisine.
He's a tough guy; you don't want to mess with him.
She tucked a stray strand of hair behind her ear.
He had a habit of pushing up his glasses on his nose.

gram.name: 紧张的非语言线索
gram.pattern: Describing fidgety or self-soothing actions.
gram.function: 通过描述贾斯汀一系列不自觉的小动作（'tucking his hair behind his ears', 'pushing up his glasses'），作者无需直接说明，就有效地传达了他面对两个男孩直接提问时的紧张和不自在。这是一种“展示而非告知”的叙事技巧。

example.en: While waiting for his interview, he kept tapping his foot on the floor.
example.cn: 在等待面试时，他不停地用脚点地。

gram.constraints: 肢体语言是揭示人物内心状态的有力工具。

gram.name: 反高潮式幽默
gram.pattern: Building up expectation for something exotic, then revealing something mundane.
gram.function: 这个场景的幽默感来自于“反高潮”。对话建立了一系列关于贾斯汀的“异域”想象（神秘的乐器箱、柴迪科和小提琴、路易斯安那州），但最终的答案却是一个极其普通、近在咫尺的地方（“布鲁克林”）。这种期望与现实的巨大落差，打破了之前的神秘感，创造出一种荒诞的、出人意料的幽默效果，并成为两个男孩之间的一个“内部笑话”。

example.en: He described his dangerous journey through jungles and over mountains... to get to the grocery store down the street.
example.cn: 他描述了他穿越丛林、翻越高山的危险旅程……就是为了去街那头的杂货店。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过打破预期来创造幽默的高级技巧。
